SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fisher Mr P.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the absence of my colleague the honourable member for Murray (Mr Lloyd), the shadow Minister, who at this moment is preparing to leave with a delegation to the United States, I wish to make a few comments. Firstly, I thank the Leader of the House (Mr Beazley) for deferring the legislation when it was last before this place. The tabling of two pages of amendments I believe did offend the forms of this House. The Opposition parties had little time to peruse and assess those amendments; of course, it was necessary for us to discuss the amendments with representatives of the industry.

SPEECH.PARA: In the time that has elapsed we have had the opportunity to consult with the leadership of the Australian dried fruits industry, a major part of which is in my electorate of Mallee. Following this consultation the Opposition is satisfied that the amendments before the Committee are both satisfactory in a technical sense and are sensible in overcoming some of the shoddy drafting that existed in the legislation.

There is no purpose in delaying the Committee because there was considerable debate on the legislation during the last sitting. Briefly, the history of the Australian dried fruits industry is one of success and stability in marketing and discipline in quality control. This has been brought about particularly by the mature leadership the industry has had over the past 100 years. The Opposition is disappointed that this specialist industry, which produces a unique Australian product, is being forced by the Government to become part of the Australian Horticultural Corporation. In addition, it is being charged some $60,000 a year for what is a very dubious pleasure.

The Australian Horticultural Corporation may have an important role in drawing together a diversity of horticultural industries that lack the necessary skills, marketing structure and professionalism to meet the demands of world trading. But the Australian dried fruits industry does not have that problem. It is a specialist industry that has been extremely successful in marketing in a very difficult climate. The Opposition believes, as does the industry, that it is an extraordinary decision to place the industry under the umbrella of the Corporation.

I acknowledge that the industry is being given within the Corporation a unique level of independence, but the move was unnecessary and will impose unnecessary costs on a very successful industry. However, the Opposition supports the legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McGauran Mr P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is not my intention to delay the Committee this morning, but the reason why these amendments to the Australian Horticultural Corporation Amendment Bill are being reconsidered today has to be stressed because it is an issue which should be of interest to both Government and Opposition members. TALK.START.PARA: —I suggest to the honourable member for Gippsland that that is not pertinent. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Costello Mr P.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Trade Practices Amendment Bill 1990 proposes to amend section 50 of the Trade Practices Act, which relates to mergers and acquisitions. The purpose of the Bill is said to be to remedy a defect which became apparent in a case known as Trade Practices Commission v. Australian Iron and Steel Pty Ltd. That case related to a transaction by which a New Zealand company, Helenus, acquired 100 per cent of New Zealand Steel.

SPEECH.PARA: Through various subsidiaries, Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd (BHP) had an interest in the acquiring vehicle, but it did not control the vehicle which purchased New Zealand Steel. Section 50 prohibits a corporation from acquiring, directly or indirectly, shares in a body corporate if this would lead to market domination or, where the corporation already dominates the market, a substantial strengthening in the power of the corporation to control or dominate the market.

It was held in the Trade Practices Commission v. Australian Iron and Steel Pty Ltd case that a corporation does not indirectly acquire shares in a body corporate where the shares are acquired by a subsidiary unless that subsidiary acts as agent for, or otherwise for and on behalf of, the corporation. This meant that it could not be said that BHP or Australian Iron and Steel Pty Ltd directly or indirectly acquired shares in New Zealand Steel as there was no allegation that Helenus acquired the shares as agent for any other corporation. This was not new law; the case followed previous authority. The case did not open a loophole, nor did it disclose any omission which had not previously been known of. What the case did was confirm the existing state of the law.

The Trade Practices Commission was naturally concerned about this case, having taken the case and having lost it, and it sought to evoke interest in the decision and agitate with the Government for an amendment as a result. But the Trade Practices Commission went further than was necessary in evoking interest in this particular decision by encouraging speculation that the case had opened a loophole and encouraging speculation that News Corporation Ltd could take advantage of this so-called loophole to acquire the Fairfax newspaper group.

Let me make it clear: the Trade Practices Commission has a role in commenting on the operation of the Trade Practices Act and it does this by an annual report to Parliament. Indeed, in its 1989-90 annual report, it drew attention to the shortcomings of section 50. But the Trade Practices Commission is not a policy making body. Its role is to enforce the law as it currently stands-that is, enforce the current laws.

The Trade Practices Commission has a fine line to walk and it crosses over that line when it seeks to become a player in the policy making process. In this instance, Professor Baxt, the Chairman of the Trade Practices Commission, went too far. He crossed that line when he made public pronouncements on the desirability of News Corporation's acquisition of Herald and Weekly Times Ltd, an acquisition which was made under the term of office of his predecessor as Chairman of the Trade Practices Commission in 1987.

When the New Zealand Steel case was decided, the Trade Practices Commission encouraged the reopening of the decision which allowed News Corporation to acquire the Herald and Weekly Times Group. By connecting that matter, which was a matter of public controversy, with the BHP case it drew a great deal of publicity-publicity, as one would expect, in the Fairfax newspaper group and in the Australian Broadcasting Corporation. More than that, nothing could be expected to more excite the back bench of the Australian Labor Party than the possibility of News Corporation maintaining or extending its ownership of the print media in Australia. Indeed, the Labor Party seized on this opportunity to reopen that whole issue, which has been a festering sore for the Labor Party for a very long time.

The Trade Practices Commission has enough work in law enforcement. It compromises its role if it seeks a high profile policy role especially if it becomes a regular repository of media comment. The Trade Practices Commission, by linking the News takeover of the Herald and Weekly Times and by linking a possible takeover by News of the Fairfax Group with the outcome in the BHP steel case, did not distinguish itself in this episode. It did raise a lot of questions, particularly in the business community, about what the Trade Practices Commission sees its role as being.

The Chairman of the Trade Practices Commission, Professor Baxt, is leaving the Commission in a short time. The Government should bear in mind what happened in this case when it comes to appointing a successor. It should bear in mind what it believes the role of the Trade Practices Commission should be and, when it appoints somebody to the position, it should have very firmly in mind that the policy and direction of the Trade Practices Commission ought to be enforcement rather than high profile media speculation or, indeed, regular contributions to the public policy making process.

A large degree of responsibility for this episode rests with the Government, which is all at sea on competition policy. We have the Keating view, which is a laissez faire view that things ought to be allowed to take place in the market without a great deal of government intervention. I should say that that is his general view, but when it comes to things such as the ANZ-National Mutual merger he is not above intervening himself. Indeed, he came under some criticism from the Trade Practices Commission over that episode, which had a statute that would have allowed a test of that proposed merger to have taken place, but he circumvented that.

The Labor backbench still consists mainly of unreconstructed interventionists who would like much more government intervention in the marketplace. I hear in the media, even as late as today, that the Labor back bench still believes it can get some kind of inquiry into media ownership and reopen the events of 1987 in relation to News Corporation's takeover of the Herald and Weekly Times. The Attorney-General (Mr Duffy) is not disinterested in this aspect of competition policy. He was the Minister for Communications at about that time; he had proposals of his own but, unfortunately from his perspective, he was not able to carry the Cabinet with him. As Minister for Communications he was comprehensively rolled on that episode as well.

As Attorney-General, I hope he takes the opportunity to develop a coherent competition policy. I hope he takes the opportunity to ensure that the Trade Practices Commission does what it ought to be doing-that is, law enforcement. I hope he takes the opportunity, when he has the power to make the next appointment of the Chairman of the Trade Practices Commission, to redirect the Commission into its primary role rather than allowing it, as with so many other government agencies, to be a free player in the policy making process.

There are of course a number of government agencies in this area that all seek to have their own input. For example, we have the Prices Surveillance Authority; the Industry Commission; as I said before, the Keating view; the Duffy view; the Labor back bench view; and we might have an inquiry into media ownership. Whatever it is doing, the Government does not seem to be coordinating its approach across the board in relation to competition policy. It is just another area where the Government, devoid of real direction during this term of office, has been unable to stamp any meaningful direction onto the policy making process and come up with coherent policy initiatives.

News Corporation did not at any stage, in the aftermath of the BHP case, evince any intention of using that particular decision, which as I said was not a new law, as a basis for taking over the Fairfax operations. Even under current law News Corporation could hardly acquire shares or assets in Fairfax; it could not acquire Fairfax through subsidiaries if they acted as agents for News, and even if subsidiaries did not act as agents, through aggregation-subsection 50 (2)-the subsidiaries, being related to or associated with News, could be deemed to be in a position to dominate a market. The aggregation provisions would take effect, and thereby any acquisition that was proposed could be prevented.

After all of that brouhaha about a loophole, all of the brouhaha about News and the Herald and Weekly Times, all of the brouhaha about News and the Fairfax Group, and all of the brouhaha about an inquiry into media ownership, the new subsection (1aa) which came forth was a bit of a dud. What it proposes is to prohibit a body corporate related to, or associated with, a corporation acquiring shares in other bodies corporate if the result would be to allow a corporation to dominate a market or, if it already dominates the market, to strengthen the power of domination.

The object of the new subsection (1aa) is to prevent non-corporations which are bodies corporate acquiring shares or assets where a corporation itself would be prohibited from acquisition. It will prevent the use of bodies corporate which are not corporations being used to avoid section 50. The chances of an acquisition being done in this way are very slight, and indeed I note that the Government cannot point to a case where this in fact has been done.

So after all the brouhaha, after all the interest, and after all the expectations that were raised, when the new subsection (1aa) came forth it was not much of a sub-section at all. Indeed, when it was first announced that some legislative action would be taken, it was announced that the proposed law would take effect from the date of the announcement, which was 10 October 1990. When the Bill actually came forward there was no proposal in it, as was promised in the Parliament, to date it from 10 October 1990, but a proposal to date it from 21 December 1990 which was the date on which the second reading speech was made. Even dating it from 22 December 1990, which was a back-down from the Government's original position of dating it as from the date of the announcement in October, does have some offensive aspects.

It is, of course, a retrospective law. Retrospective laws can be justified where they do seek to close loopholes which nobody thought existed, but in this particular case, as I said before, all that the BHP case did was confirm the current state of the law, and it can hardly be said that this is a loophole. Therefore, it is very strange when the Attorney-General can point to no practical cases which have occurred in the past that it should be backdated at all.

This has raised legitimate worries in the community, and the Law Council of Australia has made a submission to the Attorney-General. The Council has commented on this. In relation to the retrospective operation of this particular Bill, the Law Council of Australia said this:

Retrospectivity in legislation of this kind is always objectionable and the practice is especially objectionable where, as in the original announcement, the public was not given any indication of the nature of the changes which were proposed.

So far as the Law Council of Australia is concerned, it finds the Attorney-General's Bill especially objectionable, and I am sure that will do a lot to gladden his heart as he comes to pass this Bill through the Parliament.

There is an argument for the substantive change-the introduction of subsection (1aa) into the section on mergers and acquisitions-and it is this: it is technically possible for a non-corporation which is a body corporate to be used by a corporation to acquire shares in a way which would offend the policy of the section. Nobody has an example of this occurring, but it could occur. If it did, it would mean that one could avoid section 50 through the use of a non-corporation body corporate. The new subsection (1aa) will prevent that.

Of course it is hard to think of non-corporation bodies corporate. I notice that the Government has given no examples. It may be that a body corporate which is not a corporation would be a State authority or perhaps even a partnership holding corporate personality or something like that. But one would have to concede that it would be a rare vehicle. I doubt whether one could point to any example where such a body corporate had actually been used for a merger or acquisition.

Certainly such bodies corporate were not used in the New Zealand Steel case. In that case, corporations were used, but they were corporations in a foreign country. I have always believed that the New Zealand Steel case was really a section 50a case. The Trade Practices Commission probably took the case on the wrong section and came up with a predictable result. There is a public policy ground behind the substantive new subsection which is to be introduced, and for that reason the Opposition will not oppose it.

The Opposition does have several reservations. It has the reservation-which the Law Council shares-about the retrospective operation. It also has the reservation as to the way in which this came onto the political agenda. As I said before, the matter was blown up as if the New Zealand Steel case had disclosed some major defect in the legislation requiring urgent attention in the national interest. Of course, the view put around was heightened by the fact that we had a dramatic announcement in the Parliament in October that the Bill would take effect as from October. Although we did not know what the Bill was going to be, it was going to take effect from the date of the announcement. When the actual offspring was brought forth, not only was it a dud, but the date of operation, as I said before, was put back.

The legislation to rectify the so-called problem is so narrow that it is unlikely to have a major effect. It does not address the problem which was described at the time as being one which required necessary and dramatic legislation. It illustrates, as I said, something of a trend, which I am concerned about, in the Trade Practices Commission to engage in policy and publicity roles when it should be directing itself to enforcement.

Another reservation is that the Bill as drafted could be beyond constitutional power because in the new subsection (1aa) it seeks to regulate bodies corporate, not merely corporations. As the Department of the Attorney-General is no doubt aware, the Commonwealth Parliament has constitutional power over corporations. This subsection is deliberately going wider than regulating corporations and seeking to regulate bodies corporate. The whole point of it is to regulate entities that are bodies corporate, not merely corporations. There is a prospect that this could be determined unconstitutional. The High Court of Australia has already ruled that the unconstitutional reach of the section can be severed. So the section can stand with the severing of this part if it is unconstitutional. Of course, if it is rendered unconstitutional and severed, the whole of the Bill in this respect will have no effect.

In addition to new proposed sub-section (1aa), the opportunity has been taken to make changes to the balance of section 50. The Law Council of Australia has put a submission to the Attorney-General, and the Attorney-General ought to answer that submission in his wrapping up of this debate on these incidental changes to section 50. The Law Council of Australia has said that the need for most of these changes is not clear and that there is a risk that unnecessary changes may have unforeseen effects on the delicate balance of section 50.

It is proposed to include references to the words `or likely to be in a position' in section 50 (2). The Law Council believes that this is unnecessary and misconceived. These words have a place in section 50 (1) to enable account to be taken of the future impact of a merger which is yet to be effected. It is not clear why this predictive element should be included in the ancillary provision of section 50 (2), which is concerned with aggregation, when one is considering the existence of dominance as a factual matter. The aggregation provisions of section 50 (2) are to determine dominance or likely dominance of a corporation for the purposes of the section.

The relevant other parts of section 50, to which section 50 (2) attaches, can only be section 50 (1) (a) and the proposed section 50 (1aa) (a), as it is only those paragraphs that deal with a corporation's dominance or likely dominance in a market. But each of these paragraphs deals with the position of dominance in a market as a result of the acquisition. The result must be a position of dominance or `likely' position of dominance. Accordingly, the introduction to section 50 (2) of a concept of likely position of dominance is surplusage, as the relevant parts of section 50 (1) and proposed section 50 (1aa) already require the same inquiry post-acquisition. The Law Council concludes that it is unnecessary to make a similar inquiry pre-acquisition because section 50 (1) (b) and proposed section 50 (1aa) (b) apply only where a corporation is-not is likely to be-in a position of dominance. So the Law Council of Australia says that it is unnecessary and surplusage.

With legislation like this which is unnecessary and surplusage there are two ways to go. We can say, `It is unnecessary and surplus; therefore, why are we passing it?' or we can say, `It is unnecessary and surplus; therefore what harm will it do if we pass it?'. I must say that I cannot get so excited over unnecessary and surplus words as to oppose right to the barricades the particular proposal. As I said before, that is why the Opposition will not oppose the Bill. But it is a question of public policy that one ought not introduce as a matter of public policy unnecessary and surplus words, because even if they do not have any effect, being unnecessary and surplus, the risk is that some time down the track in a court it can have an unforeseen consequence which nobody at this particular time has managed to figure out.

The other reason as a matter of public policy why one ought to avoid unnecessary and surplus legislation is that it does create a degree of uncertainty in the commercial community. The commercial community says, `Why is it being introduced? What does it mean? A government wouldn't introduce it if it were to have no effect; it must have some effect'. Therefore everybody has to go back to their lawyers and engage in the expensive business of taking legal advice. To some degree, it dampens commercial activity.

Of course that also has an effect in the courts. The courts come to these statutes, and they generally assume that Parliament knows what it is doing when it passes legislation. I have always thought that this was a dangerous assumption. The courts would be entitled to say, `They must have had something in mind for this. They must have wanted to change the law in some respect. It must therefore be given some effect'. The chances are that it will be given an effect which nobody anticipated at the time. So it is a very dangerous position.

I think the Attorney-General ought to give some defence as to the effect that he thinks these particular words will have, bearing in mind the submission of the Law Council of Australia, so that it is clear from the parliamentary debate what was actually intended. I have no doubt that such a task is not beyond the Attorney-General. I have no doubt that he will be able to explain that, and I hope that he does so because it may become an issue subsequently down the track when these matters come to litigation.

The Law Council of Australia also made a comment on new provisions in section 50 (2aa) and proposed section 50 (2ab); it said again that these were unnecessary and may give rise to confusion or unintended implications. The Law Council said that it was unaware of any shortcoming in the law that would warrant further legislation on the question of whether parties who together are in a position to dominate a market would need to act in concert in order to achieve that dominance. It also said the phrase `in a position' as used in sections 50 (2) and 50 (2a) already had a wide breadth and potentiality of application and that the language of both proposed sections 50 (2aa) and 50 (2ab) and that of the reference section, proposed sections 50 (2) and 50 (2a), presupposed a combined and present proposition of dominance. Accordingly, the references in proposed sections 50 (2aa) and 50 (2ab) to needing to act in concert to achieve such dominance were irrelevant. It said that in any event the question of whether the relevant entities had acted in concert in order to put themselves in a position of dominance was irrelevant.

The Law Council is the premier law body in Australia. It has put a submission to the Attorney-General's Department. The submission is that the words that are proposed may have confusing and unnecessary effects. After hearing my outline of the Law Council's submission, honourable members will surely agree with me that it is a rather complicated subject which has the potential to have confusing aspects. It is something that the Government ought to be at pains to try to clarify before this matter goes too much farther.

The Law Council also commented on the inclusion in proposed section 50 (2a) and consequential reference in proposed section 50 (2b) of the words `or to be likely to be able to exert'; it said that that was misconceived. The question is whether a party is in a position to exert a substantial degree of influence, not whether that party in fact will do so or be likely to do so. The Law Council said that the added language detracted from the strength and width of the phrase `in a position' and concluded that the change was therefore unnecessary and confusing.

I think the Law Council has done us all a service in looking quite closely at this Bill and has come up with some very strong reservations. They are reservations that we in the Opposition certainly share and it may even be that the Department, after it looks at all these things, could reconsider its position. If the Department is prepared to reconsider its position, certainly it would get support in doing so from the Opposition.

The Law Council also raised another very good point, and that is that there is no consequential alteration to section 50a. Proposed subsection 50a (7), which is designed to exclude from the application of section 50a acquisitions which come within section 50, should be amended to refer to the new subsection that is being introduced, proposed subsection (1aa). There has not been that consequential amendment to section 50a. There ought to be; there is no reason why it should not be in the Bill. By not putting it there at the moment, the Attorney-General is leading to the bringing back of this section at some later stage to tidy it up. That is a very strong point that was made by the Law Council of Australia.

I should make it clear that I believe there is a place for legal constraints on market monopolisation in a free market economy. There is a place for establishing rules so that the market operates in a fair, efficient way so that competition in a particular market is promoted. There is a case for that. One has to be careful, however, that, in prescribing the particular rules that will enhance competition, one does not go too far and that the Government does not try to rewrite the market, second-guess the market or take control of the market. These things, although they sound technical and have very specific effects, can have quite dramatic effects in the business community.

That is why it is important to get the rules as right as possible. That is why it is important that when the Government comes into this place it explains the rules as specifically as it possibly can so that not just the Parliament but also those people out in business, and the professional communities that are advising them, know what they are-the rules that are designed to promote that free and open market competition. Because we in the Opposition believe that there is a place for that, we have in the past supported trade practices provisions which are designed to promote that free and open market competition. We believe that, although the progency that comes forth with this Bill is a bit of a dud, it does cover what could be-which has not been shown-a loophole in the future. Therefore, we will not oppose it.

We ask the Government to try to do something to get a coherent approach to competition policy, a coherent approach to the Trade Practices Commission and a coherent approach to what its role will be. If the Government can do all that, perhaps the Trade Practices Commission will not feel the need to get out there into the marketplace and start doing the Government's job for it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Wright Mr K.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —Despite the claim made in the latter part of the speech by the honourable member for Higgins (Mr Costello) that he supports the principle of having standards and rules out there in the marketplace, I suspect that his contribution in this debate on the Trade Practices Amendment Bill is little more than part of the continuing attack that the Opposition has been waging against the Trade Practices Commission (TPC). It needs to be placed on the record over and over again that the Liberal and National parties are against the very Commission that administers the Trade Practices Act that this amendment applies to.
—Oh, rubbish!

—The honourable member says `Rubbish', but the Opposition has said repeatedly that it wants to do away with the Trade Practices Commission, with the consumer protection laws and the foreign investment rules. That is what the Opposition is about. On the one hand, it says that it wants to see some protections but, on the other hand, what it really wants is the law of the jungle. The honourable member for Higgins certainly has presented a rather confusing argument. On the one hand, he says that if it will close the gap he will support it and, on the other hand, he says that the Law Reform Commission considers it to be unnecessary. I suggest that the honourable member goes back to the very reason that this amendment has been brought forward-that is, to the case of the Trade Practices Commission v. Australian Iron and Steel Pty Ltd and Others in which Justice Lockhart made it very clear that he did not support the definition, as the Commission argued, of indirect and direct acquisition.

SPEECH.PARA: I note in a paper I have here that Justice Lockhart held that an indirect acquisition was one by someone on behalf of the corporation acting as agent, trustee or nominee. An acquisition by a wholly owned subsidiary or a company that otherwise was controlled by the corporation was not an indirect acquisition unless that agency arrangement existed. What does that mean? It means that corporations can structure acquisitions and mergers through subsidiaries and companies they control without running foul of section 50.

The honourable member for Higgins wants to destroy the very reputation of the Trade Practices Commission. That is why Professor Baxt was attacked. That is why the honourable member and other honourable members have been chipping away at what the TPC does for Australia and the people of Australia. It is not an isolated situation, because the Opposition holds that same view, as I said, when it comes to the Foreign Investment Review Board.

The honourable member for Higgins has the audacity to say that strengthening the provisions and redefining this provision creates uncertainty, when quite clearly it is the other way around. The need to change this provision, the need to extend section 50 (1), is because of what Justice Lockhart said. It is because of the attitude that he expressed in that case. Otherwise we could end up with a total destruction of the protection that exists under section 50 when it comes to mergers. This amendment, I believe, will close the gap. It will correct a deficiency in the merger provisions of the Trade Practices Act.

Whether it is claimed that it is only because of the Australian Iron and Steel case-what is often called the New Zealand Steel case-or whatever, the Commission has a responsibility to warn this Parliament of the problems that may arise and that have arisen. Clearly, in view of the decision by Justice Lockhart, there is a need for this change-and I am hopeful that it will overcome the problems.

For a long time I have had some concerns about mergers. I have been concerned that in the history of mergers there has been a gradual degradation of the protections that existed. As a member of the original inquiry by the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs into mergers, takeovers and monopolies, headed by the honourable member for Maribyrnong (Mr Griffiths), I expressed some concerns at the changes that were being proposed from within the governmental structure and the marketplace. There is a responsibility on both the Commission and the Government to ensure that any problems that arise are overcome. A controlling company should not be able to use a subsidiary or its association with another company to target another company and take over its assets and shares and acquire control.

It was obviously an opinion of Mr Justice Lockhart that there must be a legal link of agency. Clearly that was not the intention of the Act and this provision will overcome that problem. There have been many difficulties with mergers; it is not an easy issue. I have sat down with many people and debated what is best. Some people say that the proper way is to have no rules whatsoever: let the strongest prevail. Yet when they are involved, they change their minds.

I have had pharmacists say there should be no controls on the number of pharmacies one can own-but they do not want another pharmacy allowed near their premises. In Queensland there are restrictions on the number of pharmacies one can have and there are local government controls on where pharmacies are allowed to operate. I am not singling out pharmacists, but they are typical of the attitude that is sometimes expressed. When they are the beneficiaries they do not want any rules but when they are under threat they want protection.

There are often arguments on whether we would really benefit if we allowed all the small companies to disappear and the larger, highly concentrated companies to develop. It is argued that we would be better off letting foreign investors take over Australian companies because they control the markets we export to. That is not an argument I support. I believe there is a need for rules and controls. I accept that higher concentration in a market can be advantageous both in economic and consumer benefit terms. I acknowledge that economies of scale do produce benefits, particularly in the integration of the production process. I accept that there are savings in removing duplication of output. I acknowledge that there are advantages in asset rationalisation and that there can be higher returns from superior management. I also accept that there can be a risk reduction through diversification of operations, which I found many years ago in my newspaper business in central Queensland.

I understand those things. I understand the importance of being big when it comes to competing in international and regional terms. At the same time, we must look at the national interest, at the public benefit of marketplace ownership and control. That is the prime reason for these provisions. We want to ensure that there is not total dominance, total monopoly, to the detriment of Australians. I am amazed that over and over again in this place members of the Liberal Party talk about the free market concept of letting the forces prevail. I would rather go the other way: whilst encouraging development and mergers to bring about the benefits I have outlined, I would argue that we need to have another look at the Act and go back to some of the provisions that are there.

We have seen some changes. In 1977 we removed the clearance provision from the Act. We have changed the Act in other ways. We changed the requirement for testing mergers using the substantially lessened competition test and we introduced the dominance test. I do not support that and I believe we should return to the pre-1987 period. That is not a view I just bring forward now. As a member of the Griffiths Committee, the honourable member for Hughes (Mr Tickner) and I brought down a dissenting report, which contained a number of recommendations. We went firstly to the substantial lessening of competition test and suggested reverting to the pre-1977 situation. We also recommended that the qualification of substantial market be retained in the prohibition that exists in section 50.

However, we argued mainly around the pre-notification requirement for a merger. It is an issue that has been quite contentious, and it did not have the support of the full Committee. However, as one talks around the issue again one starts to understand why this is the better way. At the moment there is no requirement to notify. A company could move to acquire the assets or shares of another company, and there is no requirement for that company to notify anyone. That means that the Trade Practices Commission must find out itself what is going on. It does not have a magic ball it can look into and spot these things. It has to keep its ear to the ground and watch over the marketplace and the media, generally monitoring the situation.

If a merger contravenes section 50 the Trade Practices Commission is faced with a very difficult situation. It can only force the new company structure to divest its takeover target. In other words, it has to get rid of the company it either merged with or acquired. That is disruptive for shareholders or anyone dealing with the company, be they creditors or employees, and it should not be.

To take an analogy in the area of foreign investment, a foreign company cannot simply come into Australia and buy an Australian company, with the Foreign Investment Review Board or Treasury monitoring the situation and, if they find that something like that has happened, then acting. That is not how it works. What happens is that if a foreign company is interested in starting a new business or acquiring a business in Australia or entering into a partnership, if the investment amount is over a certain amount of money then by law it has to tell the Foreign Investment Review Board of its plans. It has to demonstrate to the four members of the Board what are the advantages to Australia.

It is not a hit and miss situation. It is not a situation where someone on the Board is watching over the rural industry, another member is keeping in touch with the directors of mining companies, and someone else is working in the tourist industry. We do not have such a ridiculous situation when it comes to foreign companies or governments coming into Australia and buying up companies. Instead, we have rules that say, `You shall advise. You shall not only advise of your intention, you shall outline the benefits. You shall demonstrate to our government representatives and the people of Australia what Australia shall gain from what you are doing.'

Recently ConAgra took over a large part of Elders. That caused a lot of concern in the rural sector amongst the United Graziers Association of Queensland, the Cattlemen's Union, the Cattle Council of Australia, the Australian Meat and Livestock Corporation. They were concerned at an American company taking over not just a company but an important part of the production chain-the processing point. This would add to the situation where in north Queensland 92 per cent of processing in the meat industry is now foreign owned, in central Queensland it is something like 85 per cent and in southern Queensland 47 per cent.

The industry people expressed immediate concern, but they had one advantage: they knew that ConAgra, by law, had to go to the Foreign Investment Review Board and explain what it was going to do; it had to explain what it was going to invest; it had to explain what the advantages were to Australia in terms of new markets, new technology, better jobs and more jobs. It had to set those details down in black and white, and then and only then-consideration having been given by the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin) and by the Treasurer (Mr Keating)-did we have the Foreign Investment Review Board approve this and recommend it to Cabinet.

Yet what have we had when it comes to internal takeovers, internal acquisitions and internal mergers? We have had a total hit and miss situation where the company has been able to move and actually take over, and it has been up to the Trade Practices Commission to have the nous, personnel and resources to be able to know what has been going on.

I argue that the Act ought to be changed so that we establish a pre-notification system for mergers and acquisitions, just as we have in the case of foreign investment takeovers, partnerships or acquisitions. It would certainly help the Trade Practices Commission because the Commission would be able then to assess, I believe in a better way, whether or not the takeover or merger would create dominance in the marketplace. It would see whether the takeover or merger would destroy competition out there in the marketplace. It would place a requirement on the companies to come forward and explain what they were doing and the benefits of what they were doing. If they were not ashamed of it or if they had nothing to hide, then I believe the companies would have no reason not to advise of their merger plan. It would be dealt with, no doubt, in total confidence. There would be no breakdown of that. It does not happen within the Foreign Investment Review Board. It ought not, and I believe it would not, happen with the Trade Practices Commission. It would overcome the stupid situation that if a merger does take place and the Trade Practices Commission believes it contravenes section 50, then either the Trade Practices Commission has to approve it while not wanting to do so or, if it wants to go against the merger, it must force the merging companies to divest themselves of the assets that they have just recently acquired.

I also believe that it is proper that there be these negotiations, and if one looks at the present situation, one finds there is an informal structure. When the Trade Practices Commission finds out about a merger or proposed merger, it appears that it makes contact with the merging companies or acquiring company and the parties sit down and talk it through in an informal way. But there is nothing binding on the companies; it really comes back to the Trade Practices Commission knowing about the proposed merger. There is no requirement on the companies to come forward and talk about it.

We do have a process of authorisation, and I believe that if we were to have a pre-notification system, it would strengthen this existing informal consultative process that is used by the Trade Practices Commission and it would enhance the authorisation process, because it would make available to the Trade Practices Commission far better information. It is not a new idea. As I said, it was put forward in our committee of inquiry in our dissenting report back in May 1989. It has been argued before in all sorts of inquiries and green papers and I believe it is needed today. I appreciate that at the time of the inquiry there was argument that the existing system seemed to be working well enough. I argue that it does not work well enough and that we can improve on it.

We need to remove the hit and miss process that appears to exist today. We need to do away with this sole monitoring responsibility on the Trade Practices Commission and let there be a legal responsibility and requirement on the companies to come forward and explain the reasons why, because that is the final issue. We want to see better and more efficient companies operating in this country. We want to see them being able to compete regionally within the Asian and South Pacific areas and internationally.

The ultimate result of that may be a higher concentration of the marketplace production instruments. But if that is to be and if it is to be in the public interest and for the national benefit, there should be no difficulty in demonstrating that. We need, as I say, to place the onus on the merging companies. We need to ensure that the nation truly is benefiting and the public interest is given due recognition when these mergers take place. I totally support the provisions that have been brought to the attention of this place by the Attorney-General (Mr Duffy) in trying to overcome the gap that exists there because of the decision and the opinion expressed by Lockhart J, but I believe that we need again to reopen this issue of pre-notification of mergers, because in it there is value. Despite the opposition that did come before our committee back in 1988 and 1989, there are now strong grounds for implementing a system that is very much like the Foreign Investment Review Board system, which works in the national interest.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rocher Mr A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Trade Practices Amendment Bill extends the application of section 50 of the Trade Practices Act, which prohibits mergers and acquisitions that are found to result in market dominance. The amendments are designed to close a potential loophole which would allow a company to gain effective commercial control of another company through intermediaries and thereby circumvent the existing provisions of the Act. Under this Bill, section 50 of the Act will take account of bodies corporate indirectly related to or associated with a corporation when assessing whether a merger or acquisition results in market dominance.

SPEECH.PARA: This issue first arose in the case of the merger between a Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd subsidiary and Helenus Corporation where the Trade Practices Commission (TPC) alleged that BHP had a controlling interest in the vehicle purchasing Helenus. Initially, the Commission sought the divestiture of shareholdings in New Zealand Steel by Australian Iron and Steel Pty Ltd. The matter was subsequently settled out of court following a number of undertakings being given on the part of BHP and Australian Iron and Steel regarding the treatment of New Zealand Steel.

There is also some concern that this loophole could be utilised by News Limited in acquiring some of the assets of the Fairfax group. This would seem unlikely, and News Limited has certainly disavowed any such intention. It would appear that such a move would breach the existing provisions of the Trade Practices Act and Professor Bob Baxt, the outgoing Trade Practices Commissioner, has certainly pledged to fight any such move-and I quote him-`all the way to the High Court'. There is thus considerable doubt as to whether this amendment is a pressing requirement for there to be an effective trade practices law. It is however appropriate that, in the interests of consistency and fairness in the application of the law, potential loopholes such as these should be closed.

This Bill is the first legislative manifestation of a push by the Trade Practices Commission for greater powers and tougher penalties under the Trade Practices Act, including greater powers to order the divestiture of asset holdings. Before we proceed with grants of greater power to the Commission, we need to examine some of the problems with the application and enforcement of the existing trade practices laws. There is considerable scope for improvements in the administration of the existing law by recognising some of the inherent limitations on the effective pursuit of antitrust policies.

The Trade Practices Commission has an important role to play in ensuring the prevalence of competition in the Australian economy through its powers to initiate proceedings against anti-competitive practices. The difficulties with trade practices law arise in defining and then identifying anticompetitive commercial activities. There are many instances in which the existence of monopolistic and other anticompetitive practices is very clear cut. This is particularly true of government-sponsored regulatory schemes where the lack of competition is enshrined in legislation or institutional arrangements. It is noteworthy that the Trade Practices Commission has located its push for greater powers in the context of the need for micro-economic reform, and the Government's efforts, such as they are, are on the same front.

The Trade Practices Commission suggests that it needs greater powers to ensure that the fullest possible benefits flow from the micro-economic reform process. Of course, this strongly suggests that there is something seriously wrong with the Government's micro-economic reforms. If micro-economic reform is about ensuring competition, a more active Trade Practices Commission can only be indicative of a failed reform process. We see this in a number of areas where the Government has given the Trade Practices Commission a wider brief in implicit recognition of the failure of its own reforms.

The Commission has been given a mandate by the Government to oversee the deregulation of domestic aviation, where the Commission has already identified and expressed its concern about Government-sponsored barriers to entry into the domestic aviation market.

We are also seeing a greater role for the Commission with respect to telecommunications, in association with Austel. It is in the area of telecommunications that we begin to find inconsistencies in the application of trade practices laws. Despite the Commission's insistence that its brief includes the Government's commercial operations, and its claim that the telecommunications market will be `treated in the same way as other markets' we find that the TPC has had little or nothing to say about the merger of OTC Ltd and Telecom.

This merger must rank as one of the largest corporate consolidations in Australia in recent times. It certainly results in market dominance of the basic network by the newly created monstercom. The Government has wheeled out a lame duck competitor in the form of a debt-ridden Aussat as its version of competition on the basic network until 1997. Overseas experience with satellite-based competitors establishing networks is far from encouraging. Professor Henry Ergas of Monash University suggests:
Foreign carriers are no more interested in competing with the proposed megacom in core network facilities than they are in going to the moon.

Yet despite the unambiguous dominance of the telecommunications market by the new monstercom, and the anti-competitive implications of this dominance, the Trade Practices Commission has been silent on the merger. We have heard not a word. Nor has the Commission commented on Austel's plans to allow monstercom and OTC to price discriminate between themselves and any third carrier.
These are far from being the only examples of inconsistency in the current approach to trade practices. As John Logan et al have pointed out, section 50 of the Act:

. . . ignores the fact that government has encouraged coalitions such as unions and trade associations to amalgamate into even larger groups so that it can deal with just one industry leader in the relevant group. This . . . imposes on buyers the inevitable costs of cartelisation, which is enhanced by the formation of industry coalitions.

The Government also presides over occupational licensing and a wide range of statutory monopolies that have received little attention from the TPC, despite their dominance of the markets in which they are located.

While it is a relatively simple matter to identify the market dominance that results from government-sponsored arrangements such as the merger of Telecom Australia and OTC, private sector mergers and acquisitions present numerous difficulties. The principal difficulty lies in defining the notions of dominance, of market and of offsetting public benefit. The idea of market dominance is inherently ambiguous, given that markets are not discrete entities. Dominance may be identified on a particular drawing of market boundaries but this may be at the expense of recognising markets for substitute goods and services that would mitigate the anticompetitive effects of control over a particular market segment. Markets are often delineated artificially. For example, the print and electronic media are treated as separate markets rather than, as arguably they should be, a combined market for news media.

The Commission subscribes to a static general equilibrium view of economic activity. It tends to ignore the roles of uncertainty and the costliness of knowledge in the decision making of entrepreneurs. What may look to the Commission like an attempt to corner a market may be founded on an entirely different perception on the part of an entrepreneur. Studies of open market mergers and takeovers indicate that they tend to succeed only where they offer considerable benefits to customers and reduced production costs. It is extremely difficult for the Commission to distinguish between anticompetitive practices and returns due to entrepreneurship. Firms may well obtain and hold market share simply by virtue of being continuously more efficient than their rivals. That is what it is all about.

In the case of a hypothetical merger between News Ltd and the Fairfax group, the subsequent increased dominance of News Ltd would stem largely from the failures of the Fairfax group. No doubt the Commission could then cite public interest considerations for its opposition to such a merger, but the example points to the fact that antitrust policy may serve to reward poor business practices and to punish market successes. These ambiguities, coupled with the fact that the TPC is the only body that can undertake proceedings for breaches of the Act, mean that, as a former Trade Practices Commissioner has pointed out, `Its opinions on matters such as market and dominance constitute the de facto law in this area'.

The Commission thus has considerable discretionary power, which raises the important issue of the Commission's accountability for its actions. It is essential that the Commission make every effort to ensure that its views on these subjects and its decisions are well known if there is to be certainty in the application of trade practices law. But the fact is that the Commission has not been as forthcoming as it should have been in this regard. It is worth quoting at length what Warren Pengilley, a former Trade Practices Commissioner and now trade practices lawyer with Sly and Weigall, had to say on the subject. He said:

My concern is that the Commission is not seen to be acting in a disciplined manner or consistently . . . Regrettably, no one is really in a position to comment on or criticise the Commission's decisions, because no detailed reasoning-only a most generalistic press release-is provided by the Commission. One gathers the impression all too often that informal negotiations, rather than disciplined reasoning, governs the result. This cannot be in the best interests of company merger policy in Australia. Neither can it be in the best interests of those who want to know what the law really is (or at least what the Commission thinks it is). Nor in my view can it be ultimately in the best interests of the Commission, which is seen as involving itself in a non-accountable, `clubby' negotiating process.

They are words of a former commissioner. Pengilley has cited the Coles-Myer and Bell-BHP cases and the Ansett and East-West Airlines case as examples where the Commission has failed properly to account for its position. The Commission has shown little sensitivity to many of these issues. Indeed, at least one commissioner has expressed a desire to return to the even more permissive notion of `substantial lessening of competition' in assessing the merits of mergers and acquisitions, a definition which the Fraser Government rightly did away with in 1977.

Merger and acquisitions policy raises important questions of due process. With the law becoming apparent only during the course of legal proceedings initiated at the discretion of the TPC, the law takes on an arbitrary, retrospective and capricious character. Many of the legal and economic issues raised by antitrust policy are notoriously intractable. As the Commission states in its annual report for 1989-90, `such issues have troubled judicial authorities in countries with a longer and richer history of antitrust enforcement' than our own.

The Commission has questioned the capacity of ordinary courts to deal with these issues and has expressed its preference for them to be handled by trade practices tribunals. Yet none of this seems to temper the Commission's enthusiasm for enforcing its brief. All of these issues need to be better addressed before we proceed with further grants of power to the Commission.

Given the difficult economic climate, the importance of Australian firms achieving the size necessary for export success, it would be perverse for the Government to sanction an over-zealous Trade Practices Commission now. With recession induced reductions in the size of the various industries, firms may inadvertently come to possess greater market strength. This recession that we had to have, the recession that has been engineered, will have the effect of removing competition. The mere fact that it leads to the elimination of some firms from practically all industries will mean that some firms may find that their competitive position is inadvertently enhanced.

Econometric models have shown that a one per cent increase in antitrust cases by the United States Justice Department can produce a 0.17 per cent increase in the rate of unemployment, other things being equal. Similar studies should be commissioned here so that we can better assess the true cost of antitrust policies which include the costs of litigation and the running of enforcement bureaucracies.

Trade practices law should also not be put in the position of attempting to remedy commercial concentrations that result from our ridiculous restrictions on foreign ownership, particularly in the area of print media and broadcasting. It has become increasingly obvious that a substantial increase in the level of foreign ownership in Australian media will be necessary to foster a viable and competitive industry structure.

The view that there is a national interest in domestic ownership of media outlets is becoming more and more anachronistic in an international news environment that is becoming increasingly oblivious to national boundaries. We often treat overseas entrepreneurs as though they were agents of foreign-and by implication, hostile-powers, rather than business people with legitimate interests and with a contribution to make to Australia's economy and to various industries.

Trade practices law has little prospect of fostering a competitive market structure in the media industry in the face of xenophobic restrictions on further foreign investment. Interference by the Trade Practices Commission could well result in a further decline in competitiveness if it undermines the viability of existing corporations. For example, this might have occurred had the Commission taken action against the restructuring of News Ltd papers in Sydney and Melbourne in an attempt to protect the precarious position of the Fairfax group. News Ltd should have been free to restructure its operations without having to look over its shoulder at the impact of such restructuring on failing competitors.

The honourable member for Higgins (Mr Costello) has indicated that the Opposition does not intend to oppose the Bill. That is not to say that we do not have criticisms to make. Despite the rather irrational assertions of the honourable member for Capricornia (Mr Wright), we support-as we did when we were in government-the existence of the Trade Practices Commission and its objectives in ensuring that monopoly enterprises do not grow to dominate a particular market.

Nevertheless, there is a lot for the Trade Practices Commission still to do. It could very well address itself to the market dominance of government trading entities, statutory authorities and the like. It has made sympathetic noises on occasions in the past, but it has never tackled that area. The Trade Practices Commission should be accountable. It should give its reasons for decisions and in doing so, it should engender more certainty into the decision making process, whether it be in connection with mergers or in commerce generally.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tuckey Mr C.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Trade Practices Amendment Bill is specifically about market dominance. I too listened to the honourable member for Capricornia (Mr Wright) and I would like to express my own view regarding the Trade Practices Act and the Trade Practices Commission. The philosophy of the Liberal Party of Australia is that it deplores the intrusion of government into the operations of business. In other words, it deplores government becoming a WA Inc. or a Victoria Inc. It does not believe in government owning the shop, but I think it accepts totally the responsibility of government to be the umpire in the interests of smaller businesses and of the community at large.

SPEECH.PARA: I think we have to get that matter straight. It does not mean that from time to time the Opposition or the Liberal Party will choose not to criticise the activities of any umpires should they not be performing their tasks in the manner which we think is appropriate. That is what Parliament is all about and that is what we should be here for.

I have taken the opportunity to speak on this Bill because I have great concerns arising from constituent problems in my electorate that I think need more detailed answers from the Attorney-General (Mr Duffy) than those I have received from the Commission and from certain Ministers relating to trade and commerce. I am referring to the activities in Western Australia of the Australian Northbound Shipping Conference, otherwise referred to as ANSCON.

It is an interesting aspect of monopoly that when the Trade Practices Act was first considered, shipping conferences were thought to be better excluded. Their salesmanship over many years had convinced even Australians and shippers that they were better serviced by a monopoly. Of course, that is stupid and should be recorded as such. There has never been evidence that a monopoly gets the best price or even the best service, but over time shippers have been convinced that fragmentation of a service might be worse than having to tolerate a monopoly that sets its own prices. There is no competition on prices and in the end, as I wish to evidence today, no competition on service.

The Japanese market imports 800,000 tonnes of hay each year. It is a very interesting market because the hay is used for feeding cattle-19 million cattle, I think. The beef industry, or the dairy industry as it really is, is very peculiar as there are no large producers generally; they are all very small. Today on the Australian scene, nearly all hay is baled in almost one tonne lots in large, round, six-foot diameter bales or similarly very large square bales. This then has to be broken down into bales smaller than the traditional bale we saw in the paddocks years ago, something about two-thirds of that size.

When I asked why hay was exported to Japan in this fashion, I was told that these bales of hay ended up almost in the supermarket; Mum rode a pushbike into town, put one bale on the handlebar and took it home to feed the cattle. So much for Japan and its technology. In terms of feeding stock, it is still at the level of putting a bale of hay on a pushbike; something that a woman can pick up.

As there is an 800,000-tonne per annum market for hay in Japan, certain Australian entrepreneurs have made the attempt to sell into that market. Australia now has between 30,000 and 40,000 tonnes of that 800,000-tonne market-not very much-but in the present depressed rural situation, it is a very important bit of business. Farmers are being paid about $100 a tonne for their hay and that is good business.

Unfortunately, from there on the costs escalate at a very rapid rate. In developing this market one of the most successful entrepreneurs in my State and one of my constituents, Mr Robbie Robinson of Midwest Fodder, was able to convince the Geraldton Port Authority, which is the port close to where he operates and is in an area where huge volumes of hay can be grown, to buy a mobile container crane. The Columbus Line was convinced to commence an out-of-conference service into Geraldton and Fremantle. This was a trial procedure which, I understand, was to operate for a couple of years, at which time a more permanent service could be established. There were some problems. The availability of loadings was not as substantial as one might have desired, but it was improving and it was going reasonably well.

Overnight Columbus announced it would not continue. This was a huge blow to the Geraldton Port Authority, which happened to have a $4m crane and nothing for it to do. We were then advised that one of the directors of Columbus had made some remarks at a farewell dinner suggesting that the company's reason for stopping was not really that it was short of business-it was prepared to hang in there because things seemed to be improving-but rather that it had been heavied by the Japanese banking system.

I wrote to the Commission about this and, to its credit, it conducted inquiries. The gentleman who had been reported as having made these remarks was apparently prepared to admit that he had made some general comment during dinner to a person seated next to him about Japanese dominance of banking, Japanese banks' dominance of shipping and the difficulty of competing against such economic power. That was the way he told it to the Commission. My constituent says that he said straight out that seven Japanese banks had told the company to get out from competing with the conference Line.

I do not know what more the Trade Practices Commission can do on that matter, but it is of huge concern to me. I am concerned that people who are trying to make available to us a new, large export market are not able to serve that market in the most economical fashion. In this case it involved loading hay out of Geraldton. I might add that there were some difficulties with the local wharfies and a few other things I have had to attack as being un-Geraldton. That was successful with the wharfies in Geraldton. They took very seriously the claim that they were attacking their own town. As a matter of fact, they went to ground and we could not get them to talk to the media. Putting that point aside, in the loss of Columbus-the non-Conference operator-not only did we lose a competitor and a cheaper method of operation, but also we found ourselves back with the Conference, which suddenly does not have enough capacity.

It so happens that there are very profitable container loads and less profitable container loads, and the less profitable loads include hay. So when a boat is full the hay is left behind. It is a very sensitive market that Australia is trying to develop at a time when it is experiencing great difficulty getting financial returns on grain, wool and other agricultural products. Here is a market that is profitable, yet we cannot get the stuff out of the country. This poor devil had to road-freight 120 containers of hay 300 miles south to Fremantle, the only port of exit, and yet the ANSCON people are saying, `Stick with us, boys. Ignore our anticompetitive arrangements because we will give you a service'. But the one thing it is not doing is giving a service. It is not shifting the freight that is available.

Added to that, I am pleased to say, we are now getting a resurgence in the wool market-not so much in price but certainly in clearance. Australia has actually gone back to selling wool. A lot of that wool will have to be exported through this Conference. What chance do the hay exports have? The wool, because it is dumped and compressed, which maximises its weight in the container, will probably get precedence over the hay. So we will send wool out of the country at a loss but we will keep the profitable hay here. We have an anticompetitive practice that is tolerated by the Trade Practices Act, notwithstanding the efforts of this piece of legislation and notwithstanding the amendments this Government made to the Trade Practices Act in 1989 in the area of international liner cargo shipping. Because all of these deals were done at some time prior to that, the Commission tells me that it really does not have any power to fix this problem.

It is a very interesting aspect of monopoly. Many years ago I was the part-owner of a hotel-the Minister will appreciate this story-in the little town of Northampton. My partner ran the hotel, and in the town of Northampton-which was quite a big town 30 miles from Geraldton-there was no TAB shop. Guess what happened? A client started taking a few bets on the side. Of course, the police came and arrested him and my poor old partner was in some trouble as the licensee of the hotel. I was not a member of parliament at the time, but I wrote to the TAB and said, `You've got a monopoly in this business. You should not be out pinching entrepreneurs if you're not prepared to give the service'. Let me say that it provided a service; we did not need any illegal activities in the town of Northampton.

That story provides a simple example: if one wants a monopoly the first thing that one has to do is provide the service. I draw to the attention of the Minister and the Parliament that Australia is losing valuable export opportunities because it tolerates a monopoly in international shipping. It still falls for the three-card trick that somehow or other this monopoly will give a better and more efficient service than will come from having open competition. History has proved time and time again that that is not true. It does not work. There is only one way to get the right price and the right service and that is by having at least two people fighting over the same business.

I think we have to look at the amendments the Government introduced recently. Here it is, bringing to the Parliament further amendments that deal specifically with market dominance, yet it is continuing to tolerate this situation to the detriment of our international exports, to the detriment of the thing we apparently need most, something to pay for our overseas borrowings-export markets.

My constituent tells me that our hay could be very competitive. He has a few little problems. It costs him $450 per container to get his hay fumigated in Australia; the Americans do it for $10. So he has a few little difficulties like that where bureaucracy sticks its nose in. He still has problems, notwithstanding all the arrangements he and the town of Geraldton and the Geraldton Port Authority made to have a shipping service out of that town. But he still tells me that we could be highly competitive in that market and that farmers could make a profit. The clear message is that if we exported all of the 800,000 tonnes of hay, probably half the farmers in Western Australia could give up growing wheat, reduce their wool production and make a good profit from growing hay. All we want is for someone to deliver it out of the country and allow this entrepreneur and others like him to get out there and get the business. But they are being stopped by a Government-authorised monopoly that is clearly not doing its job.

If it is too difficult to dismantle the whole conference system as it applies to Australia, which is gigantic, the simple threat the Government should be making is, `Listen mate, go and find another ship and maintain absolute clearances or you come out of the Trade Practices Act; your exemption is cancelled. You are on your own and you will have to compete with your Conference mates in price and service and you will not like that. But lift Australia's production or else'. I think the Trade Practices Act and other powers that exist in Australia are sufficient to achieve this, but at the moment the umpire is actually working against us. I make a determined plea that that be fixed.

We have had partial evidence of this. It has been admitted to me in correspondence from the Trade Practices Commission that an international shipping agent admitted that there could be outside interference. He rationalised that when it looked like it might be made the subject of an inquiry, but I will bet that what he said over dinner was, `We were told by the international bankers to get out and stop giving competition to the conference as it applies to Western Australia', and that he inadvertently said it. Of course, when the time came that it might be getting serious, when it was not over a few drinks, he did not really want that problem, having already taken the decision to leave.

But that is only half of it. Putting that aside, if you want a monopoly-like the Totalisator Agency Board in Western Australia-you have to provide the service. The Board was not providing the service. It therefore falls on the Government, as the umpire and the regulator, to do something about it-not to hold its hands up in the air and say how tough it is.

I have another letter here regarding the fumigation problem. It is obviously written by a bureaucrat, to the shame of the Minister, because it is not true. I am told that this in-container fumigation that the Americans use is preferred by the Japanese because a container can take quite a lot of time going from point A to point B, and it can be reinfested. One can put phostoxin tablets in the container and it will get there as pure as the driven snow. The bugs are actually killed on the trip. The time to do that is before the door is slammed. But no, we have to put things under tarp. This fellow actually has to transport it from point A to point B. It costs him $450 a container-an amount that would be much better put into the hands of economically depressed Australian farmers.

I hope the Minister will take this on board and see how we can actually sell a few Australian exports. I think it is a fairly serious matter. At the moment the Trade Practices Act is preventing us from maximising our opportunity to service an existing market, and to expand it. There is no hope of expansion. The bloke has these containers.

Might I add that one of his other problems, again in the trade practices area, is actually getting hold of containers. He now has to road freight the containers 300 miles north, fill them up with hay, send them off and get them fumigated, load them back up again and send them down to Fremantle where they can sit on the wharf for up to a couple of months before they get out of the place.

He has another little problem. Wherever possible the conference denies him containers-boxes, as they are called-and he has to go to all sorts of lengths to get them. It is another part of the monopoly situation. If there is an embarrassing surplus they are given to him, but if it is thought better to hang on to them so as to give them to someone else who returns the conference a better dollar, he will not even get the boxes. It is another aspect of restraint of trade. I think it is worthy of serious investigation.

The Commission had a try on the basis of this allegation of interference from the Japanese banking area, but other than that it has really said it is all too hard. Somehow or other people signed their agreements prior to the last amendment, which would have given them some power and influence. If we believe we can tolerate a monopoly which is preventing entrepreneurial Australians from exporting at a profit, then there is something wrong with this system. I would request that it be fixed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duffy The Hon M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-Mr Deputy Speaker, in the debate this morning the honourable member for Higgins (Mr Costello) in a general way dealt with his views on the role of the Trade Practices Commission, the Trade Practices Amendment Bill itself, and particularly raised as a matter of importance the criticisms made by a body such as the Law Council of Australia. He asked that those matters be responded to, and that is a fair request having regard to the fact that the body he is referring to is an extremely significant one. I will deal with that in a moment.

SPEECH.PARA: I thank the honourable member for Capricornia (Mr Wright) for his contribution to the debate. He is not now present, but I must say I was not absolutely sure of the matters the honourable member for Curtin (Mr Rocher) was adverting to, except to say that I thought he was looking for an extension of the powers of the Trade Practices Commission through the Trade Practices Act, a view which may not be shared by honourable members opposite, but I was not absolutely certain what he was driving at.

Regarding the matters raised by the honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey), I was not aware he was to speak in the debate until late in the morning. Therefore I had no idea as to the matters he might raise, not that that is an obligation that should be discharged by honourable members opposite, but when he kept staring at me and he talked about correspondence which had not been satisfactorily answered, for a while I must say that I was worried. But I think he was actually referring to a part of the Act which is not within my administration, and no doubt the relevant Minister will pick up the issues that he raised.

Mr Deputy Speaker, in respect of the matters that came to us from the Law Council of Australia, I think it is worth stating, firstly, that the Bill was introduced on 21 December last year. A copy of that Bill was formally sent to the chairman of the business law section of the Law Council of Australia on 14 January.

Mr Richard St John, the chairman of the Melbourne trade practices committee of the Law Council, was advised on 18 February that the Bill could be debated in early March. I assume it was in response to that that the submission from the Law Council was received by us on 1 March.

The first criticism that was made by the Law Council of Australia, which was adverted to in some detail by the honourable member for Higgins, was of the question of retrospectivity. The Law Council divided its criticisms into various areas. Firstly, it said that it considered `that the rationale and urgency for amendments were both dubious'. I must say that I do not share that view. I think that there was considerable worry that advantage would be taken of the interpretation directly or indirectly put forward in the case that became known as the New Zealand Steel case.
The Council then picked up another point on the same area, and to quote the Law Council:
The explanations now given at best indicate a modest need for some technical changes.

I think that that is answered by posing the question, `Who could give a guarantee that the gap in the section would not be used?'. I think it would be a very brave person who would be able to say that this was a modest technical change. I must say it would have been very difficult for a government to have taken that chance, because a guarantee could not be given that that gap would not be used.

An amendment that extends section 50 to cover an acquisition that is not already covered surely deserves a better description than that given to it by the Law Council, that of a technical change. If one is extending section 50 to cover an acquisition which may well not have been covered, surely it does deserve a better description than `technical'. I must say that I reject that criticism by the Law Council of Australia.
On the question of retrospectivity the Law Council says:
. . . the practice is especially objectionable where, as in the original announcement, the public was not given any indication of the nature of the changes which were proposed.

The retrospectivity does not extend beyond the date of introduction, and I really find the objection of the Law Council to be hardly relevant in this area of retrospectivity.
