As set out in the second reading speech, the reason for retrospectivity to the date of introduction is to ensure that advantage is not taken of the gap in time between the introduction of the Bill into this place, and the passage of the Bill.

I do not think that the Law Council of Australia has any monopoly on virtue in respect of its concerns about retrospectivity. I accept what honourable members opposite have said, that they took the view that this has to be answered. I think it has to be. As I set out in the second reading speech, I think a measure of retrospectivity is reasonable in this case. As I said, that retrospectivity does not extend beyond the introduction of the Bill. The question of unwittingly and unlawfully committing some act just does not arise. Therefore, I must say that the criticism by the Law Council of that provision can be answered. As I indicated to the honourable member for Higgins, I will endeavour to answer the criticisms as set out in the letter, and as were outlined and expanded upon by him during his contribution.

The second matter raised by the Law Council of Australia was on the question of the indirect acquisition, which is proposed new section 50 (1aa). I say from the start that the honourable member for Higgins did not raise this because it is not a matter of concern to him. He did say in his contribution that it was possible for such an acquisition to take place. He did not put it any higher than that, but he did not take up the view of the Law Council. Nevertheless, irrespective of whether it has been raised by the Opposition, the Law Council's criticism should at least be answered. The criticism is directed, in the view of the Law Council, to the very limited practical significance of the new provision, and the conclusion is drawn that there is no need for such a change, particularly when combined with other undesirable amendments.

As was volunteered by the honourable member for Higgins, no-one is in a position to say that the practical significance of the new provision is limited. Its purpose is to ensure that a type of acquisition not presently covered is covered. While the gap in the coverage remained, advantage could be taken of it. In our view, the Government has an obligation to close such gaps when they come to light. That is what we have been attempting to do.

The next point is that the amendments are not necessary in response to any demonstrable shortcomings in the present law; the amendments would not have altered the outcome of the New Zealand Steel case. That was another proposition put forward by the Law Council. It has not been suggested that the New Zealand Steel case would have been decided differently. The relevance of that case-again going back to the very hub of what we are on about-is that the judge expressed views as to the meaning of the words `directly or indirectly' in section 50 (1) which tipped the balance so far as that meaning was concerned. There has been an earlier, contrary judicial view on this point.

On the question of the incidental changes to section 50 (2), it is again alleged by the Law Council that the inclusion of the words `likely or likely to be in a position' appear unnecessary and misconceived. The words appear in section 5 (1) to enable account to be taken of the future impact of a merger which has yet to be effected. On this side of the House we do not agree that those words in section 5 (1) apply only to a merger which has yet to be effected. The subsection prohibits a corporation from acquiring shares or assets of a body corporate if `as a result of the acquisition, the corporation would be, or be likely to be, in a position to dominate a market for goods or services'. Therefore, if there has been a merger or acquisition, in order to assess whether the section has been infringed, the court would ask itself whether the relevant acquisition resulted in the corporation either being or likely to be in a position to dominate.

As the acquisition that may have resulted in a position of dominance can be taken into account in applying the deeming provisions of section 5 (2), it is reasonable to allow the court to also look at the likelihood of dominance when applying section 5 (2). Indeed, if it was not to do so, it would be going down the track of perpetuating an inconsistency of approach with section 5 (1).

The next issue raised by the Law Council was that subsection 5 (2) applies only to subsection 5 (1) (a), that is, not to the strengthening of dominance provisions of section 5 (1) (b). That is just not correct. It is just as relevant to apply the aggregation provisions of section 5 (2) in order to reach a decision whether a corporation is already dominant.

The other matter raised was the question of the introduction into section 5 (2) of a concept of likely position of dominance, as the relevant part of section 5 (1) and proposed section 5 (1aa) already require the same inquiry post acquisition. The inquiry in sections 5 (1) and (1aa) is in effect whether the position of dominance or likely dominance has resulted from the acquisition in question. When deciding whether dominance exists, section 5 (2) comes into play and enables aggregation of market shares, including that resulting from the acquisition in question. The inquiry as to whether a position or likely position of dominance exists is not the same inquiry as whether that position has resulted from the acquisition in question. That criticism levelled by the Law Council of Australia, as with the other criticisms I have been through, can be answered.

But the Law Council had more to say. In respect of section 5 (2aa) and (2ab), it also claimed the words `together with' are unnecessary and may give rise to confusion and unintended consequences elsewhere. Again we say that the amendments are regarded by some-and this is acknowledged-as not strictly necessary. However, the interpretation the amendments are intended to override has been put forward as an arguable case by a practitioner well experienced in the field and the amendment is designed to overcome the argument. It is at least an aid to interpretation and it is arguable, as some people have put forward, that it is not strictly necessary. Nevertheless, we had the view that because the view had been put by a practitioner in this area, it was certainly an arguable case and that it was designed to overcome that argument. It purely could be said to be an aid to interpretation. I do not really see why there was any need to become particularly fussed about it on behalf of the Law Council.

According to the Law Council, the reference sections, section 5 (2) and section 5 (2a), presume a combined and present position of dominance, and accordingly the references in sections 5 (2aa) and 50 (2bb) to a future `would need to act in concert' to achieve such dominance is irrelevant. The addition of the words `likely to be in a position to dominate' in subsection (2) and `likely to be able to exert' a substantial degree of influence in subsection (2a) make it desirable, in our view, to leave in the words `would need to act in concert'. That is just simply a disagreement with the way that this should be approached between the Government and the submission of the Law Council of Australia.

The question of associated companies is one of the last matters raised by the Law Council. The Council's view is that this appears to be misconceived. It says that the question is whether a party is in a position to exert a substantial degree of influence, not whether the party in fact will do so or be likely to do so. In answer to that I can only say that the amendment does not alter the need to be in a certain position. At present that position, as is understood by us all, is a position to exert a substantial degree of influence. After the amendment what also will be covered is a position to be likely to be able to exert a substantial degree of influence. This amendment again resulted from advice that the subsection needed to be widened so as to catch relationships where it is likely that one would act in accordance with the wishes of another, even though that other is not in a position to produce that result.

An example of where the new provision could apply but the existing one may not is well worth going through very briefly. That is where company A has a substantial shareholding in company B but does not have representation on the board of B. It may not be possible to prove that A is in a position to exert a substantial degree of influence over B's activities, but the lower test may enable the court to hold that A is in a position to be likely to be able to exert that influence. Again we have examined what the Law Council of Australia has said but we do not agree with it.

In respect of the consequential amendment to section 50a, which was the final issue raised, the view was that sub-section 50a (7) should be amended to exclude the operation of section 50a in respect of acquisitions which also may have come within proposed section 5 (1aa). I think that probably sets out what the concern of the Law Council was in relation to that. In our view this is not needed as section 50a and proposed section 50 (1aa) cover different types of acquisitions. Section 50a relates to an acquisition where the acquirer achieves dominance while proposed section 5 (1aa) deals with another acquisition by a body corporate where another party, a corporation, becomes dominant.

On that amendment, the honourable member for Higgins wanted the issues to be addressed in that way-that is, in some detail. Again I think that the interpretation put on the legislation by the Law Council of Australia is incorrect.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Costello Mr P.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Trusts (Hague Convention) Bill 1991 seeks to give effect to the Hague Convention on the law applicable to trusts and on their recognition. A trust is a legal relationship between one person and another by which property is vested in or held by the one person on behalf of and for the benefit of another.

SPEECH.PARA: The holder of the property is the trustee who, as the legal owner of property, assumes equitable obligations to deal with the property-that is, the trust property-for the benefit of the other person, the beneficiary, or for some specific purpose. The trustee has property rights against the world at large, and the beneficiary has personal rights against the trustee to have the trust administered by the trustee in accordance with the terms of the trust.

No special form of words is necessary to create a trust if the intention is shown or it can be inferred that the trust will be created, but the words must be so used that they are imperative and the subject matter of the trust and the objects or persons intended to have the benefit of the trust must be certain. Trusts may be express or implied by law.

The Hague Convention on the law applicable to trusts and on their recognition became open for signature in July 1985. A copy of the English text appears in the schedule to the Bill. An overview of the provisions of the convention is easily ascertainable by reading the convention itself. The Bill seeks to give the provisions of the convention force of law in Australia so that Australia may proceed with ratifying it.

The convention applies to international trusts, say, where the settler, trustee and beneficiary reside in different nations or where the trust property may comprise Australian and overseas property. The convention sets out rules for determining what domestic system of law may govern an international trust. At the moment, where a trust has aspects extending over more than one jurisdiction the common law rules of conflict of laws will determine which domestic system of law governs the operation of the trust.

The legal concept of a trust is peculiar to common law jurisdictions. Indeed it has been said that the law of trust is one of the great inventions of the common law world. It used to be said-I know not whether it is true-that the law of trust was invented at the time of the crusades when knights went off to the Middle East and needed to leave their property in the care and control of some other person in their absence.

The non-common law world does not, generally speaking, recognise the legal concept of a trust. Whilst one common law jurisdiction will recognise and give effect to a trust created under and governed by the law of another common law jurisdiction, there is some doubt as to whether such a trust would be recognised in a civil law jurisdiction. The purpose of the convention is to address this by creating a common regime of rules governing both the recognition of trusts and the question of which system of laws is applicable.

In essence the convention deals with two issues. First, chapter II sets out the rules for determining which domestic system of law shall govern an international trust. By article 6, a trust shall be governed by the law chosen by the settler or person who creates the trust. If no specific provision is made, under article 7 the relevant law is determined by having regard to a number of inclusive matters to ascertain what law is most closely connected to the trust. The rules set out in articles 6 and 7 are in the main consistent with the approach our common law takes in resolving conflict of laws issues.

Secondly, having identified under chapter II what system of law governs the trust, chapter III specifies how the trust is to be recognised and what legal consequences flow from recognition. For example, article 11 provides that recognition of a valid trust implies as a minimum that the trustee may be sued in his capacity as a trustee, that the trust property constitutes a separate fund and so on.

Apart from the schedule to the Bill which contains the English text of the convention, the Bill has seven clauses. I will allude to the most important. Clause 2 provides that the Bill shall commence on a day to be fixed by proclamation, which shall be a day not earlier than the day on which the convention enters into force for Australia. Clause 4 provides that the provisions of the Bill extend to the external territories. Clause 5 states that the Bill binds the Crown in right of the Commonwealth and in right of each of the States and Territories. Sub-clause 7(1) provides that the Bill and convention do not apply to conflicts arising solely between laws of different States or Territories in respect of trusts. Sub-clause 7(2) is in the form of a savings provision, providing that the Bill does not preclude States or Territories from enacting laws to give effect to the provisions of the convention.

I should comment on the implications for Federal-State relations. As noted, the intention of the Bill is that the provisions of the convention apply to international trusts and not domestic trusts, which may have interstate aspects. However, in the light of clause 7 (1), this may not necessarily be the case given that the subclause says that the provisions of the Bill and convention do not apply:
. . . to conflicts arising solely-
and I emphasise the word `solely'-
between laws of different States . . .

A trust may have both international aspects and interstate aspects. If, for example, the trust property is comprised of property situated in different States and in different nations, because of the use of the word `solely' it may be that a trust which primarily is of a domestic nature but also has some incidental international aspects will fall within the provisions of the Bill and the convention. There is no test set out in the Bill to the effect that trusts which are predominantly of a domestic nature will not come within its provisions; that is by virtue of the use of the word `solely'.

In his second reading speech, the Attorney-General (Mr Duffy) said that as the convention had no effect on statute law, it was decided that it could be implemented by Commonwealth legislation as opposed to uniform State and Territory legislation. That is, of course, because the present law relating to trust is governed by the common law rather than statutes. The Attorney-General also stated that in 1987 the convention was considered by a Standing Committee of Attorneys-General made up of Federal, State and Territory Attorneys, and it was agreed that the Commonwealth should implement the convention by way of legislation. It is expected that the States and the Territories may at a future date enact legislation to apply the provisions of the convention to interstate trusts. This is reflected in subclause (2) of clause 7.

Article 26 of the convention provides that contracting states may at the time of ratification make reservations to articles 16, 21 and 22. I have raised with the Government the prospect of making a reservation in relation to articles 16 and 22. Article 16 provides:
The Convention does not prevent the application of those provisions of the law of the forum-
that is, of the nation of the court hearing the dispute-
which must be applied even to international situations, irrespective of rules of conflict of laws.
Article 16 also provides that effect may be given to another nation's laws of the same character if that nation has a sufficiently close connection with the case.

Australian courts will not give effect to foreign mandatory rules unless they clearly form part of the proper law of the trust. Article 16 could create uncertainty for parties involved in establishing a trust. Article 16 does not specify the type of connection needed, but, rather, simply that there be some connection. It is also discretionary in nature, and this compounds potential uncertainty.

After taking this up with the Government, I received the Government's reply to my request that it consider reservations to articles 16 and 22. The Government says that there is a presumption that a treaty will be implemented in good faith and it says that, according to the 1987 Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade guidelines, Australia has only infrequently made reservations to treaties and, as a matter of overall treaty policy, prefers unanimity between parties on the basis of an agreed text.

The Government's argument is that, where commitments vary from party to party, a degree of uncertainty is introduced and it may be necessary in extreme cases to examine a complex network of bilateral treaty relations within the multilateral framework in order to discover the exact rights and obligations.

However, I would suggest to the Government that whilst I acknowledge that general principle, it is muted to some extent by the provisions of article 16 itself. Article 16 clearly contemplated that states may have reservations-and indeed provides in its own wording that any contracting state may, by way of reservation, declare that it will not apply the second paragraph of the article.

I can understand the general proposition that says that we would like there to be uniformity between states, but obviously those who negotiated the convention themselves realised that there might be some problem in relation to article 16 and therefore made a specific provision. Clearly it was contemplated at the time of negotiation of the convention itself that there might be a real interest in reserving to article 16, so the general proposition is probably of less significant effect in relation to that article.

The same might be said in relation to article 22, which again has specific provision in it for a contracting state to reserve the right not to apply the convention to trusts created before the date on which, in relation to that state, the convention enters into force. I will return to article 22 in a moment. The general proposition, whilst I can understand it, may have less significance in relation to article 16.

In the notes that the learned Attorney was kind enough to provide to me, he also raised the question of what had been the position of the Australian delegate at the time the convention was being negotiated. His notes to me said that at the conference which formulated the Hague Convention, Australia voted against the inclusion of article 16, which indicated that, so far as the Government was concerned at the time of negotiation, it believed that article 16 was not one which would be appropriate for Australian domestic law. The Government voted against that article on the ground that it was considered unnecessary because it was believed by the Australian delegation that the Australian legal system would allow foreign laws of immediate application to be taken into account without any specific provision for this purpose.

The Attorney in his notes disclosed that the matter has been discussed with Professor Michael Pryles, the leading Australian conflict of laws specialist, who is a member of the Australian delegation to the conference. It refers to some work that Professor Pryles has done in this area. The Government says that when it consulted Professor Pryles in February 1991, his view was that while provisions of this kind are a recent innovation-the principle is now accepted-he noted that this is a departure from traditional Australian conflict of laws rules but he said that it had no significant consequences.

It would be interesting to know what Professor Pryles's position was. I believe that, from reading that and from other comments that have been made in the legal fraternity generally, Professor Pryles did believe, on balance, that we should make a reservation. I think that is more or less confirmed by the notes the Government has provided to me. I query why the Government is not following the advice of Professor Pryles on that, particularly as this is a departure from established rules. I think it would be advisable for Australia to, where possible, consistently stand by past rules. Notwithstanding the Attorney's response to my request, I am not satisfied that, on balance, we should not make a reservation. I have urged this to the Attorney. He, in his wisdom, has rejected my urging. But I would propose that when this matter goes to the other place, this particular Bill be examined by the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs and that that Committee be given the opportunity to investigate this Bill and to form its own conclusions. That Committee has greater powers of investigation because it, of course, is not as tightly controlled as the Committee in this place. It also seems that it has more time for these things and it may be that the Senate, as a genuine House of review, can fulfil that particular function.

Article 22, perhaps, has the same generic basis because, as I said before, there is a provision in article 22 to allow for reservations of specific provision, which, of course, does not detract from the general provision allowing for reservations; it is a specific provision in article 22 allowing contracting states effectively to negative the application of that article in relation to their own domestic law.

Article 22 allows contracting states to decide whether the convention should operate prospectively or retrospectively. Ordinarily, international instruments only have a prospective operation, but Article 22 provides that the convention shall apply to trusts created before its commencement, unless an appropriate reservation is made.

It would be in Australia's interests, as a common law country, for civil law countries which adopt this particular convention to adopt article 22 without reservation, because that would, in relation to their own laws, give the convention a retrospective operation and so protect the position of already established Australian trusts.

However, against this is the desirability that Australian legal advisers be given notice of the changes the convention will bring about and that it operate as from the date that the Bill is enacted, especially in light of the fact that it represents, to a small degree, a departure from general common law principles. If Australia were to give the convention a prospective operation, it is unlikely civil law countries would respond in the same way by reserving on article 22. It would be unlikely, in our assessment, that this would provoke a counter-reaction, as it were, which might operate to our detriment.

I note that, again, the Attorney-General's Department has provided an explanation as to why it does not propose to reserve to article 22. It says that it is for the benefit of Australian trust property that the convention extend to all Australian international trusts, irrespective of the date on which the trust was created and it also raises the prospect that our response of reservation could cause a negative counter-response from the civil law countries.

As I said before, I believe that to be unlikely and since they have not had any domestic procedure for dealing with trust law anyway, when they bring it in they probably want to bring it in complete, as in one, and they do not have the specific problems which may arise for Australia, where we have had trusts operating with legal recognition for some time; operating under clearly defined rules here in Australia and a different set of considerations overseas, which retrospectively may change without a reservation to article 22.

I would recommend that article 22 be examined in the other place, particularly by the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs, although I must say that the reasons for a reservation in relation to article 22 are not as strong as they might be in relation to Article 16. The power to sign and ratify a convention and to make reservations is, of course, an executive one, one which the Opposition has no control over, one which the Government, through its executive powers, has complete power to do. If it proposes to sign and ratify a convention, of course, it has an obligation to harmonise its domestic law with that particular convention.

The convention itself will bring great added benefits to the law of trusts and Australian trusts operating internationally. It is something that will give greater certainty to Australian trusts where they have international beneficiaries or international trust property. So the convention itself is to be welcomed, as is the Government's decision to sign and ratify it. Therefore, one must say that the Bill is to be welcomed, because the Bill is a necessary consequence of signing and ratifying that particular convention. Therefore, the Opposition supports this Bill. We believe that this is a wise move. We believe that it will give greater protection to international trusts and greater certainty to the legal community and we welcome its introduction and its enactment.

We do raise the question of reservations on articles 16 and 22. For that reason, we suggest that that be examined in the other place. Even if a recommendation came out of the other place that reservations be made, unless the other place were to take the extreme step of enacting legislation directing the Executive what to do, it would still be a matter for the Executive as to whether to take up that recommendation and make those reservations. But I believe that the Government, in a show of good faith, ought to consider very carefully any recommendation that comes out of such an inquiry.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kerr Mr D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a pleasure to contribute to the debate following the very useful contribution by the learned Attorney-General (Mr Duffy) and the very learned contribution from the honourable member for Higgins (Mr Costello) on this matter. It is true, as they both indicated, that the trust is an invention of the common law-not always one which governments have welcomed. It may have originated as a device to protect the property of knights going off to the crusades, but in the Middle Ages it rapidly evolved into a mechanism for trying to avoid various feudal incidents. It was sought to be suppressed by legislation, but the common lawyers avoided that suppression by various devices. We are taught in trusts and equity courses the device of a `use upon the use' and various other technical devices which enable the trust to survive. More recently, the trust has become a vehicle for other attempts to avoid the revenue and became the subject of considerable public approbation during that period when it was a vehicle used to drive tax avoidance schemes.

SPEECH.PARA: Broadly, the trust has been tamed. It is a well-known and useful legal device for the passage of property to trustees to manage in the interests of others, and it has been a long established part of the common law system. Unfortunately, there is no such legal device available in the civil law systems, so there have been difficulties in terms of the reception and recognition of the trust in those countries. The Hague Convention, therefore, provides a very useful and welcome opportunity for international recognition of trusts. Our ratification of the convention, which will be facilitated by the passage of this legislation through the Parliament, will bring this convention into force. Therefore, we will be the third country to sign, which will, in fact, commence the convention in practical operation, and it will mean that the law which governs those matters with respect to the countries which sign the convention will be simplified.

The important points about this convention are articles 11 and 12 which set out recognition of trusts, and which state that, as a basic minimum, all signatory countries will pledge themselves to recognition of trusts; that trust property will constitute a separate fund; and that the trustees can sue and be sued in their capacity as trustees and make provisions of that nature. The articles also provide for the registration of trust interests.

Because this matter will command assent from both sides of the House, I welcome the very constructive approach put forward by the Opposition. Obviously, there are minor issues which will be further debated between the parties, but I welcome the undertaking that the legislation will be supported.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rocher Mr A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The shadow Minister and honourable member for Higgins (Mr Costello) more than adequately described the characteristics of international trusts and the Hague Convention itself. Hence there is no need to go over the same ground, except perhaps to reinforce his request that consideration be given to making a reservation about article 16 of the convention. As he pointed out, our delegate there opposed its inclusion in the first place. There is provision in the convention itself to state a reservation and I believe that the same delegate remains in favour of our doing that, article 16 having being included ostensibly over his original objections.

SPEECH.PARA: Again I agree with the suggestion of the honourable member for Higgins with respect to article 22 that there should be a specific reservation, which is provided for in the convention. In this connection also there is the element of retrospectivity, which is of concern to us. Again, my colleague adequately dealt with that point and the argument that might be advanced in favour of it, in that it is, or could prove to be, in Australia's interests for the Trusts (Hague Convention) Bill to proceed in the form it is when it becomes an Act.

I note also that reservations are the sole prerogative of government, and therefore it is not a matter which we can pursue, except to do as the honourable member for Higgins has already said, and that is to have it examined by an appropriate committee of the Senate.

This particular Bill was introduced only two clear sitting days ago, on 20 February. In the interim, there has been a week up, giving us time to consider these issues, that is, those relating to possible reservations, as well as the Bill as a whole and its implication for commerce and the legal profession.

There does not appear to be any particular reason for haste in finalising this matter, although I understand that our law does have to reflect the provisions of the Hague Convention before the Executive Government can ratify it. That is apparently true of all conventions.

The convention itself was finalised in July 1985, a further indication that there does not appear to be any compelling reason to force the measure through the Parliament-and I am not suggesting it has been forced through the House, but simply make the point that the Senate should be allowed time to consider it more thoroughly than has been possible with the complexity of this Bill.

The implications and details of the legislation have had some examination-and certainly the convention itself has been given the attention of academic lawyers in Australia-but it does not seem to be to have been widely considered by practitioners in the field, although I stand to be corrected on that.

We understand that Australia has been an essentially common law country in the context of trusts and international trusts to date. It is distinguished by some of the other parties to the convention, or intending parties to the convention, that there will be some very complex outcomes of that circumstance, with those other countries being essentially or entirely, in some cases, statute law countries.

I do not know of any precedent for an approach such as the one before the House at the moment, Mr Deputy Speaker. I certainly know of none. Again, I think that is in itself a reason for making haste slowly in the matter. Again, it supports the contention of my colleague and the Opposition in its entirety that a Senate committee reference is desirable and I would urge that course upon our colleagues in the Senate, particularly in connection with possible reservations being stated to article 16 and 22.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Leave granted for third reading to be moved forthwith.
Bill (on motion by Mr Beddall) read a third time.

TALK.START.PARA: -I inform the House that the Minister for Trade and Overseas Development, Dr Blewett, is absent from the House today, and will be for the rest of this fortnight's sitting, leading a delegation to the United States and the Middle East, and in his absence any questions which would normally be addressed to him should be addressed to the Attorney-General, Mr Duffy.

—My question is directed to the Prime Minister. Is it a fact that the Treasurer told executives of the John Fairfax Group Pty Ltd that his motives for getting involved in the Herald and Weekly Times takeover were a desire to see the Melbourne Herald group broken up and to hurt Fairfax? Is it a fact that the Treasurer recently told members of the Caucus communications committee that an inquiry into media concentration could unnecessarily antagonise Rupert Murdoch's News Ltd at the time of the next election? Is it also a fact that the Treasurer's interventions in the area of media policy have helped to send most media operators broke or near broke at the cost of hundreds of jobs? Has the Prime Minister required the Treasurer to explain his interference in another portfolio; if so, what explanation did the Treasurer give? If not, when will the Prime Minister impose some discipline on this rabble of a government?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —First of all, let me pick up that part of the Leader of the Opposition's question which went to the problems in the media which allegedly have been caused by the Treasurer's interventions. As I think anyone knows, the industry as a whole is going through a massive catharsis as a result of excesses by particular individuals going back over a period of time which had nothing whatever to do with anything said or done or allegedly said or done by the Treasurer-and that is a matter which is clearly understood. If one pays excessive prices for assets in the media, prices which are not capable of sustaining the interest burden in terms of the cash flow associated with that enterprise, one will see the sorts of results that have in fact occurred.

ANSWER.PARA: The fact is that in regard to the media the major contribution of this Government has been to introduce cross-media limitations so as to introduce a greater degree of competition across the media generally than existed in this country before.

Coming to the question about the Treasurer, I make two observations: firstly, I understand that the Treasurer has today denied the allegations that are in today's press, and I accept whatever he says about that. Secondly, if the Leader of the Opposition has any guts, he would ask the Treasurer himself.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Members of the Opposition will cease interjecting.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Aged, Family and Health Services. It has been estimated that alcohol, tobacco and illicit drug abuse in Australia costs our community in the order of $14 billion each year. What action will the Government take in response to the huge economic costs of drug abuse in Australia?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Staples The Hon P.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today, I released a study for the national campaign against drug abuse which sets the methodology for measuring the costs of all drug abuse in Australia. In that regard, it estimated that in 1988-the last year for which figures were consistently available right across the country in all the areas under consideration-alcohol, tobacco and illicit drugs cost our community more than $14,300m. This is really an estimate of the value of resources which are unavailable to the community for consumption or investment as a result of past or present drug abuse.

ANSWER.PARA: What is very important in that estimate of $14.3 billion is that there are many areas that are not included, such as the cost of absenteeism, passive smoking and other parameters of lost productivity. Looking at estimates of amounts that cannot be fully quantified at this stage, it is not unreasonable to conclude that the real cost of drug abuse in Australia could be at least double that $14 billion estimate.

I make three important points about the Government's policy on drug abuse. First and foremost, that industry loses at least $3.7 billion each year in direct costs because of drug abuse. So I said this is a minimum amount because it does not include the costs of absenteeism and poor workplace performance. When one considers that approximately one in 10 Australian adults suffer alcohol-related brain damage, one gets some indication of the impact it has on our productivity.

It is not up to government alone to address these issues. It really needs a total community consensus approach. It requires employers and unions to cooperate with government and industry to reform these problems in the workplace, and particularly in drug education and support programs.

The Federal Government has taken very significant steps, as people are aware, in reducing tobacco and harmful alcoholic consumption in Australia. We have seen the tobacco advertising print media ban most recently and the ban on smoking on domestic flights, as well as other responses. Very importantly, we have to recognise that at a cost of at least $14 billion per annum the Government will be continuing to take action on this front. The conference that will take place in April in Melbourne will be a very important one because for the first time in Australia it will bring together in the one place government and, more particularly, employers and employees to consider the implications of the costs of alcohol and drug abuse in the workplace.

Quite clearly and unequivocally, it shows that the most important contribution this study can make is to stimulate us to think in terms of the economic cost of drug abuse, outside the social and personal costs of those 26,000 Australians who die every year. It has really put the cost of drug abuse fairly and squarely on the economic and industry agenda.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Treasurer. Now that the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, Senator Button, has confirmed that we are in the mother of all engineered recessions, will the Treasurer have the same courage as the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support, Senator Collins, and adopt a 12-month timetable for his resignation? If the Treasurer will not resign now and the recession extends to further quarters, will he resign then? Indeed, when will the Treasurer resign?
—The strategy is to make human shields out of the Opposition at the next election.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Community Services and Health. I draw the Minister's attention to two issues regarding acquired immune deficiency syndrome (AIDS)-both recently highlighted in the media. The first issue involves a proposal from Western Australia for compulsory testing for HIV-AIDS of all blood samples taken in that State. Secondly, I raise the results of a recent survey which claims that there was an increase in support for the quarantining of people with HIV-AIDS in Australia. Is it intended to compulsorily quarantine people with HIV-AIDS, and does the Government intend to fund compulsory testing for AIDS?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howe The Hon B.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for Stirling for his question. The proposal put forward by the Western Australian Opposition health spokesperson, Kevin Minson, to test all blood samples for HIV is wasteful and irresponsible and reveals a depth of ignorance about HIV and AIDS and its prevention. It is impossible to estimate accurately how much this proposal would cost. With hundreds of thousands of blood samples collected, it would undoubtedly run into tens of millions of dollars. At a time when resources for health care are in short supply, this level of expenditure is entirely unjustified in terms of benefit to public health. For example, in Western Australia, there have been a total of 109 cases of AIDS and a total of 581 reported HIV infections, or about 0.03 per cent of the population. Already there have been more than 100,000 HIV tests carried out in public laboratories in Western Australia since 1987, and more than 200,000 tests carried out by the blood bank in that State. Many if not most people at risk of HIV infection have already been tested for HIV; some have been tested several times. Currently, the costs of HIV testing at blood transfusion services are shared between the State governments and the Commonwealth.

ANSWER.PARA: The additional costs incurred by compulsory testing of all blood samples would not in fact be borne by the Commonwealth. I think it is important when one discusses these kinds of proposals with respect to AIDS to recognise that the Australian situation is somewhat different from that in the United States. Under the leadership of my predecessor, we acted early; we developed a very effective preventative program; and we have been able to achieve an approach to AIDS which is the envy of many countries in the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development.

To refer briefly to the second part of the honourable member's question, I am aware of the reports of a survey conducted by George Patterson Advertising which showed that nearly half of Australian respondents were in favour of quarantining people with AIDS. This survey was also carried out in a number of other countries, where around one in four respondents had similar views. The Government's own research does not support the findings of the George Patterson group. In June 1990, a survey commissioned by the Government found that over a six-month period in 1990, approximately one in four Australians-not one in two-supported the idea of isolating people with AIDS. The total sample size in this survey was 4,000, which is greater than the 2,800 sample in the George Patterson survey.

I am concerned that so many people appear to be unaware of the facts about HIV infection and AIDS. HIV is not highly infectious and can only be transmitted in very, very specific ways. Quarantining people with AIDS is unnecessary and inappropriate as a routine health measure. As you know, Mr Speaker, Australia interacts with the rest of the world. Isolating people with HIV-AIDS in Australia would not prevent the virus being brought into the country. To commence and continue to quarantine or isolate people with HIV would require regular testing of the entire community, which has been costed at more than half a billion dollars annually. In Australia there is plenty of evidence that our education efforts, as I have suggested, have paid off.

Only this week in an article in the British Medical Journal, the Lancet, we were commended for our strategy in relation to AIDS as being highly effective. In this area of AIDS we have, with bipartisan support, over a substantial period made very, very significant inroads. We have done so at considerable cost, but one much less than the cost projected in these ideas that I have just been discussing. I hope that we can go on in a bipartisan way and ensure that Australian people are protected but in ways which are much more cost-effective than those suggested.

TALK.START.PARA: —I inform the House that we have present in the gallery this afternoon the honourable Michael Polley, Speaker of the House of Assembly of Tasmania.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Reith Mr P.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Treasurer. I invite him to go back half a decade to his `banana republic' speech, in which he said:

QUESTION.PARA: If we don't make it this time, we never will make it. If this Government cannot get the adjustment, get manufacturing going again and keep moderate wage outcomes and a sensible economic policy, then Australia is basically done for. We will just end up being a third-rate economy.
I note that at that time our foreign debt was about $75 billion, today it is $131 billion and, as shown by the balance of payments figure released today, it is still rising.

TALK.START.PARA: —Will the Deputy Leader of the Opposition get to his question?
—I ask the Treasurer: when will he get his policies right?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The last part of the question was delivered with all the studied sincerity of a police court solicitor.
—A freeloader, like you.
—The honourable member for Gippsland will cease interjecting.

—The fact is that the adjustments which have occurred in the Australian economy since 1985 have been nothing short of profound. For a start, we have taken a huge structural deficit, bequeathed to us by the Opposition's indolence, and turned it into a structural surplus-the first in the nation's history. We have presided over a large correction to our competitiveness, via the exchange rate, with all of the attendant inflationary effects and then come to terms with them. We have restructured the tax system in favour of equities against debt-which the Opposition was happy to see, with equities taxed twice.

ANSWER.PARA: Although supposedly the party of business, the Opposition was quite happy to see a taxation rate of 78c in every dollar of company income, which murdered all of the income producing businesses in this country and played into the hands of the stock market speculators who bought our companies and sold off the assets. We have changed all that. We have totally opened up the financial market.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Members of the Opposition will cease interjecting.
—Above all that, we have had an enormous--
—Nobody believes this.
—I warn the honourable member for Gippsland.

—We have had an enormous boom in investment in the meantime, so large that it put pressure on the current account deficit. In other words, we have underpinned the change to a more productive country with more investment, which the Opposition was incapable of doing. They are the changes we have made since 1985. While the debt has continued to grow, the fact is that the greatest growth in the debt to gross domestic product (GDP) ratio occurred between 1981 and 1984.

—If members of the Opposition think it is a fabrication they should look at the Business Council of Australia documents presented to the competitiveness summit this week, in particular the paper prepared by Dr Shann and Dr Fitzgerald. They should look at the table and graph in relation to the debt to GDP ratio, and they will see that the debt villain is no other than the honourable member for Bennelong sitting over there, who watched the big increase in debt. It has now only slightly increased from that. But the damage was done.
—Order! Members of the Opposition will cease interjecting.
—You would make Goebbels blush.
—Order! The House will come to order. The honourable member for Bennelong will cease interjecting.

—If the Opposition is so interested in guffawing, it should turn up the work of people who support its point of view and look at debt to GDP between 1981 and 1984 and from 1984 onwards. They will find that I am not exaggerating the position one iota.
—Order! The honourable member for Bennelong will cease interjecting.

—The productive damage was done then. The Deputy Leader gets up and asks this question as though he has some sort of virtue on his side. The fact of the matter is that the reason Australia has a productive weakness is the indolence of 25 years of coalition government. Members of the Opposition have sat there from about the time Harold Holt died, from 1968 to 1983--
—Order! Members of the Opposition will cease interjecting. The Treasurer might resume his seat. If members on my left continue to interject I will give them one warning and then I will name them.

—The 25 years from 1968 to 1983 were the years when it was obvious to any student of the Australian economy that the terms of trade were letting Australia down, that commodities alone would not cover our production costs and our imports, and we needed a stronger production base. Nothing was done of a structural nature in all of those years. There was a Labor government for three years in those 25 years. The Opposition was in office for 22 of the 25 years. Nothing structural was done until this Government came to office in 1983. As I said, by then the debt damage had been done. The structural changes which have taken place from 1985 to this period-more of which we will see in the Prime Minister's statement next week-have been initiated by this Government. Members of the Opposition should not suggest that any smarmy question they ask has the slightest virtue whatsoever.
—Order! Members of the Opposition will cease interjecting.

—My question is to the Minister for Land Transport. The Minister would be well aware of the work force reductions now under way in Australian National's operations in Port Augusta which were agreed to by the appropriate trade unions. Can the Minister give an undertaking that there will be no further job losses at Australian National (AN) in Port Augusta without further consultations with the trade union movement and that any job losses will be kept to an absolute minimum?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Brown The Hon R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The question that has been asked by the honourable member for Grey almost certainly was precipitated by the announcement that in about the middle of this year there would be a further reduction of 50 staff employed by AN in Port Augusta. I think the honourable member for Grey is also aware of the fact-and the content of his question indicates that he is-that in 1988 AN made an announcement that it would seek to reduce the number employed in Port Augusta to about 1,312. That represented a reduction from then until the middle of 1992 of about 400 employees, and that most recent announcement concerning 50 people is part of that 400. There are difficulties in attempting to determine the extent to which there may be redundancies associated with AN or, for that matter, any other type of business or transport operation.

ANSWER.PARA: I think people are generally aware of the fact that, as a result of very significant improvements in technology, management and work practices, AN has been able to bring about a significant improvement in its productivity. It is required under the Australian National Railways Commission Act to pursue improvements in efficiency and productivity and it has been doing that. It is interesting that one of the reasons for this Government's attraction towards the possibility of our becoming more involved in rail development-particularly through the proposed National Rail Freight Corporation-is the success achieved by AN, not only at management level, but also as a result of the very constructive and intelligent responses we have had from the unions associated with the rail activity of AN.

I can understand the concern of the honourable member for Grey about those developments because he represents the Iron Triangle. He represents that large proportion of railway employees and he represents them admirably. I emphasise that AN does have that legislative responsibility to pursue improvements of that kind. But we should keep in mind that, to a large extent, the future of AN and rail operations in Port Augusta and anywhere else in Australia, particularly on the mainline rail links, will be dependent upon the success of that National Rail Freight Corporation which we will have in place and operating from 1 July this year.

If that achieves the objectives that we and the State systems have set for it-and those objectives include improvements in efficiency and productivity-to the point where that transcontinental rail freight operation will become profitable, I think it is likely that, apart from any possibility of labour restructuring in the railway industry, there will be an increase in employment in that industry. That will come about because if we can improve the effectiveness and efficiency of rail, it will be able to take back an increasing proportion of that increasing national freight task.

If we look at the geographic and strategic location of Port Augusta-and the honourable member would be aware of it as he represents the area-we realise that it is obvious that it will have a central role in the development of Australia's rail industry. So Port Augusta's interests lie in our making sure that it can be done efficiently and that we can get improvements in productivity.

If we want any further assurance of the type of commitment that AN itself has brought to Port Augusta, we need to look no further than the fact that it has now committed $3m to upgrading and modernising the workshops there. There is a commitment on the part of AN to Port Augusta. People there need have no fear about the future of Port Augusta in the Australian national railway industry. Its future is assured and those people have a secure future because they will be part of it.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Reith Mr P.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Treasurer. I remind him of a promise he gave back in January 1990 when he said:

QUESTION.PARA: In three years there will be no government debt, domestic or external. It is an enormous claim that I make on behalf of the Government of Australia.
Now that the Treasurer's Budget has virtually disappeared, when will he get his policies right?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —What I said was that if the Commonwealth continued to run surpluses of that variety there would be no debt in three years. The honourable member left out the preamble. I do not know which quote he has, but I will give him the benefit of the doubt that he did not see it. Let me assure him that that is what I said.

ANSWER.PARA: Let us ponder for a moment on what that means. If the Commonwealth continues to run surpluses by virtue of the tightness of this Government's grip on outlays, within a relatively short space of time we will have the capacity to repay the debt of every Australian government since Federation. That is, there will be no bonds outstanding whatsoever. The issue for the Commonwealth will then be whether it uses its surplus to buy assets. That is why at that point consideration would have to be given to deciding whether in fact the policy of running surpluses of that variety should continue.

This means that, given the fact that outlays have been about 2 percentage points of gross domestic product (GDP) below receipts, we have been in a position, were we of the view that we did not need the surplus, to be able to hand back about $8 billion to $9 billion worth of tax cuts and still have a balanced Budget. For the moment, that position has been eroded by the recession and by the stabilisers operating on the Budget. But the fact of the matter is that we will still produce a surplus-as I have said, the third in a row-from the only government that has ever produced a surplus in Australia's history as a Federation.

The last part of the question asked, `When are our policies going to work?'. How could the honourable member ask such a question when his Party bequeathed to us a Commonwealth Budget deficit of 5 per cent of GDP? It is no good the honourable member rattling his head.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The Deputy Leader of the Opposition!

—Five per cent of GDP. Honourable members opposite should have hung their heads in shame. But no, they left it to us, and we have had to bring down the huge deficit and turn it into a surplus. Now the honourable member has the hide to ask me, `When are the policies going to work?' Really!

—I ask the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories: why is the Government proposing to introduce a user pays scheme to finance management of the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kelly The Hon R.J.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: THE ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for his question and also for his continuing interest in and support for the Great Barrier Reef.
—It was a great idea, wasn't it?
—Order! The honourable member for McPherson!

—Last week a ministerial council meeting of the Ministers responsible for the Great Barrier Reef decided in principle to endorse the introduction of charges to users of the Great Barrier Reef. I remind the House that that council consists of two Federal Ministers and two State Ministers.
—Order! The honourable member for O'Connor will cease interjecting.

—Over the years the number of people visiting the reef has increased very rapidly; the increase is probably in the order of 10 per cent per year. As a result, we have to find additional resources to support particularly the areas of infrastructure and research into the future of the reef. Currently, the total budget for day to day management of the Great Barrier Reef is about $14.6m. The Commonwealth contribution to that is just over $12m and the Queensland contribution is $2.6m. We intend to establish a Great Barrier Reef Marine Park management fund and ensure that the funds collected there will flow back directly into the management of the Great Barrier Reef. We will not be diminishing in any way the Federal contribution. Rather, this will top up the money that will be available.

ANSWER.PARA: It is anticipated that this scheme will provide for increases in field staff, interpretive centres, public moorings and, very importantly, research projects. So it will enhance the reef area. Council members do consider that it is appropriate that people who make a profit from the reef should put something back into it. We are not asking for much of a contribution from them. We are looking at about one per cent. That is under $1 for an $80 ticket out to the reef.

Consultations have been under way for about a year with the tourist industry, and though of course not everyone supports the proposition, some people do, because they see the value of it. Frankly, if you ask users whether they are prepared to put something back into the protection of the reef, I think they are prepared to do that.

SPEECH.PARA: Many people from the floor of this House have had occasion to remind not only you, Mr Speaker, but also a number of your predecessors that ultimately the skill and respect a Speaker commands in this place depends not only on the literal and fearless application of the Standing Orders but also on a fundamental sense of fairness and balance. They realise that they get one hit in Question Time and that is the question that they ask. This realisation has been manifest in two ways. The first is this absurd repetitiveness which might indeed have provoked our inquiries under standing order 146 which says that a question that has been fully answered cannot be renewed. The question that is repeatedly put to the Prime Minister or the Treasurer about when the Treasurer intends to resign is one that has been fully answered. This tactic is an attempt to get over the problem that those opposite have suddenly discovered and which they did not anticipate as a result of televising Parliament and that is that in Question Time, the Opposition does not get an argument across because the Standing Orders prohibit it. It has decided that repeatedly asking the same question is one mode of dealing with that problem.

The other mode of dealing with this problem is for Opposition members to introduce for the first time a substantial amount of argument in the questions that they put forward. Therefore those opposite have placed the Speaker in this position: is the Speaker going to uphold Standing Orders against this new tactic or is he not? If the Speaker does not, then he is placed in the invidious position that he cannot stand close to Standing Orders as he deals with the business of this Parliament. That is not a position any Speaker can be placed in, whether it be a Speaker drawn from the Government ranks or one drawn from the Opposition ranks. No Speaker can handle that.

There is an absolute obligation on the Opposition. If its members object to the Standing Orders, they should not wander into the House, as the former Leader of the Opposition did, and say that the Speaker has to `introduce a general atmosphere of balance, irrespective of the Standing Orders'-a general atmosphere of fairness and love for the dear old Opposition.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is the interpretation we object to.
—Order! The honourable member for Gippsland will cease interjecting.

—The Opposition introduces that type of argument, but it will not go through the process of sitting down and putting to the Standing Orders Committee ways in which it seeks to have Question Time altered. It is no accident that the Opposition takes that view; it is embarrassed by the situation that the Question Time rules that have been put down were put down at a time when the Opposition enjoyed a majority in this place. So what the Opposition seeks instead is an opportunity to come in here and render Question Time ineffectual by repeated breaches of Standing Orders and repeated disruptions.

SPEECH.PARA: Honourable members will remember those promises that were made by the Leader of the Opposition: `We have to lift the standards of Parliament. Absolutely essential to lifting the standards of Parliament, central to it, is the televising of Question Time'. `Unless the Government agrees to televise Question Time' says the decent, ingenuous Opposition, `we cannot possibly have an uplifting of standards in this place'. The behaviour of the Opposition since the televising of Parliament during Question Time began has been noted further afield than simply this chamber. The total ineffectualness of the Leader of the Opposition in the way he has handled his front bench, sitting through this process of total disorderliness on the part of his front bench and his back bench--
Mr Tuckey interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member for O'Connor!

—Like a moo-cow watching the passing traffic-totally gormless, totally unfamiliar with what is going on around him, totally reliant on the only parliamentarian in this place as far as the Opposition is concerned, the honourable member for Bennelong, who in this case is using his parliamentary skills to argue the parameters of the debate well beyond its central features. He will not get away with that; nor will the frustrated, embittered, deeply disturbed honourable member for Pearce (Mr Chaney). He has smarted in this place because he is no longer in a position to dominate it with the same patronising, arrogant attitude we would watch on the box day after day in Senate Question Time when he was Leader of the Opposition in the Senate. The President, not enjoying a majority of senators prepared to support orderliness, was obliged to put up with this, but it is something this chamber does not have to put up with.

SPEECH.PARA: This motion is clearly out of order-just as it was ruled out of order. The Opposition is smarting about this. Opposition members get up here and make their speeches about this subject, but are they sensitive when they get it straight back the same way.

TALK.START.PARA: —Meanwhile, back at the motion. What about the motion?
—Order! I warn the honourable member for Gippsland.

—No Speaker-not this Speaker, not any of his predecessors on this side of the House, not Speaker Snedden-could ever have interpreted phrases such as `playing the environment for every vote', `appalling record', `using the environment as a political football' as anything other than examples of argument, imputation, epithet or ironical expression. Those opposite are a disgraceful mob. This debate will go no further. I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the question be now put.

—The question can be put in the converse, which is that the motion before the House be adopted.
—We moved dissent from your ruling, sir.

—The converse of that is what I just stated. The question before the House is that the motion proposed by the honourable member for Bennelong be agreed to. All those of that opinion please say `aye', those against `no'. A division is required.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper.
-Mr Speaker, I wish to make a personal explanation.
—Does the honourable member claim to have been misrepresented?
—I do, Mr Speaker.
—The honourable member may proceed.
—Thank you, Mr Speaker. In newspaper articles, in the Telegraph Mirror of 6 March at page 5--
—On a point of order, Mr Speaker: questions without notice are still in progress, as far as I know.
—No, they are not.
—I am sorry, Mr Speaker. I will start again.

—Mr Speaker, on a point of order, yesterday when a member of the Opposition sought to make a personal explanation, the personal explanation was put off until some time later in the day. Why was this so?

—Because there were some ministerial statements. Personal explanations are normally made after ministerial statements. There are no ministerial statements today. I have called the Attorney-General and then I will call the honourable member for Bennelong.

—Newspaper articles in the Telegraph Mirror of 6 March at page 5 and the Herald-Sun of the same date at page 20 claim that a spokesman for me stated that the reason for lifting the marriageable age is `to ban child brides'. That claim is incorrect. At no time did a member of my staff state that this was the purpose of the Sex Discrimination Amendment Bill. As honourable members will understand when the Bill is introduced later today, the purpose of the Bill is to bring the Marriage Act into line with the requirements of the Sex Discrimination Act.
—Mr Speaker, I seek leave to make a personal explanation.
—Does the member for Bennelong claim to have been misrepresented?
—Yes.
—The honourable member may proceed.

—I was misrepresented, as usual by the Treasurer, on the question of debt. The Treasurer made the quite absurd allegation that the debt problems of this country commenced before he became Treasurer, which everybody and his dog knows is wrong.
