DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received a letter from the honourable member for Flinders (Mr Reith) proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The urgent need for the Government's 12 March statement to signal a comprehensive shift of policy in view of the recent and further serious deterioration of the Australian economy as highlighted by today's balance of payments figures.
I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of members required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reith Mr P.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday, 5 March, was a very important day for the Australian Labor Party. Yesterday was the eighth anniversary of the election to office of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), the handing over to him of the keys of the Lodge and the installation of the Treasurer (Mr Keating) in that portfolio. Did anybody hear the champagne corks popping yesterday?

SPEECH.PARA: Opposition members-No!

TALK.START.PARA: —Of course they did not, because what a parlous state we find the Australian economy in today. Eight years later it is timely to review the state of our economy and to do so, as I will, within the context of the Prime Minister's 12 March statement next week and the Treasurer's response, a response which is to the recession and which, I am sure, will be announced with much fanfare.

SPEECH.PARA: Before I go through my contribution today and canvass some of the issues, some of the alternative policy prescriptions that ought to be adopted, let me say that if the Government does adopt them, it will have our wholehearted support.

Before proceeding, let me also declare two articles of faith. First, I am a great optimist about the future of this country. This country has a fantastic future and no-one should ever put that fact to one side. Beyond the doom and gloom of Labor's recession, I believe that Australia can repay its debts, that young Australians can go to university and look forward to having a job, and that in the future Australia can run an economy where families' living standards rise, rather than fall. But it will take a massive national effort over a number of years to turn around this country. That is why we say: let us make a start on that process of readjustment now; let us not wait two years, until we are re-elected at the next election; why do we not make a start now?

The second declaration of faith that I present to the House is really in response to a question that people rightfully ask. They ask whether Australia will have a manufacturing industry in the year 2000. My answer is an unequivocal yes. Australians are good at sport, medical research, literature; I believe they can be good at manufacturing as well. But I believe that a lot needs to be done if we are to achieve that objective and arrest Labor's brick-by-brick destruction of Australian manufacturing.

There have been a lot of leaks already about what will be in the 12 March statement and the Delphic oracles have gathered to examine the entrails of next week's statement. I suppose it would not be unfair to say that many of them have already found them to be lacking. In fact, the high priests are preparing their lines already for the burial soon after. Ross Gittins said this morning that it is like watching somebody dying: you know they are going to die and you know that you are helpless to help them. I thought Terry McCrann put it rather well when he said, `When you are listening to it next week it will be like listening to Baghdad radio'. So might people be somewhat cynical about what they expect from the statement next week. I suppose, after we have had eight years of the world's greatest environment statement and the greatest statement on this and that, we understand people's cynicism about this Government.

But needless to say there is still out there in the community a great yearning for some real action to address this country's economic problems. The community really does want to see someone show some leadership and show us how we are going to get out of this mess. I suppose it was rather well stated recently by Toby Daniels, Managing Director of Tubemakers of Australia Ltd, who said:
What we need is a leadership agenda. We need an element of vision about where we need to go and we need it from the top.
Dr Michael Deeley, Managing Director of ICI Australia Ltd, in an excellent speech which I would recommend to people, said that the statement was:
. . . the Government's last major shot at getting the economy right.
He said that he was looking for:
. . . not more words, not more philosophy, not rhetoric. Indications of actions. It is time for action.

How right he is. This country can afford no longer to wait. I say sincerely to the Government on behalf of all those out there who have lost their jobs, struggling on the farms and who are in that statistic of a 60 per cent increase in bankruptcies in the last 12 years, as I myself feel, `I hope next week you get it right', because this country can no longer afford to have the policy inaction, the paralysis, that appears to have gripped this Government in the face of the recession that the Treasurer said that we had to have.
Let me appeal to the Government's political self-interest. The Government ought to move in a radical and fundamental way to shift policy because it is the only thing that will save them politically.

When I look at that statement, I think it ought to have four basic components. First, let us have a realistic assessment of our current economic circumstances. Secondly, there ought to be a summary from the Government as to both the domestic and international economic outlook. Thirdly, the Government ought to spell out its medium term objectives for this economy. Fourthly, the policies needed to achieve those objectives should be adopted and we ought to have a program of implementation for them.

Let me now just briefly examine some of those component parts. That starting point is very important, because we have not really had from this Government a realistic assessment of where we are at. It is like pulling teeth to get from this Government a fair statement. If one talks to most people outside Canberra, and even perhaps some people in the Cabinet like the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button), they understand that this Government is wrong when it says that the economy is about to turn around. In fact, since we have come back this year, much of the data that we have been confronted with has been evidence of a further deterioration in the Australian economy.

I suppose the most obvious is today's balance of payments figure-$1.6m-which is a massive accumulation to our debt. Coming on top of a figure released the other day, our gross foreign debt is now $131 billion. Our country has got more debt than the combined debt of places like the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics, Czechoslovakia, Bulgaria and Romania. This Treasurer himself said five years ago-I can hear the antique clocks ticking away-that if we do not grasp this problem, meet this problem of a current account deficit, then we will be a banana republic. Where is the Treasurer now to stand and defend that statement he made five years ago? Where is this set of objectives and policies to deal with this massive current account deficit problem?

Let us look at some of the other data we have had. The Treasurer says that investment is strong, but the day before we saw the worst quarter since 1979-a drop of 11 per cent. The Treasurer says that fiscal policy is crucial to our debt stabilisation task, yet we all know that the deficit is fast approaching us, that the surplus has literally disappeared in front of his very eyes, as has the Treasurer's credibility.

Let us take unemployment. The Treasurer says that unemployment in 1991-92 is different to unemployment in 1982-83. Unemployment in this country is 8.4 per cent and rocketing up by about 1,000 people a day. Just to look further into the future, the Australian and New Zealand Banking Group Ltd job advertisements in February showed an 11 per cent drop. Those figures have dropped 67 per cent since their peak in April 1989.

The Treasurer has got the cheek to stand here and say that corporate profits are strong, yet on the very same day we have the statistics out showing that manufacturing profits dropped a whopping 43 per cent. Lastly, as an example or consequence of that, bankruptcies are up 56.8 per cent in the year to December. The Treasurer says one thing; the reality is another.

Finally, when looking at the data, the Government ought to look at the international situation, because I do not think that this Government has yet factored into the equation the recession in the United States, Canada, United Kingdom, New Zealand and elsewhere. That is the second wave. On top of that for us, of course, is not a rural recession but basically a rural depression. The second wave effects of that are yet to hit this economy, and that is why we say that a realistic assessment is one of a rolling recession through this year.

Once we have got a realistic assessment of what our problems are, obviously the Government ought to proceed-and we urge them to proceed in the 12 March statement-with a set of medium term objectives. We ought to have clear national objectives, firstly, to stop adding to our debt and start repaying it over a period of time; secondly, to lower inflation which robs pensioners of their savings and intrudes into the economy one of the great uncertainties that undermines our investment effort; and, thirdly, to boost productivity to international standards so that eventually we can start to trade our way out of our problems.

What are the Government's objectives in the face of this crisis? Who knows what its objectives are. Look at the blank stares on the back bench and the front bench, when we have a front bench which is sufficiently interested in this debate to be here. The Minister for Transport and Communications (Mr Beazley) daydreams, thinking about leadership. The Prime Minister's expression tells it all. What is that? He is secure in the Lodge until the next election.

This Government has simply been changing its objectives like it changes Italian suits. One day it is the current account deficit and the next day it is inflation. What will it be next week? We need a clear set of objectives. The Government ought to take the 12 March statement as an opportunity to introduce those objectives.

The statement then ought to move on so that we have an identification of the problems, an identification of where this economy is likely to go and the impacts on it in the future. We have got a set of objectives. We then ought to move onto some policies that will meet those objectives so we can start to turn this economy around. First, we need the introduction of more stable medium term monetary policies to reduce and ultimately eliminate inflation. Lower inflation is critical to raising savings, reducing the real cost of capital to businesses, achieving a more realistic exchange rate and switching the incentive towards productive rather than speculative investment.

Secondly, national savings must be increased through repairing the current erosion of public sector finances and incentives to private sector saving. The Treasurer ought to come in here and, instead of the personal abuse which so typifies most of his contributions to this debate, provide us with an indication of how the public sector will be restored to surplus from its current position of deficit in excess of 1 1/2 per cent of the public sector borrowing requirement. He ought to spell out what that means for Commonwealth Budget expenditures and taxation levels.

Thirdly, the Government must detail a believable program to accelerate the deadly slow progress in micro-economic reform. That would include some privatisation, some plans for contracting out of government services and a detailed plan of action to meet the need for accelerated reform of our wharves, transport systems and other vital infrastructure.

Fourthly, we should have announced a phased program for reducing protection against imported goods, including plans for reducing protection for the motor vehicle, clothing, footwear and textile industries. Fifthly, we need an industrial relations system built around the settlement of wages and conditions in the workplace so that pay and performance are more closely linked. We ought to have a system, after we have scrapped the accord, where voters have a right to have a secret ballot before strikes. Employers and employees ought to have the right to enter into voluntary employment agreements so that they can secure tenure of the positions they now hold. Sixthly, we ought to see drawn up and then adhered to some environmental policies and assessment procedures which provide an appropriate balance between development and conservation and minimise uncertainty. The main requirements are defined-certain processes involving minimum time, not subject to reopening at a later date or to disputes between governments.

The opportunity in the 12 March statement ought to be grasped with both hands by this Government. It ought to be realistic. It ought to set some medium term objectives. It ought to give us the policies. The Government really needs in place the personnel who have an understanding of the magnitude of the problem and the urgency of the task in front of us so that those policies can proceed to be implemented.

There is a useful message for the Government in today's Sydney Morning Herald about the contents of the forthcoming statement. The statement ought to be substantial. It ought to address Australia's basic problems. Let me provide the Prime Minister with this extract from the Sydney Morning Herald:
Bob's heart-stirring rhetoric won't impress.

TALK.START.PARA: —I call the honourable member for Cowan.

—On a point of order, Mr Deputy Speaker, I seek your guidance on whether it is appropriate that in a matter of public importance one of the most junior, inept backbenchers should represent the Government. It is an insult to the importance of the debate.
—Order! The honourable member for Gippsland will resume his seat. There is no point of order. All honourable members have a right to speak on matters before the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jakobsen Mrs C.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I could not believe the comments of the Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr Reith) when he raised this matter of public importance. Everybody in this House knows that this is just another ploy by members of the Opposition to try to get ideas for themselves because they have none on their own side. They are totally bereft of them. They want the Government to declare before 12 March what it is going to put in its industry statement. I urge the Deputy Leader of the Opposition to be patient. All will come to him on Tuesday, 12 March, when the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) makes his industry statement, backed up by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) and the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Dawkins).

SPEECH.PARA: While I can understand the desperation of the Deputy Leader of the Opposition, given the lack of ability to formulate policy on his side of the House, this matter of public importance seeks to mislead the public into thinking that the industry statement is in some way a Government response to Opposition concerns. Nothing could be further from the truth. It is entirely an initiative of the Government and has nothing whatsoever to do with the Opposition. Suffice it to say that the Government's statement on Tuesday will be appropriate to the requirements of the slowing economy and will sensibly and sensitively address the difficulties encountered by industry at this time within the context of Australia's future needs.

One could not make any such prediction about the ability of the Opposition to respond in an appropriate manner. On the contrary, its undertaking to slash $3 billion from government expenditure is ill considered and totally inappropriate and would exacerbate the difficulties confronting both industry and individuals within the economy.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition couldn't achieve it anyway.
—As the honourable member for Canning (Mr Gear) quite rightly says, the Opposition would never actually achieve it anyway. But if it did, it would still be the wrong thing to do.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government has consistently reduced government expenditure over the past seven years and there is no fat left to trim. Opposition proposals to slash $3 billion would have to concentrate on the sensitive and necessarily expensive areas of social security, health and education. Who would it target with its cuts? The old? The sick? The disabled? The young? The unemployed? Families with children? Students striving to gain an education? One thing we can be sure of is that the cuts would hurt those most in need and those least able to fight back. Because the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) is one of those least able to fight back, I suspect that the cuts would never come to anything at all. That is something we have been led to expect from the Opposition, and I believe it can deliver nothing it promises to the electorate.

Although unemployment has increased recently, it has not reached the levels it did under the Liberal-National Party Government in the early 1980s. The participation rate is still very high and there is no significant level of hidden unemployment because registration with the Commonwealth Employment Service is a prerequisite to entry into most training courses. Even now access to education and training and receipt of associated income support helps to provide a buffer for people who are unemployed but who want to improve their chances of obtaining work in the future.

As a consequence of the Government's attention to education and training there is now more likelihood that courses undertaken will yield certification that has some recognition and standing with employers, with the community and with other educational organisations. Furthermore, people who are having employment difficulties but for whom retraining is not an option at least have the security of knowing that they and their families are protected by a fair and equitable welfare system. This may not be much comfort to someone who has lost a job but it is a vast improvement on anything the Opposition would introduce or oversee, given its tendency to privatise welfare and attempt to wash its hands of income support for Australians in need. It would return us to the Dickensian times of soup kitchens and welfare handouts-to the deserving poor alone.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I rise on a point of order. As you would have observed earlier today, there is considerable emphasis upon the Standing Orders. The Standing Orders, if they are literally interpreted, require that a speaker be relevant in debate. The matter before us relates to the Government's 12 March statement and the signals that might be contained therein. The honourable member continues to address policies of the Opposition, which have no relevance to that statement. She should indicate the way in which the Government intends to address these matters, and that has not been done in the contribution I have heard to date.

—I have heard the point of order raised by the honourable member for Dundas. The terms used refer to the urgent need for the Government's 12 March statement to signal a comprehensive shift of policy. The honourable member for Cowan is talking about policy options and is therefore in order as far as the matter of public importance is concerned.

—I can understand the sensitivity of Opposition members on this issue. They do not want Government members talking about things they did when they were in office because they were so dreadful. Furthermore, they do not want us to talk about their prospective policies, which are not developed and in which the electorate can have no confidence.

SPEECH.PARA: When the Deputy Leader of the Opposition spoke he had the cheek to talk about the reduction of the Budget surplus in the present economic circumstances. I cannot believe that he could have the hide even to comment when the coalition government never achieved a surplus during the entire time it was in office. Tax reform also rolls easily off his tongue and off the tongues of Opposition members in the context of the industry statement, difficulties facing industry and addressing the needs of small business. The Opposition in government never achieved any tax reform during its period in office. It has been up to this Government to address these needs, and address them it has. It will continue to do so in an appropriate manner for industry, for the economy and for the people of Australia.

Given the Opposition's propensity to dodge responsibility for income security issues, I certainly would not trust them to maintain a system of payments for people who are unemployed or otherwise in need of income support from government, or for sustenance, for that matter; neither does the Opposition have the confidence of industry in terms of its so-called policy positions-that is, any of them. I do not believe that industry welcomes the introduction of a consumption tax-a tax on spending. At a time when the economy requires sensitive handling the Opposition is still talking about policy positions that have both an inflationary impact in the cost sense and a contractionary impact in terms of people's tendency to spend their money on Australian produced goods.

The Opposition still has not learned the elementary lessons from its previous term in government. This is a classic recipe for another case of stagflation. Everyone remembers that the Liberal-National Party coalition, when last in government, managed to produce stagflation in the Australian economy. It is a complex condition which is difficult to induce and to cure. The coalition induced it, and this Government had to cure it. Double digit unemployment, double digit inflation and an economy racing into recession-that is what the Opposition gave to us when it was in government. A nightmare was produced when the Opposition's economically illiterate policies were last tried, and it would have us do it all over again. It has learned nothing from that experience, and it still mouths the same platitudes without thinking through the consequences of its prescriptions.

In his contribution, the Deputy Leader of the Opposition indicated that there should be a policy to bring inflation down. Inflation is coming down; has he not noticed? It is a normal response to a contraction in the economy, and it may also have side effects which are unpleasant. But certainly inflation is coming down. In short, as usual, the Opposition is wrong.

Fortunately, industry almost universally recognises that the Government is now, just as it has been in the past, much better equipped than the Opposition to deal with its problems. For instance, through its positive approach to consultation with industry and unions, this Government has delivered industrial relations stability and wage certainties to companies in this country. The Opposition's prescription would yield industrial confrontation and wages chaos-and that is all we can be sure it would yield.

The Opposition is an absolute disgrace. It lacks a coherent position on anything. Industry policy is no exception. The Leader of the Opposition shoots from the hip, or the lip, on important questions of policy, or lack of policy, as the case may be-it is very seldom really policy-irrespective of the expectations of his audience that he will have properly considered his own and his Party's position.

One can only pity his shadow Ministers who find themselves looking down the barrel of a policy-on-the-run gun which undercuts the positions that they themselves are still attempting to develop. They are then forced to discuss ideas publicly which they had not previously been privy to or even considered; the voucher system is one case to boot, as is the soup kitchen welfare idea.

No amount of protestation from the Opposition can hide the fact that it was singularly unsuccessful in achieving any micro-economic reforms during its extensive period in office prior to 1983. As the Treasurer mentioned in Question Time, 22 years it had and it did nothing. It is easy for the Opposition to sit on the other side of the House and tell the Government what it should do on micro-economic reform when the Opposition itself was totally incapable of achieving it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Bereft of any initiative.

—As the honourable member for the Northern Territory quite rightly says, absolutely bereft of any initiative at all. Opposition members are no more capable now of negotiating an agreement on micro-economic reform on the waterfront, in coastal shipping or in road transport than they were 10 or 20 years ago.
—They do not even understand it.

—They do not know any of the people involved, that is right. They do not know any of the people they should be talking to. They do not know where half the places are. They would not have a clue on what to do. In contrast and as usual, the Government is responding to the exigencies of the economic downturn within a structured policy framework taking into account all of the factors which impact upon industry in these circumstances. We have clearly set out the micro-economic reform agenda and established a process by which it can be achieved. Progress is now being made on a number of important fronts--
—What about privatisation?

—It is no good for the Opposition to talk about privatisation as if we have not attempted it. We have tried to introduce competition for Telecom Australia. At the present time there is nobody in a position to buy anything. You do not think about these things. You just shoot off at the mouth, Peter. I am disappointed with you; be quiet.
—The honourable member should refer to other members in the House by their electorate.

—The honourable member for Mallee; I am terribly sorry, Mr Deputy Speaker. His office is next to mine. Progress is now being made on a number of important fronts, not the least of which is that of the coastal shipping area. The Minister for Land Transport, Senator Bob Collins, is confident that negotiations currently under way will bring about significant changes which will benefit industry and the nation.

SPEECH.PARA: The Opposition laughs at suggestions of micro-economic reform being achieved and demands speed in effecting such change. It fails to understand that real reforms are not made by waving magic wands and saying that it will happen, which is the Opposition's way of dealing with these things. Reforms are made through concentrated endeavour and consultation with the people at the coal face-the employers, the employees and their representatives, the unions. Nothing substantial or lasting will occur unless these groups agree on a process and a timetable for achieving the improvements required.

For instance, land transport and rail reform are essential areas on which the Government has made a commitment. The Industry Commission's analysis of road transport suggests that the value to the Australian economy of reform of road transport alone is worth $1.2 billion a year. The reform of areas such as coastal shipping are actually worth considerably less than that. But if we include rail, we add another $4 billion to that area because there is considerable inefficiency in the rail system.

Whilst I felt sorry for my colleague the honourable member for Grey (Mr O'Neil) when he was speaking in Question Time about the consequences of some of that reform in the context of reductions in employment, I think that is an inevitable consequence of the things that have to be done. It is also an indication that the Government is not afraid to make hard decisions to achieve improvements in productivity. The Minister at the table (Mr Robert Brown) understands these matters very well.

I do not believe that the industry welcomes any of the suggestions made by the Opposition in terms of its policy prescriptions. I do not think the country can afford to have an Opposition which is so appallingly badly represented in terms of people who wish to discuss in a constructive manner change that needs to be made in the economy and in industry generally. I think that the Government has taken the proper approach to all of these matters and will certainly continue to look after industry in this country.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cobb Mr M.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Ever since Captain Cook sailed into this country, it is doubtful whether there has been a more incompetent Government in charge of Australia's economic policy. We desperately need a new direction in this country, and we need a new direction to be announced in the 12 March statement of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) to be delivered next Tuesday. It is probably the Government's last chance and the last chance for Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: There is an economic tragedy taking place in Australia today. It is a tragedy that is largely unnecessary, and the magnitude of its destruction is even greater than what we witnessed back in the Gough Whitlam days in the early 1970s. It is the result of the most incompetent and arrogant Treasurer that this country has ever seen. We are witnessing today in Australia the results of that incompetence, and it is causing major heartache for business, major heartache for workers who are being laid off and for every other citizen in this country. I would go further and say that the results which are turning up from its policies are also causing it and the Australian Labor Party major embarrassment.

Everything that the Treasurer (Mr Keating) has ever said or predicted almost inevitably has turned out to be wrong. We told the Treasurer and the Government that if they continued this insane one dimensional high interest rate policy, we would have a recession in this country. The Treasurer of course said that we were wrong. But when the recession arrived to prove that he was wrong, what did he do? He then came out and said that this is the recession `we had to have'.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a depression in the bush.

— It is a depression in the bush, as the honourable member for Gwydir says. But we are now in the situation today where we have `the mother of all recessions' caused by the Treasurer, who has done to Australia virtually what Saddam Hussein has tried to do to Kuwait. Hardly a week goes by in Australia today without another one of the Treasurer's predictions being proved wrong. They have been proved wrong week after week, month after month with interest rates; week after week, month after month with inflation; and even in this last week, we have had the Budget surplus plunging from a figure that he said would be over $8 billion down to something that will undoubtedly end up in a deficit. We should cast our minds back to what he told the Premiers only a few months ago in June of last year. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: It is entirely important-it is not a matter of some accountant's fixation with numbers-that the public sector remains in surplus. That is our objective.

Today the Treasurer is preaching a very different message; he is almost saying it is desirable. This Treasurer would argue that black is white or his grandmother is actually his brother if he thought it was going to get him off the hook. We cannot believe anything the Treasurer says any more. He has no credibility whatsoever in this country-and the country, I remind him, is in chaos.

We should look at investment figures. The December quarterly figures are out. They are the worst for over a decade. The retail sales figures have come out. They are the worst for 25 years. Bankruptcies in this country are up 57 per cent over the last year and they are still rising, and rising rapidly. Net overseas debt has just gone up to $131 billion and is still rising-five times the level it was when the Treasurer took over. He is so loose with the truth. We heard that in Question Time today when he tried to say it was no worse than when we were last in government.

TALK.START.PARA: —He should resign.

—He should resign. Three-quarters of a million people in this country are unemployed and the figure is soaring. The balance of payments figure came out today. It was $1.6 billion for the previous month. Rural industries in this country are in the worst position of all. This Government has squeezed and milked them in the good times so that now, when things are down, their plight is desperate. This Treasurer and this Government's economic policies are totally discredited. The Treasurer is suffering a huge dose of fiscal humiliation. His tongue-lashings of Caucus that he has been getting away with when selling his policies might still be working but his tongue-lashings of this Parliament, and even the press, are not working any more. Everybody is seeing through him. Of course, this should come as no surprise. Wherever we see Labor governments in this country, they are a total failure. We have only to look at Victoria.
—A hopeless disaster.

—It is a hopeless disaster, as the honourable member for McEwen says. Western Australia is bereft. South Australia is going down the tube. Tasmania is plunging southwards and even Queensland, having inherited a healthy position, is starting to turn the corner and go down. We have even seen a Labour government thrown out in New Zealand. I direct that at the previous speaker, the honourable member for Cowan (Mrs Jakobsen), who I believe was born there. Wherever there is a Labor government in this country it is a hopeless situation. They just cannot handle money. They cannot run countries. They can do all right for two or three years, muddle their way through an election or two, but their inheritance of the previous conservative government's achievements is finally used up and they bankrupt the country.

SPEECH.PARA: We badly need a change of direction in this country. It should come out of the statement of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) next Tuesday. One of the main areas that needs to be looked at is taxation. Since the Government has been in office we have had nothing but more tax. We have seen the introduction of the fringe benefits tax and the capital gains tax, the wholesale sales tax has increased two or three times, personal income tax has gone through the roof, and the fuel excise has increased fourfold, from 6c a litre to 24c a litre. We have seen the luxury car tax. For heaven's sake, if there was ever a more insane tax than that I have yet to hear of it. The Government is now collecting less money from the sale of luxury cars, and caryards are shutting down around the country. All this Government has managed to do is penalise the worker and reward the indolent.

In the Government's last desperate move in the taxation area, apparently next Tuesday there will be some announcement that it will exempt the wholesale sales tax component of business inputs. Have honourable members ever heard anything like it? It is a steal from part of our goods and services tax policy. We are delighted to see that, of course-but why does the Treasurer not have the guts to embrace our policy fully? He knows that a goods and services tax is what this country desperately needs. He knows it in his heart of hearts. All members of the Government know it but they do not have the guts to do the right thing by Australia. Waterfront reform is another classic area.

TALK.START.PARA: —What reform?

—That is right-there has been no reform whatsoever. The Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support (Senator Collins) promised that it would be reformed by 6 May. We are now enjoying the ten-month anniversary of that date and we are looking forward to his resignation. The Government has not delivered. It is the one desperate area crying out for reform. The Opposition would support the Government on it but it is not delivering. It is not delivering because of this stupid 60-40 rule that we have been reading about in recent days, whereby the Australian Labor Party cannot make a decision at a conference or anywhere else unless 60 per cent of its delegates come from the trade unions. We know how stultifying that has been for the Government, how it is locking it in the past at the very time we need to be moving forward with a bit of vision.

SPEECH.PARA: The other day when the Leader of the National Party of Australia (Mr Tim Fischer) was trying to sort out another dispute, the Heinz dispute at Dandenong, he went into the Food Preservers Union office. What should be hanging up but a photograph of Colonel Gaddafi on one wall and Joan Coxsedge on another. This is how the trade unions are locked into the past and are dominating the Labor Party today. How can we have progress in the country with these sorts of undemocratic and unconstitutional things going on?

I turn to resources legislation. We have just had a debate on that subject today in Question Time. All that the miners and the foresters of this country want is some sort of guarantee that they can go about their business in a proper and sensible way. But this Government is so beholden to so many conflicting minority groups that it is frightened to move one way or the other in case it sheds 1 1/2 per cent of a vote here or half a per cent there. It is locked into the past. Common sense and courage have evaporated as far as the Government is concerned.

The wheat industry is in a dreadful mess and the Government cannot even get something simple like a bipartisan mission right. It has even written to the Leader of the Opposition begging us not to send two frontbenchers; one of them had to be a backbencher. Have honourable members ever heard such nonsense?

This country is in desperate need of a new direction. We hope that next Tuesday the Government takes that new direction. We need more than ever to signal a new economic direction in Australia and, above all, we need a new Treasurer.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Elliott Mr R.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —Having just heard the honourable member for Parkes (Mr Cobb) speak on this matter of public importance, I would have thought that both he and the Deputy Leader of the Opposition, the honourable member for Flinders (Mr Reith), would have put forward some suggestions as to what should be the new direction the Government takes. What did we get from the honourable member for Parkes as far as a new direction is concerned? We had a rehash of the National Party's environment policy-if it sways in the breeze, chop it down; if it moves, shoot it. That is the sort of mentality we have seen expressed for decades in the National Party's environment policy. It is the sort of record that the Queensland National Party in government had and it is what the Opposition wants to go back to.

SPEECH.PARA: The Australian community has learnt a bit over the years. I do not think it will cop that sort of approach. The Opposition should not identify that as one of the prescriptions that need to be taken. We need to display sensitivity for the environment, quite rightly, and to get the balance right-something that many previous governments in this place and in the States have failed to do.

Then we come to the question of what we should do in the taxation policy area. The Liberal Party and the National Party have some great ideas about taxation policy. One of the best is probably that put forward by the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) in an article in the National Australia Bank bulletin a couple of weeks ago. He was asked, amongst other things, whether his policies involved a shift towards consumption tax and other changes to the income tax base, including the possibility of a flat rate of personal income tax. He was also asked what this approach means for company tax under a Hewson government. The answer was:
We haven't released the details. There's nothing new there. There's no details of any of the policies.
He went on to say:
But if you accept the strategy that you're moving towards a tax on expenditure rather than on incomes then there is the question of whether company tax might be phased out entirely.

Is that not a wonderful suggestion? The Opposition is saying, `We'll phase out company tax entirely; we'll introduce a goods and services tax'. Who will pay for it under that sort of approach? As the honourable member for Cowan (Mrs Jakobsen) said earlier, the people who will pay for this are the poor, the disadvantaged, the pensioners, the people who have the greatest need. That is the sort of approach we are being asked to suggest should be the new direction that is followed in the statement next Tuesday. That is something that should be rejected outright.

We also had the Deputy Leader of the Opposition say how important it is to tackle inflation. At the same time we are going to have an anti-inflation strategy-it is one of the themes that the Opposition says it is interested in-it is going to introduce the goods and services tax. The very thing that could be the most inflationary form of taxation to introduce at this time will be part of the Opposition's anti-inflation strategy.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who is that going to hurt?

—Who will that hit most severely? Again, it will hit the very people that the honourable member for Cowan referred to-the needy, the poor, the pensioners and the disadvantaged. But that is part of the Liberal Party agenda in the 1990s and the people should see it for what it is.

SPEECH.PARA: If we accept the scrapping of the company tax and also the introduction of the goods and services tax, what other sorts of policy directions would the Liberals suggest that we should follow? They have some beauties. They are going to have vouchers for health care, vouchers for education services. They will not worry about the people who have been disadvantaged and those whom the Liberals in government have ignored-the people who could not complete an education, who could not get proper health care. They will go back to the Dark Ages. The ones they will help are the ones who can pay for it.

We have the classic case of the honourable member for Lowe (Dr Bob Woods) who made the comment that the Liberals would introduce a policy that would mean that people are only going to be worse off if it is through their own choice. If they choose to be worse off, then that is okay. What sort of policy is that? We will have the same situation that we had before the last election. Because the Liberals would not flesh out the detail and because they could not develop proper policy guidelines, they went to the election without a health policy. The Australian Labor Party had a health policy based on the Medicare system which the majority of people clearly identified with and supported. What do the Liberals suggest as an alternative? They might have vouchers; they might have something else. One thing we know is that they just cannot come up with hard, cohesive policies. People are starting to talk about the fact that the Liberals do not have clear, cohesive policies.

The Leader of the Opposition is the great floater of ideas. He floats the ideas but as soon as a bit of pressure is placed on him to flesh out the details of those, he sinks; the floater sinks. That is what happens to him. The Leader of the Opposition sinks on all these issues: he floats the idea about scrapping the company taxation; he floats the idea about changes that might occur in some other areas of policy relating to the goods and services tax rates or what that might mean in terms of government outlays or impacts on government outlays; he floats the idea on what he might do about capital gains tax-something that the Liberal Party has always hated. It does not believe in such things; that is a tax on people whom it has to look after.

If we go back to the days when the honourable member for Bennelong was Treasurer, we remember that the taxation system was in greater disrepute than it had been in since Federation. What did he leave us with? Today we celebrate eight years of Labor Government, so it is worth noting that when we came to office we faced a situation of rampant tax avoidance and evasion. We had all sorts of ramps and rorts in the system.

TALK.START.PARA: —And you got rid of them all, did you?

—Yes, we did get rid of them all. We now have the reality of a fair and just tax system, based on a social policy that is fair, that is targeted to the people who have the greatest need and that recognises there are people who need the assistance of the Government from time to time. This Government has compassion and the decency to provide that help when it is needed. There is no point in trying to suggest, as those opposite do, that if we formulate a new direction we can say that the great mass of the Australian population does not matter any more. If we do that, we cease to be any sort of decent political party and we have no credibility.

SPEECH.PARA: The question that we come back to is this: Malcolm Fraser came along in 1975 and he was going to fix up inflation; he was going to fix up unemployment; he was going to have the benefit of having the honourable member for Bennelong to do all these things for him. Unfortunately, if we look at the situation in 1975, and then at what occurred in 1983, on almost all the indicators the situation was dramatically worse in 1983. So the track record of the Opposition in eight years in government was abysmal and appalling. There was no decency at all in what it achieved on the economic front.

Yet we still have the honourable member for Bennelong dictating the tactics for the Opposition. Today it is not the Leader of the Opposition or the Deputy Leader of the Opposition who take whatever spurious points might be taken at Question Time. They have to rely on the honourable member for Bennelong thinking on his feet on their behalf. They are not capable of doing that; they are not capable of developing policies; they are not capable of thinking quickly. As far as they are concerned, they have to rely on the failed discredited Treasurer of the past to provide policy direction for the future. That is a pretty sad state of affairs because, as I said before, the Opposition's record as at 1983 was abysmal.
People talk about employment today and I want to introduce a couple of facts into the discussion because this is an issue that the shadow Treasurer was not really keen on.

TALK.START.PARA: —You will lose the Opposition with facts.

—Yes, that is not one of its stronger suits, that is for sure. We are faced with the situation today where, sadly, there is a considerable amount of concern in the community, quite rightly, about the economic difficulties we have. That concern is shared and appreciated by the Government, as it should be. The statement to be delivered next Tuesday night will quite rightly go to the very heart of those issues, both in the short and longer term.

SPEECH.PARA: But let us get this clear: if we look at the question of employment and the level of participation in the Australian work force, some salient points can be made. The honourable member for Bennelong represents an electorate that is not very far away from my electorate in Sydney.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a nice electorate, too.
—He has a nice electorate, but it is not as nice as Parramatta. Nevertheless, we will accept that he has limitations on him as well.
—You have a better football team.

—Yes, we have a much better football team. But the truth is that in 1983 the level of unemployment, particularly amongst young people in my electorate, was more than 30 per cent. At the same time, participation rates in schools were abysmal. Only 33 per cent, or less in many cases, of young people completed schooling and a great part of that was because of the deliberate policies of that time of the Fraser-Howard Government. Compare that situation with that existing today where we have high rates of work force participation. We have historically record high rates of students completing secondary school and we also have people going on to complete skills training and higher education, something which in 1983 would have been unheard of in the sorts of numbers we have today.

SPEECH.PARA: So the Government has developed policies. It will continue to develop policies. It will ensure that the statement on 12 March does not need to have in it-as was suggested-some sort of U-turn or some sort of new horizon. The Government needs consistency, coherence, sensitivity and the strength of purpose and the courage to see the job through and to create a better Australia for all those who live here.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Robert Brown, for Mr Duffy, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown The Hon R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The purposes of the Bill are to remove from the Sex Discrimination Act 1984 the exemption for superannuation and replace it with more limited exemptions, to insert in the Sex Discrimination Act a number of exemptions for certain Commonwealth and Territory legislation which is presently exempted by regulations, and to amend the Marriage Act 1961 and the War Gratuity Act 1945 so as to remove inconsistencies with the Sex Discrimination Act.

The process which led to the first set of amendments in the Bill, dealing with superannuation, dates back to the report by the then Human Rights Commission titled Superannuation and Insurance and the Sex Discrimination Act 1984 Part 1-Superannuation. That report was prepared in response to a request by the then Attorney-General, Senator Gareth Evans, and was tabled in Parliament on 25 November 1986. The report was considered by the Government and it was decided that the exemption be removed and that certain more limited exemptions for particular practices in superannuation be inserted into the Act. Following the Government's decision, consultations on the proposed exemptions were held with the superannuation industry, employer groups, State and Territory governments and the Australian Council of Trade Unions.

The Government, as indicated in its National Agenda for Women, is committed to the objective of removing discrimination in superannuation on the grounds of sex, marital status and pregnancy. The major effect of this Bill is to remove most forms of direct discrimination on the grounds of sex and marital status in superannuation practices for new schemes. Where funds are unable to comply with the new obligations under the legislation, the reasonable expectations of the members will be maintained and the discriminatory fund will be allowed to continue. However, such funds will not be entitled to admit new members. Further, members of such discriminatory schemes will generally have to be given an option to obtain non-discriminatory superannuation benefits.

The proposed continuing exemptions, shortly stated, deal with the following areas: the inclusion in fund conditions of a provision which is based upon actuarial data upon which it is reasonable to rely; the current practices whereby lesser death and disability benefits are provided to members who are single-that is, members who do not have a spouse or a de facto spouse-or to members who do not have a child; the possibly discriminatory effect of current vesting, preservation and portability arrangements in funds' conditions; and the protection of the existing expectations of members of discriminatory schemes.

The introduction of the Bill was initially delayed pending the reappraisal by the Government of a proposed exemption which would have allowed funds to confine the provision of superannuation benefits to permanent and full time employees. In January 1989 the Government decided not to proceed with this exemption. Following that decision a further round of consultations on the issue was held with the superannuation industry, peak employer bodies, State governments and the National Women's Consultative Council.

The Bill was first introduced on 11 May 1989 but lapsed when elections were called. It was then amended by the deletion of proposed section 41c, which would have permitted the remaining superannuation exemptions-that is, sections 41a and 41b-to be repealed by regulation. This provision, which was opposed by the Opposition, was not considered essential to the Bill. The Bill was reintroduced on 12 September 1990 but was withdrawn in order to make several minor technical and drafting amendments. As the regulations providing exemptions for inconsistent Commonwealth, State and Territory laws were being reviewed at the time, the Government decided to incorporate the amendments to the superannuation exemption into a more comprehensive Bill which further limits the scope of existing exemptions under the Sex Discrimination Act.

I turn now to a brief description of the proposed limited exemptions to be inserted in the Act. The first I wish to outline are those relating to superannuation. Because, statistically, women live longer than men, the actuarial exemption covers the resulting difference in costs of providing a pension for women. Schemes will be able to continue to offer optional conversions between lump sums and pensions which differ by sex, so long as the difference is reasonably based on reliable actuarial data. As many superannuation benefits are provided via insurance this exemption is interlinked with the insurance exemption in the Sex Discrimination Act. The Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission has released a report on the exemption of insurance from the Sex Discrimination Act. This report is now being considered by the Government. The need for the actuarial exemption for superannuation may need to be reviewed in light of the Government's response to the Commission's recommendations concerning the insurance exemption.

The exemption for certain superannuation benefits is designed to allow schemes to continue current practices, whereby upon a member's death or disability no benefits to, or in respect of, dependants are payable for a member who does not have a legal or de facto spouse or children. In the absence of this kind of exemption it may have been possible for a member who was single to succeed in a complaint of marital status discrimination. There are a number of reasons for maintaining this exemption. As the former Human Rights Commission noted in its report, the exemption reflects the community's attitude that it is appropriate to make special provision for persons who have a spouse or who have children in the event of the death or physical or mental incapacity of members of superannuation funds. As was noted by the Commission, to provide benefits to all dependants of members on proof of financial dependency would create difficulties both in administration and in finding a suitable objective test of `dependency'.

In regard to the exemptions dealing with vesting, preservation and portability, the issue of discrimination arises because there is evidence that women statistically do not remain in continuous employment for the same length of time as men. Matters such as vesting, preservation and portability fall within the area of the operating standards for superannuation funds administered by the Insurance and Superannuation Commission. Regulations made under the Occupational Superannuation Standards Act 1987 impose a number of operating standards with which superannuation funds must comply in order to be eligible for taxation concessions. These standards require all member-financed benefits and all employer-financed benefits arising from contributions made in accordance with an industrial agreement or award to vest in full in the member. They also require certain benefits, including award superannuation and personal superannuation benefits, to be preserved, generally until retirement at or after age 55.

The Government announced in the 1989 Budget that the introduction of vesting and preservation standards covering all employer-financed benefits will be phased in with effect from 1 July 1995. The Insurance and Superannuation Commission is engaged in the process of consulting with the superannuation industry, employers and unions for the purposes of the detailed implementation of these improved vesting and preservation standards.

The Bill also provides in clause 6 that section 14 of the Sex Discrimination Act is to be amended to make it unlawful for a person who exercises a discretion in relation to the payment of a superannuation benefit, in respect of a member of a superannuation fund to whom the provisions of new section 41a apply, to discriminate on the grounds of sex or marital status. The purpose of this provision is to ensure that trustees, when deciding who should receive such benefits, consider the circumstances of all the potential beneficiaries rather than making their decision purely on the basis of a person's marital status. For example, it will be unlawful not to pay a death benefit to a current de facto spouse purely because of a fund policy always to pay such benefits to the current legal spouse.

I now turn to the provisions of the Bill which are designed to protect the existing expectations of members in superannuation schemes. New section 41b will enable schemes which cannot or do not wish to comply with the requirements of new section 41a to continue to provide benefits for existing members, provided current members of these funds have the option to obtain non-discriminatory superannuation benefits. The Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission may, pursuant to section 44 of the Sex Discrimination Act, grant an exemption from the requirement to provide an option to current members. This will enable trustees or employers to apply for an exemption where it is clear that it would not be beneficial for current members to join a new scheme or to obtain non-discriminatory benefits.

The amendments concerning superannuation contained in this Bill should not have an impact upon government expenditure. However, it is anticipated that all Commonwealth superannuation schemes will be amended in separate legislation to comply with the Sex Discrimination Act by the time the proposed provisions of this Bill come into effect. These further changes may affect Commonwealth expenditure.

Superannuation is a very technical area of the law and the issues of discrimination which may arise may vary from case to case and industry to industry. The former Attorney-General wrote to the Sex Discrimination Commissioner requesting that guidelines be published to clarify the application of the Bill to particular situations. In addition, where trustees or employers feel that they should be exempted from the requirements proposed in this Bill, they can apply to the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission for an exemption under section 44 of the Sex Discrimination Act.

The Government believes that the amendments outlined above represent a significant reform. While I am informed that most schemes will be able to comply with the amendments with only minor adaptations to their existing conditions, the amendments will require schemes which have not yet modified their benefits to do so over the next two years, or to close off their membership. Further, the amendments are likely to increase the opportunity for part time employees to gain access to superannuation. This will significantly improve the opportunities for women to build up a worthwhile superannuation entitlement over their working lives. A large majority of part time employees are women and it is clear that women tend to return from child rearing to part time employment. Where part time employees are performing the same duties as their full time counterparts and the full time counterparts receive superannuation, it is likely that a court would find a failure to provide access to superannuation to such part time employees unlawfully discriminatory.

These amendments should therefore be viewed in light of the Government's commitment to increasing superannuation coverage for the Australian work force. Arbitrated superannuation awards are providing increasing superannuation coverage. These amendments will not only encourage this development and help Australia make appropriate provision for its ageing population, but the benefits which will be offered will be fairer and more equitable and in line with the Government's commitments under the National Agenda for Women.

The remainder of the amendments to be effected by this Bill concern the exemptions for inconsistent Commonwealth, State and Territory laws. The original purpose of the exemptions was to allow a period of two years from the date of commencement of the Sex Discrimination Act for the relevant governments to amend their legislation so as to remove inconsistencies with the Act. The original exemptions were due to expire on 31 July 1986 and, although the number of exemptions has decreased each year, exemptions have been continued for some legislation since then.

The Senate Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances has expressed strong concerns about the possibility of any further renewals of the exemptions by regulation. Following consultations with the State and Territory Governments and the relevant Commonwealth departments, the Government has decided that it is inappropriate for the practice of exemption by regulation to continue. Consequently, it is proposed that the existing provisions of the Act concerning the power to extend exemptions by regulations, that is, section 40, sub- sections (2), (3) and (4), be repealed by this Bill. The current regulations expire on 31 July this year.
After consulting the relevant Commonwealth departments, the Government has decided to grant indefinite exemptions under sub-section 40 (2) of the Act to a number of Commonwealth Acts. These are:
Sections 4 (1) and 84 (1) of the National Health Act 1953;
the Social Services Act 1980 (Norfolk Island);
the Gift Duty Assessment Act 1941;
the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936;
the Income Tax (International Agreements) Act 1953;
the Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) Act 1935; and
the Taxation (Unpaid Company Tax Assessment) Act 1982.

The relevant sections of the National Health Act and the Social Services Act (Norfolk Island) are discriminatory on the grounds of sex in that they mirror the discriminatory provisions that apply different ages for pension eligibility for men and women under the Federal social security scheme. The provision of an indefinite exemption for these Acts is consistent with the existing indefinite exemption provided for the Social Security Act 1947.

The Income Tax Assessment Act uses a number of terms such as `relative', `associate' and `dependant' which are discriminatory on the grounds of marital status. These terms, as defined in the Income Tax Assessment Act, are used in the Income Tax (International Agreements) Act and the Taxation (Unpaid Company Tax Assessment) Act. As these provisions are aimed at preventing tax avoidance and the abuse of tax concessions, the desirability of indefinitely exempting this legislation is obvious.
The Gift Duty Assessment Act only applies to gifts made before 1 July 1979. As most assessments have already been made, amendment of this Act is considered inappropriate.

The Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) Act uses the terms `relation' and `dependant' which are defined so as to be discriminatory on the grounds of marital status. The Act exempts from duty certain goods sent to or imported for the personal use of members of the armed forces of the United States and of Papua New Guinea or their descendants. These provisions permit Australia to comply with bilateral agreements entered into with those countries.
The existing exemptions under section 40 (2) are to be reinserted into the Act by new sub-section 40 (2).

The regulations under the Gift Duty Assessment Act, the Income Tax Assessment Act and the Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) Act are also to be given an indefinite exemption as provided for in new sub-section 40 (3).

An exemption under new sub-section 40 (4) is to be given to student assistance schemes provided for in the Student Assistance Act 1973. The criteria for means tests and rates of payment for these student assistance schemes are discriminatory on the basis of marital status. The Government has decided to undertake a review of the discriminatory provisions of these schemes over the next three years and has limited the period of the exemption accordingly.

The Department of Defence and the Department of Veterans' Affairs are currently conducting reviews of the Defence Act and the Defence Services Homes Act respectively with a view to amending the provisions of these Acts which are inconsistent with the Sex Discrimination Act. Consequently, an indefinite exemption is not required for these Acts. If these Acts are not amended before the expiration of the current regulations, an administrative exemption under section 44 of the Sex Discrimination Act may be sought from the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission.

Most of the inconsistent State and Territory laws covered by the regulations have either been amended to remove inconsistencies with the Sex Discrimination Act or no longer have any application. Of the inconsistent legislation which remains, the necessary exemptions may be continued, on application of the relevant government to the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission, by the grant of an administrative exemption under section 44 of the Sex Discrimination Act. In regard to the State legislation prohibiting women being employed in lead processing, it is open to employers to apply to the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission for an administrative exemption. Consequently, no action is required by Parliament in respect of relevant State and Territory legislation.

The amendments to the Marriage Act to be effected by this Bill remove the longstanding discrimination on the grounds of sex relating to minimum marriageable age. The Bill also proposes to make gender neutral two provisions of the Marriage Act concerning marriages solemnised overseas.

Under the existing provisions of the Marriage Act, the marriageable age for females is 16 and the marriageable age for males is 18. The minimum age at which females and males below marriageable age can obtain court authorisation to marry a person of marriageable age is 14 and 16 respectively. The Bill provides for a common marriageable age of 18 with provision for reduction to 16 in exceptional circumstances.

The provision of a common marriageable age for females and males is a worldwide tendency. There are now at least 38 countries which prescribe a common marriageable age, with 24 of these prescribing a marriageable age of 18 years. The following table shows these countries.

In 1989 there were around 117,000 marriages in Australia. Of these, 1,052 were of females under the age of 18 years. Further, only 13 were of females under the age of 16 years and required court authorisation to marry.

The Australian Law Reform Commission recently released discussion paper 46 on Multiculturalism: Family Law. The Commission set out the arguments for and against a common age of 18 years and expressed a provisional view in favour of that common age. The discussion paper was only issued after substantial, community-wide consultations, which included the ethnic communities, and its views are based on those consultations. The focus of the discussion paper is whether there should be court authorisation for marriages where a person is below 18 years and, if so, in what circumstances.

A survey of marriage counsellors, marriage educators, court counsellors and national marriage counselling representatives was conducted by the Attorney-General's Department in 1988. Forty-seven per cent of 1,010 persons polled responded, of whom 65 per cent were of the view that 18 is an appropriate minimum marriageable age for males and 63 per cent that 18 is an appropriate minimum age for females. The Attorney-General's Department has also consulted with all other Commonwealth departments and is satisfied that there is no Commonwealth legislation other than the Marriage Act 1961 and the Family Law Act 1975 that refers to marriageable age, that there is no other Commonwealth legislation that would be affected by the proposed amendments to marriageable age, that there are no administrative arrangements that would be adversely affected and that there are no likely difficulties that might be caused in relation to any arrangements with State or Territory governments.

The Bill also contains transitional provisions relating to marriageable age which preserve the position of females between the ages of 14 and 18 who had commenced proceedings or given notice of intention to marry in accordance with the present law.

The Bill also contains a consequential provision relating to the recognition of foreign marriages by minors where neither party is domiciled in Australia. At present the Marriage Act provides that such a marriage, that would otherwise be recognised in Australia, shall not be recognised as valid while the female party is under the age of 14 years or the male party is under the age of 16 years. Those ages are, of course, the minimum ages at which parties may presently marry with court authorisation. As the Bill raises the minimum age at which a female may marry in Australia with court authorisation to 16 years, it is consistent to apply this age to the recognition of these foreign marriages. Accordingly, the Bill provides that such a marriage shall not be recognised while either party is under 16 years of age.

The Bill further deals with discriminatory provisions relating to the solemnisation overseas of certain marriages under our Marriage Act. These provisions are very rarely used. Section 77 imposes an additional requirement on a female non-Australian; section 78 imposes an additional requirement on a male non-Australian. The Bill renders both provisions gender neutral, but does not affect their substance.

The other Act which is currently exempted by the regulations and to which the Attorney-General has not yet referred in this second reading speech is the War Gratuity Act. The War Gratuity Act provides for the payment of a gratuity to members of the Armed Forces who served in World War II and their dependants. The Act is discriminatory on the grounds of sex and marital status in that it does not recognise de facto spouses and provides differing benefits to widows and widowers. As the financial impact, if the offending provisions were to be amended, is minimal, the Government has decided to amend the Act to remove the discrimination. The amendments will in no way affect existing payments and entitlements but they will extend the ambit of the Act.

The Act is also to be amended so as to be expressed in gender neutral language. Section 5 of the Act is racially discriminatory but has been impliedly repealed by section 10 of the Racial Discrimination Act 1975. It was therefore in keeping with the policy of amending the War Gratuity Act to be non-discriminatory to delete section 5 from the Act. These amendments are contained in Part 4 of the Bill and its attached schedule.
I commend the Bill to the House, and I present the explanatory memorandum.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Simmons, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Simmons The Hon D.W.

TALKER.NAME: Mr SIMMONS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts, Tourism and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

This Bill gives effect to the Government's pledge to work towards prohibiting mining in Antarctica. On 17 August 1990 the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Senator Evans) and the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (Mrs Kelly) announced the Government's decision to introduce legislation to ban all mining in Antarctica to the extent of Australia's legal capacity to apply such a ban. This Bill achieves that objective.

This Bill will prohibit minerals activity in the Australian Antarctic Territory, and will prohibit Australian nationals and corporations from undertaking minerals activities elsewhere in the Antarctic region. The Bill is a first key step towards achieving our objective of comprehensive and legally binding protection of the Antarctic environment.

The Antarctic environment is unique. It represents the world's greatest pristine wilderness. The processes of nature are still taking their course largely unaffected by mankind. The Antarctic is not isolated, however. It is fundamentally linked to the global environment through, for example, complex interactions in the global atmospheric and oceanic circulation. Pollutants generated elsewhere in the world are now detectable in Antarctica. The rapid growth in recent years in countries wishing to be present in Antarctica has also brought additional stresses on the environment. But these impacts are negligible compared with the potential damage that could be caused by minerals exploration and development.

Antarctica is portrayed as a harsh place. But the delicate balance of life forms show that, despite Antarctica's harsh image, the environment is exquisitely beautiful and fragile. The scientific work that has been done in Antarctica over many years, in which Australians have taken a leading role, shows that Antarctica still has much to teach us. The Government firmly believes that Antarctica's extraordinary environmental and scientific values must not be put at risk. Thus Australia, together with France, Belgium and Italy, is asking the Antarctic treaty parties to agree on a means for permanently protecting Antarctica by declaring it a nature reserve and a land of science.

I am pleased to report that Australia is making progress towards its objective of securing the agreement of its Antarctic treaty partners to a new legal instrument that will achieve effective protection of Antarctica. The recent Antarctic treaty special consultative meeting in Chile saw encouraging movement towards our objectives. A significant number of countries are now supporting the thrust of our proposals.

This Bill will assist in achieving a prohibition on all mining and related activities in Antarctica by banning mining by Australians and non-Australians alike in the Australian Antarctic Territory. This is some 42 per cent of the Antarctic continent. In addition, the legislation will prohibit Australian nationals and corporations from engaging in mining activity elsewhere in Antarctica.

The Bill recognises the need to allow for activities in support of scientific work. The legislation is targeted at commercial minerals activity and has been drafted so as not to apply to scientific research and building and maintenance activities in support of scientific stations. The Government recognises the importance of Antarctica for scientific research and, for example, will not stand in the way of legitimate geological and geophysical research. Nor does the legislation apply to foreign nationals or corporations of countries which have enacted similar legislation. The reason for this is simple: the Government is seeking to encourage other countries to put in place similar legislation binding on their nationals. It is pleasing to see that a number of other countries have already moved in this direction.

The penalties for contravention of the legislation are, in the case of an individual, a maximum of $100,000 and, for a body corporate, $500,000. Offences are indictable, although provision has been made for proceedings to be heard summarily if it is proper to do so and both the defendant and prosecutor agree. In that case, the maximum penalties are correspondingly reduced.

In conclusion, the Government's stand on protection of the Antarctic environment has been strongly supported by the Australian community, and I believe this legislation will be widely welcomed. I urge the Opposition to be equally firm in its support of it.
I present the explanatory memorandum which contains more detailed explanations of the provisions of the Bill. I commend the Bill to the House.
