PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Simmons, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Simmons The Hon D.W.

TALKER.NAME: Mr SIMMONS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts, Tourism and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

This Bill provides for a revised system to elect the Legislative Assembly for the Australian Capital Territory, to be known as the ACT Electoral System. The system is designed to overcome the inadequacies of the existing heavily modified d'Hondt system which arose out of parliamentary consideration of the Government's legislative proposals in 1988.

The Government's decision to introduce a new ACT electoral system arises out of its review of the recommendations of the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters in its 1989 report entitled Inquiry into the ACT Election and Electoral System. The joint standing committee's inquiry was in large part initiated by the controversy surrounding that first election and the system used to decide it.

The Committee's principal recommendation proposes that a referendum be held in the ACT to determine the preferred electoral system to be used at future ACT elections. The Government believes that the inability of the joint committee to reach agreement on a preferred system is of key significance and is witness to the disparate but firmly held views which exist. Further, any referendum result is unlikely to identify clear electorate support for any single system. Accordingly, the Government rejects the Committee's referendum proposal on the grounds that such a course is not likely to provide a definitive outcome, may not be accepted by the parties concerned and may merely serve to regenerate earlier debates on the merits of self-government. The cost of a referendum is a further but secondary factor in this decision.

The new ACT electoral system is in large measure the system which this Government sought to establish when it introduced its electoral legislation in late 1988. The heavily modified d'Hondt system used at the first election in March 1989, including the arbitrary cut-off threshold and the complex vote counting procedures, combined with the large number of candidates who chose to stand-many on anti-self-government platforms-resulted in an election count that extended for over two months. Quite unfairly, it has been the d'Hondt system itself which has drawn the resulting wide criticism rather than the modifications to the system.

The Government's continuing view is that the problems and criticisms surrounding that first ACT election could have been avoided had the Government's original 1986 proposal for an electoral system based on single member electorates been accepted. To have proposed that the Territory elect its representatives from single member electorates in the same manner as other mainland Australian States should not have been novel or controversial. In fact, it is this system-which has been used to elect members to many people's Houses in English speaking democracies-which was not supported.

The opposition parties' objections to a system of single member electorates persist. Accordingly, in 1988 and again now, the Government, in its commitment to effective self-government for the Territory, has been forced to compromise. Facing the rejection of a system based on single member electorates, as used in other people's Houses, the Government has decided on an ACT electoral system which embodies some key elements of the d'Hondt system.

This system has a high reputation. It is in common use to elect people's Houses in non-English speaking Western democracies including France, the Netherlands and Finland. The d'Hondt system is one of proportional representation, through which the electoral wishes of the people are directly reflected in the composition of their government. The system is highly regarded for its ability to deliver stable government. As I have said, it is not the d'Hondt system itself which has resulted in the current unwieldy election process, but the amendments which were made to it in the political context of the first self-government election.

This Bill largely removes those amendments. Accordingly there will be no threshold or droop quota, no provisional election process, and no provision for voters to express preferences for party candidates other than those within the party of their choice. Indeed it is significant that the recommendations of the ACT Legislative Assembly Select Committee on Self-Government make it clear that demodification of the d'Hondt system along the lines of that now proposed would be an improvement.

One of the major shortcomings of the existing system, particularly in the context of the first ACT election, is the inordinate length of time needed to decide the election count. Even given that the 1989 election involved 117 candidates, the period of nine weeks required to complete the count is unacceptable. Under the new system, a staged counting process will be used with the first stage comprising a count of the votes cast for each party and independent candidates. The staged process means that a guide to the state of the parties and independents should in most circumstances be available on election night and the full count completed within two weeks. To assist the early completion of the election count, the cut-off time for the receipt of postal votes is to be set at the close of polling on election day.

The Government has previously responded to the recommendations of the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters report Inquiry into the ACT Election and Electoral System. The Government will give effect to the commitments noted in that response through provisions contained in this Bill. Specifically, to discourage other than serious candidates, the candidate deposit is to be raised to $250. To discourage frivolous parties, all political parties other than parliamentary parties will be required to demonstrate a minimum membership of one hundred eligible ACT electors, and individuals will be prevented from being the registered officers of more than one party.

The Government believes that the passage of this Bill would discharge the Commonwealth's duty to the people of the ACT by providing them with an efficient and democratic electoral system. The Government believes that, following the next ACT election, the Assembly will be at a stage where it is able to conduct its own electoral affairs. Accordingly I am pleased to announce the intention of this Government to hand over to the Territory the power to control the Territory electoral system after the next election, scheduled for February 1992. I intend to bring forward legislation in the Budget sittings later this year to give effect to this commitment.

Like other ACT legislation any electoral legislation of the ACT Assembly would be subject to the disallowance power of the Governor-General. No doubt those parties and independents contesting the second ACT election scheduled for 1992 will seek to declare their platform regarding the future territory electoral system.

To use the words of my predecessor, the honourable member for Melbourne Ports (Mr Holding), in his second reading speech on the original Bill in 1988, the Australian Capital Territory (Self-Government) Act 1988, this Parliament has a constitutional responsibility to ensure the good and stable government of this the nation's capital. This Bill achieves this by providing for the people of the Territory a simplified, democratic and efficient ACT electoral system. In presenting the Bill, I note again the Government's intention to extend to the people of the Territory in 1992 the power to control their own electoral system. I present the explanatory memorandum to the Bill, and I commend the Bill to the House.

DEBATE.TITLE: ARTS, SPORT, ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1991

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 14 February, on motion by Mr Simmons:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hawker Mr D.P.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —As was announced when the Arts, Sport, Environment, Tourism and Territories Legislation Amendment Bill was introduced, this Bill repeals one Act, the Darwin Lands Acquisition Act 1945, and amends six Acts in that portfolio-namely, the Australian Capital Territory (SelfGovernment) Act, the Australian Sports Commission Act, the Australian Sports Drug Agency Act, the National Library Act, the Audit Act, and the National Parks and Wildlife Conservation Act. The Opposition has no problem with any of these amendments and will not oppose them. However, I would like to make a few brief comments on some sections just to illuminate some of our views.

SPEECH.PARA: First, I turn to the amendment concerning the Australian Capital Territory's superannuation provisions and Territory borrowings. Clearly there had to be some amendments made for ACT Legislative Assembly members to receive their superannuation as a consequence of self-government. The idea of this amendment is to allow that superannuation provision to overcome the problem where an Assembly member is deemed to have vacated office if he or she receives any remuneration, allowance, honorarium or reward for service rendered in the Assembly. That clearly is a machinery provision which puts into the Act what already has been occurring in the past.

Secondly, it removes the requirement for the approval of the Federal Treasurer for borrowings, and removes the Commonwealth's guarantee on such borrowings. Again this does not affect the Commonwealth's power under other legislation to guarantee Territory borrowings for special reasons; nor does it limit the borrowing powers of the ACT and of the Northern Territory. It obviously comes as a result of an Australian Loan Council decision to allow the States and Territories more autonomy in raising and servicing their own debt.

I understand that this amendment, as it affects the Northern Territory, will in fact increase the borrowing cost for the Territory because of the removal of this guarantee. While it means that the Territory no longer has to get the Treasurer's approval, it may reduce the attractiveness of Territory bonds. I am informed that the cost to the Territory could be quite significant. For example, for Telecom Australia's non-guaranteed bonds, issued in February, the rates were some 70 to 75 points-that is, 0.7 per cent-above Telecom guaranteed stock. The fear is that this cost may in fact be translated to Northern Territory bonds.

The Commonwealth has suggested that withdrawing this guarantee will allow the Territory to be treated more like a State. I understand that the Territory would be much happier with this if other areas currently under Commonwealth powers were transferred to the Territory. A couple of areas that have been specifically drawn to my attention are uranium royalties and also the question of land rights. However I also understand that the Territory would be prepared to continue to seek the Federal Treasurer's approval for its borrowings if the guarantee were to be restored. I also understand that the Territory is not in favour of this amendment.

The second set of amendments, which comes into the portfolio of my colleague the shadow Minister for the environment, the honourable member for Pearce (Mr Chaney), involves the National Parks and Wildlife Conservation Act 1975. I understand that the honourable member for Pearce would like to make special mention of the fine job done by those working for the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service. He has been extremely impressed by the work they have done. I believe that many other honourable members who have had the opportunity to see this work have been equally impressed.

The amendment would allow any money collected by the Director of the National Parks and Wildlife Service from leases, licence permits and other authorities to be used by the service in its conservation role.

Likewise there are a number of amendments to the Australian Sports Commission Act 1989, the Australian Sports Drug Agency Act 1990 and the National Library Act 1960. The amendments will bring reports on the financial transactions of the Australian Sports Foundation under the reporting of the Audit Act. These reports were previously done voluntarily. Again the Liberal and National parties do not oppose these amendments.

The amendments to the Australian Sports Drug Agency Act are only drafting amendments and the amendments to the National Library Act are of a minor technical nature to allow the library more flexibility and to bring it in line with other statutory authorities and institutions such as the Australian War Memorial and the Australian National Gallery. As has been pointed out, the Liberal and National parties do not oppose these amendments.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown The Hon R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —When the Arts, Sport, Environment, Tourism and Territories Legislation Amendment Bill was introduced in February, the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (Mrs Kelly) indicated the purposes of the Bill and the essential amendments that were being introduced.

SPEECH.PARA: The effect of the amendments proposed for the repeal of the borrowing provisions in the Australian Capital Territory (Self-Government) Act 1988 and the Northern Territory (Self-Government) Act 1978 is that the ACT and the Northern Territory governments and their statutory authorities no longer require the approval of the Commonwealth Treasurer to enter into borrowing transactions and to remove the Commonwealth guarantee of such borrowings. As the Minister indicated, this is part of the Government's program to implement last year's decision by the Loans Council that the States and Territories will gradually assume full responsibility for raising and servicing their own government debt.

The explanatory memorandum and second reading speech also explained that this repeal will not affect the Commonwealth's power under present or future legislation to guarantee Territory borrowings for special reasons or to limit the borrowing powers of the two self-governing Territories. To a very large extent, of course, these amendments are of a technical nature and this legislation, as I have indicated, is simply used as a vehicle to effect those particular changes.

The amendment to the Australian Sports Commission Act 1989, as the Minister indicated, will bring the Australian Sports Foundation under the reporting requirements of division 3 of part XI of the Audit Act 1901. This is consistent with the Government policy of applying provisions from either division 2 or division 3 of part XI of the Audit Act to all Commonwealth statutory authorities and their bodies corporate, such as the Australian Sports Foundation.

I know that a number of members-including your good self, Mr Deputy Speaker-are listed to make a contribution to the debate on this legislation. I have made the few very brief observations that I wanted to make.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Chair thanks the Minister very much for that contribution!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Johns Mr G.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —When a Minister jumps to assist a member who has not entered the chamber at the right time, we are always grateful.
—It's not good enough; apologise to the House.

—It was because the honourable member for Wannon (Mr Hawker) had not really used his full time. I intend to use mine, and I am grateful to the Minister for Land Transport (Mr Robert Brown) for assisting me there. The Arts, Sport, Environment, Tourism and Territories Legislation Amendment Bill proposes a wide ranging series of amendments to the Arts, Sport, Environment, Tourism and Territories Act, but I want to speak to a particular topic which is at the very core of the administration of the Department of Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories, and that is a role it has taken on recently to manage World Heritage listed properties. I have in mind one in particular, and that is the wet tropical rainforests of northern Queensland, because it is the management of that region, which is carried out jointly with the State Government, that will perhaps be the first test of how well we are to stand by our commitment to World Heritage listed areas.

SPEECH.PARA: Last week I travelled to the area of Tully, south-west of Cairns, with some members of the Caucus environment committee, in order to look at the Tully-Millstream hydro-electric scheme proposal. This proposal exhibits an exquisite conflict between the need for a renewable source of energy and its undoubted impact on the World Heritage listed rainforests. I say it is an exquisite conflict because most certainly we need renewable sources of energy in this country. Not only do they tend not to run down the energy capital as do coal and other sorts of energy sources, but also, by and large, the proposal provides a clean source of fuel.

Nevertheless, the impact on the World Heritage listed rainforests has to be accounted for, measured and then decided upon. The Queensland Government has established a task force to look at the hydro-electric scheme across all of its many elements-that is, its environmental impact; the demand for energy in Queensland; alternative demand energy; the importance of demand management in Queensland-that is, reducing individuals' use of energy in Queensland; and so on. It has brought together a whole array of issues that are important to the future of the energy industry in Queensland, and also, as I say, to this important World Heritage listed area.

I want to give my impressions of the area and the issues. The Queensland State Government and the Federal Government only recently established a joint management authority to look over the wet tropical rainforests. It seems to me that, in the public's mind, wherever an area is listed as a World Heritage area, it is probable that most people think that that is it-that we put that area aside for all time and there shall be no further interference with it. Of course, that is not so. One of the difficulties that the Federal Government will have in the next couple of years is that, wherever there is a proposal to undertake some form of industry or whatever in a World Heritage listed area, there will be the expectation that the Government will say, `No, you cannot do that, this is a World Heritage listed area'.

We have to be very careful about that sort of debate. We list certain areas on the World Heritage List because of the values that obtain in that area. The critical question in this particular instance is whether the hydro-electric scheme will damage the values for which we listed the area. We do not say no just because there will be some impact; we say yes or no according to whether the values for which the area was listed will somehow be impaired.

The important values for which the wet tropical rainforests were listed have been outlined. Without going into great detail, there are four major subheadings under which any area of the world may be listed. It so happens that the wet tropics were listed under each of those four areas, so obviously it is a very important area. The first value that a site must have before it is listed by the World Heritage Committee of the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organisation is that it must be an outstanding example representing a major stage or the major stages of the earth's evolutionary history. The second one is that it must be an outstanding example representing significant ongoing geological processes, biological evolution and man's interaction with his national environment. The third is that it must contain superlative natural phenomena, formations, features or areas of exceptional natural beauty. The fourth is that it must contain the most important and significant natural habitats where threatened species of animals or plants of outstanding universal value from the point of view of science and conservation still survive. The question is whether the Tully-Millstream hydro-electric scheme impairs each or any of those four values.

To put the scheme in perspective, the World Heritage listed rainforest runs from Cooktown, to the north of Cairns, right through to Townsville. It is an extremely large area of land. I believe that in terms of rainforest it covers some 660,000 hectares. In terms of the lesser forests attached to the rainforest-that is, the wet sclerophyll forests-there are 49,000 hectares which fall within the World Heritage listed area.

The major impact of this proposal for a hydro-electric scheme is the drowning of these forests. There is no greater impact than actually drowning an area. Let us get the magnitude right. The area that will be drowned-the Nitchaga dam will be one of the major reservoirs associated with the scheme-is 135 hectares of rainforest. The magnitude is important if we are to talk about impairing values-135 hectares out of 660,000 hectares will be lost as a result of one of the reservoirs associated with the scheme. There will also be 1,366 hectares of wet sclerophyll forest lost out of 49,000 of that type of forest in the area.

It is absolutely important that we analyse this matter sensibly. Just because some area will be lost in a huge total World Heritage listed rainforest area does not mean to say that this scheme should not go ahead. The loss of forest through drowning is minuscule, in anyone's terms. The impact, of course, of just a straight loss through drowning can be felt in a number of ways. It can mean the loss of habitat for certain animals. There are the greenhouse implications of having that wood rot after it has drowned. There may be implications for certain plant species if those particular hectares of drowned area happen to coincide with some very rare species.

So far, in the material that I have read and the observations that I have made, no habitat will be destroyed that will impact on a particular animal species to its total detriment. There will be no significant impact on any plant community. What I mean by that is that, whilst certain trees will be drowned and will be gone forever, the evolution of those trees, the habitat of the animals and the specific and rare species that abound through this entire region will not be lost. I argue therefore that the values for which the area has been listed will not be lost.

Those are not the only impacts. As part of the scheme, which will in essence connect a number of sources of water and pipe them through the hydro-electric turbines in order to create 600 megawatts of energy-it really is a very significant source of renewable energy-there will be a diversion off a number of small streams of significant amounts of water. The Koolmoon stream, which sits squarely within the World Heritage listed area just north of Tully, will have significant amounts of water diverted from it. So there will be a small wall which will not cover the whole of the stream and water will be diverted constantly-wet season and dry season-through an underground tunnel so as not to disturb the general environment of trees and the connectivity of forest areas into a reservoir.

The great fear is that at some periods there will be such a diversion of water that there will be an impact on the water life, the biota, further down that stream. These are the sorts of areas about which we need to be extremely sensitive. Is there to be a major impact on a particular stream within a World Heritage listed rainforest? We do not yet know, to my satisfaction, the significance of that impact. Certainly, the Queensland Electricity Commission (QEC), and other consultants as part of the task force, have sent the botanists and others into the region to study the impact of a change in water flow in this Koolmoon stream and other associated works.

I have had discussions with the Australian Conservation Foundation and others on this matter. They talk in terms of the percentage of water that will be diverted from Koolmoon stream. Up to 97 per cent of the water flow will, at some stage, be diverted from Koolmoon across into a pipe. If the 97 per cent is diverted during a flood period of very high levels of rainfall-Tully has the highest rainfall in Australia-then there may be a quite significant impact because of the loss of that water further down the stream. That needs to be studied carefully. The sorts of diversions that would occur at low rainfall will be minimal. There will not be a great deal of water flowing down that creek-and I have seen this myself-and, to the extent that not a great deal of water will be diverted, presumably, there will not be a great impact further down the stream. That is a presumption and assumption we make at the moment. The Queensland Electricity Commission confirm that there will not be adverse impacts on the stream downstream from these diversions. That work needs to be completed before we are satisfied-if ever-that there will not be significant impacts on that particular stream. So there are areas in which we need to do some work.

The three major arguments that the conservation movement has against the hydro-electric scheme are that Queensland does not require this new generating capacity, that Queensland in fact has produced sufficient generating capacity, mainly as a part of the gear-up to the 1980s resources boom, and that it does not need any new capacity. The Queensland Electricity Commission has given us its projections for demand management. Some independent consultants have given us their projections. The conservation movement has also done its figures and, lo and behold, the figures are significantly different. The conservation movement suggests that with clever-I stress clever-demand management over ensuing years there will not be the need or requirement for this 600 megawatts of power.

The Queensland Electricity Commission and, I think, four different reports have said that with reasonable technical feasible demand management there is a need for this hydro scheme to be brought on stream by 1996-97-which is not so far away. For me, the jury is out on that question; but there is a significant weight of opinion that says that in practical terms Queensland will need this hydro scheme. I think something like 100,000 new people are coming to Queensland each year. We are a growth State. We cannot avoid that and we cannot avoid the energy requirements that come with that growing State.

I know that back in 1983, over the Franklin Dam issue, the Tasmanian Hydro Electric Commission had run off a number of projections there about the energy that would be required in Tasmania into the future. The Tasmanian Wilderness Society at that time proved quite convincingly that the Tasmanian Hydro Electric Commission was far too optimistic in its projections for demand. But Tasmania, with great respect to all Tasmanians, has not been a State of any significant population growth or industry growth for many years. It simply does not compare with the sort of growth that we are finding and could reasonably expect in Queensland for the next however many decades. So I suspect that the question of demand, of the need for this hydro-electric scheme, will only be answered in the positive: that it is needed and that the demand is there and will need to be satisfied by this hydro scheme.

The area where I want to support the conservationists and push the State Government very hard is that of demand management. Are the Queensland Government and the Queensland Electricity Commission thoroughly convinced of the need for demand management? Will they seriously put a great deal of effort into considering alternative means of generating capacity and ways of making people save energy? That is the big question. Again, the jury is out on that one because the task force is still deliberating; there are reports to be handed down next month.

Right now the Queensland Electricity Commission states in its annual report that its major objective is to raise the price of electricity at about half the level of the consumer price index (CPI) and its second objective, which appears a little contradictory, is to reduce its own debt. The QEC has a financial capacity to divert some of its moneys to studying ways in which demand management can be imposed very firmly within Queensland and where some technically feasible alternative means of generating capacity can also be implemented quickly. That comes to the question of political will, and the conservationists are part of the movement which ought to pressure the Queensland Government, in the most proper sense, to ensure that it is fair dinkum on the question of seeking out technically feasible alternative methods of generating electricity and demand management for electricity.

The second major problem the conservationists have is the environmental impact of this scheme on a World Heritage listed area. I suspect that the main reason they are worried is not because of the detailed arguments I have alluded to but because it might seem to be a crack in the wall: if we can have a hydro scheme associated with a World Heritage listed area, what can we not have? Where does one rule off the sorts of activities that are allowed in a World Heritage listed area? That matter will have to be worked out scheme by scheme. When we pushed for the listing of the wet tropical rainforests we never intended that all activity would stop.

The joint management authority now has a very difficult task of working through the management of the impact of these sorts of schemes, but it should be remembered that this is a renewable source of energy. Queensland and Australia require that sort of energy. My view is that the impact is not so great. It can be handled and minimised. This scheme, excepting some quibbles and some more work, will probably succeed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dobie The Hon J.D.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am very pleased to have listened to the honourable member for Petrie (Mr Johns) because the area he has been discussing is one where I lived part of my younger life. Although I do not have any notes to speak to and I do not have the time-I see that the honourable member is showing me his notes-it is an area that has been under great debate for at least 40 years to my knowledge and I was very pleased to hear the strength of his views.

SPEECH.PARA: I rise to speak as chairman of the coalition's task force on environment and development and I wish to make some comments on the Arts, Sport, Environment, Tourism and Territories Legislation Amendment Bill 1991. This omnibus Bill deals in only a minor way with matters regarding the environment and conservation. However, they should not pass without comment. I shall try to limit my remarks to those parts of the Bill that deal with the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service (ANPWS).

The coalition, as the House has already heard from the honourable member for Wannon (Mr Hawker), does not object to the amendments to the National Parks and Wildlife Conservation Act 1975. As the only political party in Australia to have a written environmental policy, we on the Opposition benches have always made clear our support for the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service. I too would like to pay tribute to all the people in the Service, who give a remarkably dedicated service around Australia and who are very generous with their time in giving advice to honourable members on both sides of the House.
The coalition's environment policy recognises the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service as, and I quote from its last annual report:
The Commonwealth's principal management and advisory body in regard to the discharge of direct Federal responsibilities.
We totally support the mission of the Service, as described in the 1988-89 annual report of the ANPWS:
To protect and conserve the nature conservation values of the Australian natural environment and native wildlife-
and here is the important line-
in cooperation with the States and Territories as appropriate and to enhance awareness of and access to the Australian natural environment.
Let me remind the House what the coalition's policy has been for some time:

Stress its role in providing expert advice to the Commonwealth and State Governments; in monitoring and enforcing the Wildlife Protection (Regulation of Exports and Imports) Act and in controlling the operations of the kangaroo monitoring unit.
That policy also says:

We endorse the recommendations of the Senate Select Committee on Animal Welfare regarding the control of the kangaroo industry. Improvements will be made in data collection of population numbers and dynamics and there will be adequate research into these questions. The present system of quota setting and control management will be maintained through a system of licensed shooters adequately policed by the appropriate authorities.

It is also our policy to create an endangered species unit within the ANPWS. I mention these points because this is an occasion to remind the Parliament of the strength of the Opposition's environment policy and the total reliance we have on the continuation, development and proper recognition of this Service.

In so far as the amendments in the Bill reflect increased independence of the ANPWS, we support that intention. The insertion of new subsection 46 (1) (f) into the Act, which provides that money payable to the Director of the Service from leases, licences, permits, and other authorities be now paid into the Australian national parks and wildlife fund, is a sensible amendment that has our support.

Obviously the autonomy of ANPWS is improved by this non-contentious amendment which, at the very least, will simplify the accounting procedure and should lead to greater autonomy of the Service. For my part, I hope this move will not mean that the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service will have to rely solely on its own fund-raising endeavours as time goes by. I can find no mention in either the Bill or the explanatory notes of the intention of the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (Mrs Kelly) to maintain the real level of government funds to the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service. I raise that issue because this afternoon the Minister answered a dorothy dix question from her own side on the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park, saying that, despite no mention of it, the Government will maintain its funding of that fine organisation. Although I hope this is still the Government's intention with the Bill, there is no mention of it.

The second environmental aspect of the Bill is again not contentious and the coalition will not oppose it. The coalition supports the new section 49A to be inserted into the Act. This amendment will allow the Director of the Service to invest funds not immediately required by the Service (a) with an approved bank; (b) in Commonwealth securities; or (c) in any other way approved by the Treasurer. This is another small improvement to the independence of the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service.

I notice that the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (Mrs Kelly), in her second reading speech, likened-only likened-this amendment to section 54A of the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Act which, as we heard in her answer to a question today, gives power to the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority. In view of that fact, one would expect ANPWS to have similar responsibilities over any funds it receives, and thus the amendment is welcome certainly on this side of the House. Again I say this small amendment may assist the ANPWS in raising funds for research projects; I hope it does.

Honourable members and, I suspect, the Parliamentary Secretary to the Prime Minister (Mr Free), who is seated at the table, may not be aware that since 1985, when the government parties set up the Australian Wildlife Fund, a non-profit company, it has helped to raise funds for the service to assist koala research and support research into endangered species. It is hoped by this side of the House that the Australian Wildlife Fund will continue its work in providing funds for research projects. It has been said, and I agree, that this amendment may also provide further funding for similar research by ANPWS. However, no mention has been made of who will be appointed to the board of governors and whether they will be appointed without financial reward, as is the case with the Australian Wildlife Fund Ltd. This is a remarkable omission by the Minister.
The Minister has had a lead from the annual report of the National Parks and Wildlife Service for 1988-89. In that report, under the heading `Australian Wildlife Fund Limited', it states:

The Australian Wildlife Fund Limited (AWF) is a non-profit company set up in 1985 to raise funds for research projects of the ANPWS. The AWF has a board of governors who are prominent in business, community service or broadcasting and contribute their time to the Fund without financial reward.
It goes on to state:
As the first fund raising activity the AWF introduced an annual release of Koala Research Stamps. Although not for postage purposes, similar `cinderella' stamps--
I do not quite know what that means-
have proved very popular with stamp enthusiasts in North America for a number of years. A third series of Koala Research Stamps was released in February 1989.
This is over two years ago, honourable members would quickly understand, but we have no further information since February 1989. We assume it went well.
The report also mentions that in October 1988 $5,000 was provided to the ANPWS as the first contribution from the AWF to research funds of the ANPWS. This small section finishes by saying:

While the AWF has initially concentrated on generating funds to assist koala research these efforts are now being diversified to support more general wildlife subjects and specifically endangered species.

As I have mentioned, there is no identification of the members who make up the governors of the board. There is no mention in previous situations of who are the approved banks, what are the approved investment sources. A third lot can be invested into things that are approved of by the Treasurer.

This tends to be going against the argument that I have been putting, that we are giving the ANPWS added autonomy. Its own last annual service report available to us gives no lead as to what funds it may deal in. It gives no indication as to just who are the people who are making what we hope will be substantial decisions. As I have said before, there is no mention at all about what the Government plans to do with continuing to provide funds for the service.

So, despite this, I personally support these two amendments in the bipartisan manner which the coalition follows and adopts in regard to matters concerning environment and conservation. My great problem is that nowhere near enough time is given in this Parliament and certainly not in this House or-as the Leader of the House (Mr Beazley) referred to it this morning-chamber. We do not have the opportunity to speak anywhere near long enough on environmental matters. It is a tragedy that the Tully Falls, being the subject of the speech given by the honourable member for Petrie (Mr Johns)-an area of North Queensland which is much more vital than the average person living in the south of Australia believes-has not been discussed in this House at all until that honourable member raised it this afternoon in what has been allowed to be a wide ranging debate on this Bill.

The coalition is committed to the objective of sustainable development and we have developed clear detailed policies with that objective in mind. We have never shirked our responsibility in this area, and we have always supported the present Government when it has made a correct decision. Sadly again, those correct decisions have been far too few. I would say to the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories that, when the Government makes correct decisions, those decisions will be supported, as in this instance. However, the coalition will continue to use Parliament as the proper and effective forum for debates on environmental matters.

En passant, in view of the contempt with which this Government treats this Parliament and its reluctance to initiate parliamentary debate on the environment, it is remarkable that the legislation today gives no indication as to who will control the Australian Parks and Wildlife Fund. It does not even say whether this is to replace the Australian Wildlife Fund Ltd. One suspects that it will, but there is not a word from the Minister who prepared the papers for the Parliament today. It is really too careless of the Minister to have kept this information to herself, if in fact she has it.

I was going to conclude my remarks by reiterating the coalition's support for the two amendments to which I have addressed my remarks today. I assure the Minister that the coalition is proud of its own record of achievement in the area of the environment, and we shall continue to press for sustained debate on conservation matters within this Parliament without heat, without rancour and without prejudice. However, in view of the wide ranging nature of the debate, I thought I would just mention one small point which is not strictly within the confines of the Bill. It relates to the interjection made by the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard), not earlier today but later today when the Antarctic Mining Prohibition Bill second reading speech was being read to the House. The Minister, who had had the speech written for her, obviously said that she hopes the Opposition will follow the lead that she has given.

As a member of the former parliamentary environment committee in the last Parliament and as one of those Liberals who were responsible for the Opposition leading the Federal Parliament on the need and on the policy of no mining in the Antarctic, and having been congratulated by the then Chairman and my friend now, Mr Peter Milton, I do believe the Minister should be aware of these facts, as should those who write her speeches. I shall have more to say on this when the Antarctic Mining Prohibition Bill comes before the House for further debate. In the meantime, Mr Deputy Speaker, I thank you for allowing me to speak on a wide range of subjects in this Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Wright Mr K.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —While the Arts, Sport, Environment, Tourism and Territories Legislation Amendment Bill refers to a number of the Acts which come within the responsibilities of the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (Mrs Kelly), I intend to restrict my remarks to two aspects of the Minister's portfolio-the first relating to the sporting area and the second to heritage.

SPEECH.PARA: It is probably very easy to play politics on the issue of sport because of the excellent record that this Government has, but I want to give credit to the previous Government, the Fraser Government, for the initiatives that it took in establishing the Australian Sports Commission, as it was, and setting up the Australian Institute of Sport. In saying that, I think the credit ought to go to this Parliament. Irrespective of who was in power at the time, the records show that there was strong and widespread support for greater emphasis being given to sport in this nation.

Since the Fraser years the Hawke Labor Government has continued with the promotion of sports development and sports participation to ensure that it was community wide and to ensure that it picked up those who, we might say, are the disabled and minority groups. It has given a special emphasis to the elite aspect of sport, particularly elite coaching. During this period of government we have seen inquiries into drugs in sport. There has been a new emphasis on sports medicine and sports science. There has been a recognition by this Government and by the previous Government, and also certainly by the Whitlam Government, that there is a demand within the Australian community for governments to play their part in the provision of those facilities and resources to promote sport.

TALK.START.PARA: —It has more to do with votes than anything else.

—I do not think it is a matter of votes, although I take the point that if one looks at any newspaper or follows any media program one will note the great emphasis given to the sports area. Today within any newspaper structure we have specialist sports writers. They are sometimes given greater prominence than those who write the world news. I do not think it has anything to do with votes.
—Oh!

—I will explain why. I really think it has come from community demand. There has been a demand coming from every level of the community. This has been seen with the aged. People have lived longer and have stayed more active. As we seem to have combated infirmity, at least to a significant degree, there are those who wish to maintain their participation in all sorts of recreational pursuits. There has been a recognition also that there are economic advantages-I will go to those issues in a moment-from simply a health aspect, from the preventative and curative aspects, of sport and recreation. Doctors have become deeply involved in sport, not just because of the dollars that they might gain in sports medicine but because they see the preventative aspect as well.

SPEECH.PARA: We have seen a growth in the importance of sport politically and also within the community. We have seen an increased amount of money being spent on resources and facilities. This has achieved better sporting performances. It has achieved improved coaching standards. There are those special international achievements that one might read about in the latest annual report of the Australian Sports Commission. It highlights those page after page, particularly centred around the Olympic Games. It mentions the Australian teams who have participated in the Commonwealth Games and other international sporting events.

I mentioned earlier that sport is economically important. Today it is truly an industry. The economic significance flows not only to the national level but is experienced at the regional and local levels, be it in equipment sales, the provision of facilities, the employment that is created or the health issue that I talked about before. It even flows to the media and printing industries. A massive amount of money is spent today on the production of material.

In the latest report that the Minister for Local Government and Ethnic Affairs (Ms Fatin) has distributed to honourable members, outlining the sort of assistance that is given under the recreation and fitness program, there is page after page listing the publications, videos, manuals, posters and all sorts of material available to Australians. One can imagine the costs involved in this production level. Again, sport and recreation is vital in that field.

We could add the travel industry to the importance of sport economically. I do not know what percentage of the income earned by the travel industry relates directly to sport but I would suggest a large proportion is linked up directly and indirectly with sport and recreation across this nation. It is important that governments, regardless of their political colour, recognise this and are prepared to give not only policy attention to the issues but also resources in terms of dollars.

The issue that I want to raise is that it seems that whilst the emphasis has been national-there are certainly runs on the board when it comes to achievement in sport and we have certainly achieved our objectives set down in the report, the objectives of significantly improving Australia's sporting performance and promoting widespread community participation in sport, and providing the resources and the services and facilities-I am concerned that the emphasis is placed too much on where the population is. I speak as a member of parliament representing a provincial city and a large rural area.

I want to talk about talent identification. This is a subject that concerns all members who represent those areas where young people particularly do not get the opportunity that they deserve. Some time back I was at a sports day at a place called Coppabella, a tiny railway town in the northern part of my electorate, west of Mackay. One of the teachers said to me, `That fellow could be an Olympian. Trouble is he won't make it because he won't be given the edge, that special edge that he needs in coaching terms'. I asked what we could do about it, and he said, `I think we need some sort of coaching clinic because he's not the odd person out. There are dozens of people, young people particularly, right across the nation, particularly in country areas, who have it but never get the opportunity'.

I took this issue to the Australian Railways Union which, in cooperation with the Queensland Government, ran the Railway Institute at Coppabella-and I point out that this was a National Party Government. I spoke to the education officers in Rockhampton and asked whether they would be prepared to assist in establishing a weekend clinic if I could get a sponsor. The Coppabella area would provide the facilities and the Coppabella Railway Institute, with the backing of the union, would supply the food and accommodation if the Education Department would supply the coaches. It took some time to put it together, but it happened.

I am told from conversations I have had with the parents, the individual kids and the teachers of those eight or nine schools who participated in this sports day-in some cases there were only five or six kids from each small school-that it was one of the greatest successes they had ever seen. It was not the biggest day in terms of participants and it was not the biggest day in terms of spectators, but in terms of the quality of performance and the quality of coaching it was the zenith.

I would argue that we need to duplicate this event right across this nation in rural Australia. We need to give those kids in little schools and small towns the chance to work at the edge, to improve their performance at the edge, as it was suggested to me by that teacher. There are kids missing out because of geographical disadvantages; because of the cost of travel, the lack of opportunity and the lack of availability of quality coaching. It simply comes back to the numbers game; it comes back to the cost of providing facilities. They simply do not have those facilities. They run on dirt tracks and half-grass tracks. They do not have the tartan tracks that the athletic groups have in the capital cities and the major provincial cities; they run, as it might be said, in the bush.

There is no magic wand to solve this problem because we are talking about taxpayers' money. We are talking about economies of scale. But we are also talking about a philosophy that we certainly have in the Australian Labor Party that we ought to have policies that accommodate the needs of all Australians, not just those who live in the major cities of our nation.

We need to come up with some answers. The issue here in the first instance is talent identification. We will not identify the talent unless kids have an opportunity to be involved in the sport in question. We will not identify the talent unless the young people have the chance to participate in some form of competition. We cannot assess a child running down a bush road, but we can make an assessment when four or five young people participate in small school sports, fight it out together and are timed in a race. We can see from the skills they have and the style that they use that, as the teacher to whom I referred said to me 18 months ago, `This kid could be an Olympian'.

I argue that we need to establish a joint government sports network for non-metropolitan Australia. It could come under the terms of reference of the Australian Sports Commission. It could be taken up through a joint ministerial approach by the Ministers of sport right across the nation. We need to acknowledge that there are young people out there in the broad areas of Australia who have the capacity and potential to achieve but who will not reach the line unless they are given special assistance. I would argue that such an approach be at least started by way of negotiations or at the discussion table so that Ministers could get together and come up with a policy that would address what I see as a problem-a national problem.

It is a problem not only of talent identification, but also of provision of facilities. As I said before, there is no way that we are going to provide a tartan track in some of the small country towns. But if we took on the concept of multipurpose facilities, using a central point in a region-the largest town in the area that services a region-then we may be able to meet this need. We may be able to address the problem. This approach to multipurpose facilities ought to be pursued on a community, schools and local authority basis.

I have many examples in my area where this approach could work. For instance, Moranbah has some 13,000 people. It is a mining town in the northern part of my electorate. Surrounding it we have towns such as Coppabella, the railway centre that I mentioned earlier, Nebo, Dysart and Clermont, which is not part of my electorate but is not far away, and the general district. That figure of 13,000 people suddenly grows to 30,000 people. Given financial support from local authorities, from State and Federal governments and the community, the necessary facilities could be provided.

There is also the question of travel costs. I have no magic wand for this issue, but I wonder how we overcome the travel costs. How do we ensure that young people-whether they be individuals or part of a team-can compete in sports with teams in other areas? It may be that we need to give assistance to local authorities for the provision of sports buses. We do this sort of thing for the aged, so this is not an issue for which there is no precedent. We have an excellent approach with day respite care programs throughout Australia. I know in my own area, in Yeppoon, recently we allocated $300,000 and that was initially for capital costs of the buses and facilities and then recurrent costs for the bus driver. This means that elderly people and disabled people are able to go to one centre on the whole Capricorn coast area on a regular daily basis to benefit from the facilities and services that are provided.

I argue that, just as we provide those services for the elderly, we need now to target the young. We need to acknowledge that there are kids out there who deserve a better opportunity and we need to assist them. From a funding point of view, perhaps we could find a way around this by setting up what I have simply called a national sports foundation. People in the private sector who are given an incentive-and it comes back to tax incentives or monetary incentives-would be prepared to support such a structure if it were to their advantage. That money could then be used to support the would-be Olympians, to support young people participating at the State level and to support the regional programs which I have discussed in my contribution today.

There is certainly a need for what I am suggesting and our Government, the Hawke Labor Government, has already indicated its understanding of the problem. The 1990-91 report, Commonwealth Assistance for Local Projects, which I received from the Minister for Local Government (Ms Fatin), points out what has taken place in the community recreation sporting facilities program. It also demonstrates the demand that exists for facilities. So this is not just an issue of a few people in Moranbah or Nebo or Coppabella saying that they need these facilities.

The report shows a record of demand. In a period of two years, there were 2,000 applications and the requests for funding amounted to $200m. The initiative taken by the then Minister for Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories, Senator Richardson, made available $13m. That was a very generous amount in comparison with what was given before because nothing was given before, so that was a lot of money. But I ask honourable members to consider that situation. There were 2,000 applications with requests for funding for projects amounting to $200m. We had $13m to spend and we were able to fund 382 projects.

I suggest to the House that those 2,000 applications represent only a very small part of the demand in the community. The reason why that is only a small part of the demand is that this special scheme which was initiated by the Federal Labor Government was for the upgrading of existing facilities. It did not cover other issues; it did not go to the issue of talent identification or sports development when it came to the personnel involved; it did not go to the issue of travel costs or to the issue of coaching. So when we add in all those other projects that at the moment are being left to the States, I would suggest that figure of 2,000 applications could blow out to 20,000.

The Federal Government has given a lead in the provision of this money. Regrettably money has not been allocated for this financial year, but I am hoping that the scheme will be resuscitated. The Federal Government deserves credit, as do previous governments, for giving the priority that has been warranted to sport. But I believe we now need to give emphasis to the rural and country parts of Australia and we need to ensure that the kids who live out there have the same opportunities as their counterparts in the metropolitan area.

In the few moments I have left, I wish to go to another issue. I have raised this matter, in part, in this House on other occasions. Once I raised it in a party situation and I received a few cracks that I was looking for a plaque recovery for the economy of Australia. I suggested that we needed a `plaque system' to ensure that we did not lose the heritage that we have. In the past we have funded a famous peoples, places and events commemorative program. Having spoken to a previous Minister, Mr Barry Cohen, I now find that funding for that has dropped from hundreds of thousands of dollars in past years to only $50,000 this year. I believe that we cannot risk the loss of our heritage. We have to reactivate interest at the local, State and community levels to preserve and protect those important places and sites. We need to preserve the sites; we need to preserve the events. We also need to designate sites and past events. We need to try to find funds-possibly mixed funding-to renovate the famous places and also in some way to commemorate the people and the events in question.

My immediate answer to this problem would be to come up with a national heritage plaque that could be produced, I argue, at a low cost, when one considers the economies of scale. I would suggest that these plaques be made available across the nation to local governments and community historic groups so that they could be put in place to designate some historic aspect that relates to our nation, be it post-1788 or pre-1788. That would encourage the recording of local history. It would involve local authorities more in this important area. It would also ensure that we have community involvement because there would be a task of ensuring that we authenticate the claims that are made.

In all, we would gain because people today are interested in our history, be they domestic or overseas tourists. When they come to my area, they want to go to Mount Morgan; they want to see what central Queensland has been all about; they want to read about the history of the region. Yet they go to some places in my area and there is no way of knowing what really took place because there is no record of the event and no description of the place.

There are advantages in economic terms from a tourism point of view. There are also advantages from an educational point of view and there are certainly advantages from a community involvement point of view because emphasis would be given to local history. I therefore ask the Minister to give consideration to this scheme. It could be simply a development of the present commemoration scheme that is in place. It would require additional funds, but I suggest the advantages would be many.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Webster Mr A.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am very pleased to be able to say a few words about these amendments contained in the Arts, Sport, Environment, Tourism and Territories Legislation Amendment Bill. I am pleased to see that the Parliamentary Secretary to the Prime Minister, the honourable member for Lindsay (Mr Free), is at the table because some of the things to which I will be referring I am sure he will be very interested in-and not the slightest bit embarrassed about.

SPEECH.PARA: The Bill includes a number of amendments to the National Parks and Wildlife Conservation Act 1975, as has already been pointed out. These amendments will allow any money collected by the Director of the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service for leases, licence permits and other authorities to be used by the Service in its conservation role by having the money paid into the national parks and wildlife fund instead of into Consolidated Revenue. That is indeed history in the making. We have heard so often, at both State and Federal level, that all these funds that are collected by government bodies, no matter how small, have to go into Consolidated Revenue. I commend the Government for this step forward.

The Bill also permits the Director to invest money held by the Service but not needed immediately and to accept bequests in the form of shares, securities and other forms of investment. I find this to be astonishing, wonderful reading; it is certainly something very new on the agenda in terms of available money coming into the hands of government bodies.

I am particularly interested, as I am sure the honourable member for Lindsay is, in the increased funding that might now become available to the National Parks and Wildlife Service and associated Commonwealth services to engage in more research into, for example, bushfires. We come from an area that, prior to the last bushfire season in the Blue Mountains, was described as a powder keg. It is probably the worst potential fire area in the world today. The main reason for that is that we have not had a major fire through the Blue Mountains, which contains quite a bit of Commonwealth territory, for eight or nine years, maybe longer.

TALK.START.PARA: —Thirteen.

—As the honourable member reminds me, it has been 13 years. As every experienced bushfire fighter knows, as the honourable member knows, and as I know, having been a captain in the surrounding area for nine or 10 years, the hazard that has built up as a result of the inability of those who could reduce that hazard to do so has created a tremendous problem, and a quite frightening one.

SPEECH.PARA: A couple of days before Christmas-perhaps it was Christmas Eve-we had a very serious bushfire in the Hawkesbury region in an area where there had not been any hazard reduction for many years. Anybody who has been to an area of heavy bushland where hazard reduction programs have not been undertaken knows that when the fire conditions are right-when there is very low humidity and high temperatures and, in our situation, strong north-westerly winds-there is the potential for a great disaster. Indeed, quite horrendous fires occurred on that day, making the attendance of the very well equipped and trained bushfire fighters almost meaningless.

When these wildfires get going-as they do in the Blue Mountains and as they will do again, if not in the next season then certainly in the not too distant future-it does not matter how well equipped the brigades are. I pay tribute to the bushfire brigades in the Blue Mountains and to the council and the fire control officer in that area for what they have done in equipping the brigades. The whole fleet is now dieselised in terms of the engines in the trucks and the pumps on the back, and the training that has been undertaken is very good.

Having said all that, if we get a fire through the area without having done the necessary hazard reduction there will be massive loss of life. I can see the honourable member for Lindsay and myself approaching the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), perhaps after next December-it is quite feasible-to tell him that 1,000 or 2,000 homes have been destroyed by an horrendous fire. One of the main reasons why we have this great difficulty, as has been indicated a number of times, is that some areas of government-not only Commonwealth but State as well-do not have funding available to allow personnel to engage in the necessary hazard reduction activities. When I see that money will be allowed to be used by the government bodies who receive fees and lease money and all sorts of other things, I am very hopeful that there will be a removal of this difficulty that confronts many government bodies. In the past they have used lack of funds as an excuse to limit the hazard reduction that is necessary in these areas.

Many people have mentioned hazard reduction in this debate. For the benefit of those people who might not know, hazard reduction simply involves choosing a time when the conditions which would allow a serious fire to occur are totally absent but when it is still possible to burn the underlayers of rubbish that gather over the years. As leaves and bark fall, these levels build up to sometimes 20 to 30 tonnes to the hectare of bushland. When a fire occurs and there are the conditions I mentioned earlier-low humidity, high temperature and strong north-west winds-we have a bushfire that is absolutely uncontrollable. They are called wildfire or crown fires and they roar through the tops of the trees like blow torches.

I have attended some of these fires; I have watched them coming out of the valleys. They roar out of the valleys like giant blowtorches I have watched the big signs on the corners of the highways and roads actually melt before my eyes and drop in a heap of solder because of the intensity of the heat. I have seen the rocks on the side of the roads in the cuttings explode because of the heat. That heat has been generated because the fire has been a wildfire that has resulted from the lack of hazard reduction in areas that are prone to regular fires.

If it were possible for us to leave the bush as it is and, hopefully, not see any fires pass through, that would be lovely. But because we have hundreds of thousands of houses scattered throughout these fire-prone areas something has to be done to reduce that fire hazard. I hope that a lot more money will become available as a result of the amendments to this legislation to enable State and Federal bodies who are able to do so to give assistance to local bushfire brigades and councils so that hazard reduction programs can be undertaken much more quickly.

I know that the New South Wales Government has made amendments to the legislation to allow a workable arrangement between the Forestry Commission, the New South Wales National Parks and Wildlife Service and local councils to work together. This is very commendable, and has been done to enable hazard reduction to take place in the Blue Mountains at a faster rate.

I do think more money needs to be allocated to this problem. If we become more generous with these relevant bodies, then the honourable member for Lindsay and I will not find ourselves ringing the Prime Minister and others with horrendous tales, seeking massive assistance for the tremendous damage that will result-particularly in the Blue Mountains during the next or the following fire season-if nothing is done.

This is not to say that we want to see the whole of the mountains burnt out. There is no more ridiculous viewpoint than that. We need a collective effort from the points of view of organisation and the granting of further financial assistance to enable this to be done in a very practical, organised way so that there will be strips of land around residential areas where firefighters will be able to reduce the hazard, and as well in other strategic areas so we will have some ability to control the fires in the Blue Mountains-fires which are looming upon us and which will be quite horrendous.

I know I have the full support of the honourable member for Lindsay, who is at the table, in this regard. I hope that between us we will be able to apply more pressure, and perhaps get more assistance as a result of the extra money which I hope will be available following these amendments, to assist councils and to reduce the impending horror. I am not overstating the situation when I say `impending horror'. Anybody who has experienced a bushfire of the kind that can occur in the Blue Mountains will know exactly what I am talking about. We believe that the ingredients are now in place for a major conflagration in the Blue Mountains. It will make a very, very vivid impression on the minds of people who will experience it.

I was very interested to draw out an old cutting that was in the Daily Telegraph in February 1985. It is headed `Politicians and ``greenies'' mean more Ash Wednesdays'. It is an expression of the views of a fellow named Ron Prior who was interviewed by Mike Safe, a journalist. Mike Safe said that he was talking `with a man burned up about lack of action on bush fires'. It is quite a good article. It is further headed, `Firefighter foresees future of ashes'.
I see great destruction pending in the Blue Mountains and in other areas around the State-indeed, around the country- because we have this ultra concern about not destroying any bushland at all.

I noticed when I was out at the fire on 23 December last year that during the day we had this tremendously uncontrolled burning of a crown fire, but when the weather conditions cooled down during the night, and the wind dropped and the humidity rose, the fire continued on through the bush, but all it did was take away the litter in a most wonderful way on the forest floor, leaving intact the boles of the trees and many of the shrubs which were about. They did not burn at all-they retained their greenery-whereas many of the trees burnt during the day were totally destroyed. I am talking about trees 40 to 50 feet high. The heat of the fire totally destroyed those trees.

Anyone who remembers the bushfire which passed through the Grose Valley-in another part of the Blue Mountains through the Bilpin area-in 1979, I think it was, can visit that magnificent area of bushland today and see that it is still recovering. It has not returned to what it was due to the fact it had this giant wildfire pass through it. There had been no hazard reduction in that area in previous years.

I am making a plea tonight that we be very generous towards organisations which have anything to do with the future protection of people who live in these fire prone areas. I do not intend to speak about policies where councils may have been a bit indiscreet in allowing people to build in areas where they ought not have been allowed to build. That is another area which needs to be looked at, but it is straying a bit far away from this Bill. I have perhaps strayed a little far away from it in some respects already.

I draw this major problem to the attention of the House and the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (Mrs Kelly). The Minister happens to be visiting my electorate in the Blue Mountains on the coming weekend, and she will see for herself how magnificent that area is, how many lovely homes there are in the area and how these may be preserved, and how damage may be minimised if there is an intelligent undertaking of careful hazard reduction-and if the money is made available to government agencies, both Commonwealth and State, to be able to do that.

I commend this matter to the honourable member for Lindsay. I am sure he will be seeing the Minister when she visits the area. I know he shall bring it to her attention and that she will be very sympathetic to whatever he has to say.
Sitting suspended from 6.27 to 8.00 p.m.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Charlesworth Dr R.I.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Arts, Sport, Environment, Tourism and Territories Legislation Amendment Bill 1991 now before us relates to a number of Acts, including the National Library Act 1960, the National Parks and Wildlife Conservation Act 1975 and the Australian Capital Territory (Self-Government) Act 1988. A number of these issues have been canvassed by other speakers in the debate.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to focus my attention on two particular aspects that are picked up in this legislation. One relates to some minor amendments to the Australian Sports Drug Agency Act 1990 and the other to the Australian Sports Commission Act 1989, which will ensure that the financial transactions and general state of affairs of the Australian Sports Foundation are included in all reports to the Australian Sports Commission (ASC) prepared by it under section 63m of the Audit Act 1901. (Quorum formed)
It is delightful once again to see such a large number of honourable members drawn to the House when I am on my feet.

The issue I want to pursue is that of the Australian Sports Drug Agency. It is one which was canvassed in this House quite recently when the legislation came to this place. Of course it is something that honourable members of both sides of the House would endorse. At that time I expressed some concerns about the nature of the agency and the way in which it would operate. I will once again take the opportunity to say that there is concern on my part about how the information which the agency gets will be used by sports administrators.

A number of those drugs which are on the testing list for the agency are drugs for which their efficacy in improving sports performance has not been established. Indeed, the use of some drugs on the testing list is illegal. It concerns me that the use of the agency may lead to conviction or indeed great embarrassment to sports people who may be tested in the course of their sport and found, for various reasons, to be using these substances.

A concern was expressed after the last Olympic Games about the arbitrary level at which some of the blood levels have been set for sporting performance. Indeed, it was the case during those Olympic Games that one athlete from Australia was ruled out of the competition because his level of caffeine was above the level that had been established. However, it was established in an arbitrary way, for at the previous Olympics the level at which he was judged ineligible would have been adequate and acceptable. So there is concern about the way in which the agency operates.

There is no concern about the fact that we need such an agency, that there needs to be random testing of athletes and that athletes need to understand that using substances to enhance their performance will not be tolerated. There is concern about the way in which the agency operates. The agency needs to be vigilant and not judgmental in the way in which information is used and is made available to sports administrators. It needs to be carefully monitored. It is with interest that I will watch the performance of the Sports Drug Agency, which is in its infancy. I imagine that in future reports of the Sports Commission we will see the progress of that agency and will be able to follow it.

The other issue I wish to canvass is that of the Australian Sports Commission. As is included in this legislation and as I pointed out earlier, in the future the records of the Sports Commission will contain the state of financial affairs of the Australian Sports Foundation. This Foundation was set up within the ambit of the Sports Commission to canvass and obtain funds from the private sector and to provide significant tax benefits to those who choose to be benefactors of sport. The majority of the funds that were made available through the Foundation last year were directed to particular projects and sports. Of the order of $9m was available to sport last year through this fund. Certainly it is something that has been very beneficial to sport in general and to the way in which amateur sports in particular can receive funding.

What is more important to me than the way in which the Australian Sports Commission operates is the way we see the development of the Australian Institute of Sport (AIS). It is something about which I have spoken before in this place and about which I will continue to speak until I am satisfied that the aims and intentions of the Government and the Martin Finance and Government Operations Committee, which reported on sport, have been satisfied by the way in which the ASC operates. No-one would have been a greater supporter of the Australian Institute of Sport than myself. Conceptually, I believe that it was the right thing to do.

Over the last decade there has been significant change in the way in which sport is structured and administered in this country and it is important that we take that into consideration. When we look at the development of elite sports people, it is important that we take into account the geographical, climatic and regional differences in this country and realise that if we are to fund and develop elite sports people, we need to do it where they are, where it is most convenient for them and where the coaches are. It is not a sensible approach in a country with the size and geography of Australia to have all that centralised in Canberra.

We have significant and very high quality facilities in Canberra-no-one would doubt that-but what we do not have in Canberra is the people. As the honourable member for Dobell (Mr Lee) would understand, the majority of young people, the majority of athletes, are in Sydney, Melbourne, Adelaide, Perth or Brisbane-in the major centres of population in this country. I think it is necessary for us to consider that when we talk about developing elite sports people in this country and the way in which we allocate funds for that purpose.

It is the case that since the Australian Institute of Sport was established most of the State governments have established institutes of sport themselves. They are now providing sports science backup, sports medicine backup and coaching expertise to support the athletes, including the developing athletes, in those places. The suggestion has been made-and indeed it is canvassed by the AIS-that the AIS needs to provide associate scholarships for these people who choose not to come to a central program. This is essentially an argument about who gets the credit for the development of sports people. We need to go beyond that. It is nonsense to be arguing about naming rights when we talk about the development of elite sports people. We should be making sure that our allocation of resources is as efficient as possible.

It is the case in some sports that it is appropriate to have a centralised training program in one place because of the number of talented athletes available, the coaching expertise that is available or the necessary facilities that are available, but in the majority of sports that is not the case. It is not necessarily the best way.
