At the moment we find that many sports and sports administrators are held to ransom by the fact that they are under the impression that they will lose their funding and that their sport will lose assistance from the AIS unless they are involved in a national centralised program. Many athletes see their only chance of national selection and of getting the best coaching as being through centralised programs, and in a sense they are pushed towards those programs.

What we should be doing, what the Australian Sports Commission should be doing-and it is what the Martin Finance and Government Operations Committee recommended and indeed I believe it is the intention of the Government-is supporting the best athletes wherever they are. `Wherever they are' does not mean supporting an athlete living in Widgiemooltha by himself; it means supporting athletes where they have accredited and well supervised and supported programs. That is what we mean when we talk about decentralising the AIS, increasing its efficiency and making the dollars go as far as possible.

The last time I spoke on this issue-only a few weeks ago-there was considerable media follow-up. Jeff Wells, in his article in the Australian of the weekend of 16-17 February, went to this issue. He was talking about the Australian Sports Commission and in particular the approach of ASC Executive Director, Jim Ferguson. I quote his last paragraph:
. . . he can be a statesman and grasp the logic of the coaches' concept that sport is best served by a federal network of excellence-not a federal centre of excellence.

I think that is the issue that needs to be taken up here. We need a network of excellence in this country. The last time I spoke here I talked about swimming and I pointed out the fact that the Australian Institute of Sport's centralised swimming program received $700,000 and produced five out of the 38 athletes who were in the national team at the beginning of this year. A small program in Western Australia with $140,000 produced six athletes, and if you include the long distance swimmers many more. The majority of the athletes in the national team-33 out of 38-were produced in centres all around the country, close to their homes under the supervision of their own excellent coaches. The same should apply in a number of sports.

Subsequent to that speech, just last weekend we had the national athletics championships. Again I point to the results. The performances of Western Australians in the national championships last week were extraordinary. I am not trying to be parochial in saying this, but although Western Australia has a relatively small population, seven national titleholders were from Western Australia-the best ever for that State. It is coincidental, but I believe that the following correlation is compelling: in Western Australia we have a program from the Western Australian Institute of Sport that indeed is embryonic but that is supporting future elite athletes. The way in which that program operates has been responsible for a great deal of the resurgence of sporting performance.

I am sure that the honourable member for Barker (Mr McLachlan) will be interested to know that the national high jump champion is now a young Western Australian woman named Alison Inverarity, who jumped 1.94 metres-which is taller than him or me. Indeed, she is now ranked seventeenth in the world. She is a product of this regional program in Western Australia, which has excellent sports science and sports medicine backup and an outstanding coach in Tutor Bidder, who is a former Welsh national coach.

I could go on and talk about other programs. The point I am trying to make is that the results in these national championships are indicative of the fact that local programs where people live can provide the sort of support and development that is important for our elite athletes.

The arguments that we hear against this are interesting, but I do not think they carry weight. The first argument we hear is that, in an educational and vocational sense, the assistance that is available in Canberra through the AIS is greater than that which can be provided in the States. That makes a mockery of the fact that the States are responsible for education. Indeed State governments involved in State programs are in an excellent position to provide vocational and educational backup and support for athletes in their area.

The fact that many young athletes could live at home with their parents is a huge plus. It must be as a last resort that we move towards centralised programs in sport. In respect of coaching, we can take the example of Western Australia. I have already mentioned Tutor Bidder and the success that he has had, but now the Western Australian Institute of Sport has secured the services of Andre Rodionenko, who was the coach of the women's gymnastic team from the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics at the 1985 and 1987 world championships. He was the coach of the gold medallist in all round gymnastics for women in 1988. He is arguably the best women's gymnastic coach in the world, and he is part of that program. The rowing program in Western Australia has Stephan Muhlenberg, who was a former East German rowing coach at world championships and Olympic Games.

Coaching quality is available not only in Western Australia, but in many other places. The only person who has been producing gold medal winning swimmers in this country over the last few Olympics is Laurie Lawrence, whose program is on the other side of the country. It is not the case that all coaching expertise resides in Canberra; indeed, it is spread across the country.

When we look at the facilities, it is very clear that in Western Australia we have excellent facilities when it comes to swimming, gymnastics, hockey and cricket. In Tasmania we have a rowing program because of the excellence of the facility there. In Queensland, where the climate is so conducive to swimming, we have the impetus of the facilities that are available for swimming. When we look at sports medicine and sports science backup, we find that what is available all around the country is the equivalent of anything available in Canberra.

We need to understand that a centralised fortress in Canberra is not the appropriate model for the next decade, and it is important that we consider that the future of the development of elite sportsmen in this country lies in the States where the people are.

The AIS has led the way so far, but in the future it will be State programs that will do so; if the Australian Sports Commission is not careful and does not take note of this changing trend, then it will be left behind in the development of elite sports people in Australia.

This is not a States rights issue; it is an Australian perspective, and cooperative effort is required if we are to use our sporting dollars most efficiently. That is the aim of the Australian Sports Commission. It was set up to provide independent and expert advice and an expert way of managing sports dollars in this country. It is my view that if its members are wary of the changes that are occurring in sport they will take a view that decentralisation of these programs is the way that we have to go in the 1990s.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Simmons The Hon D.W.

TALKER.NAME: Mr SIMMONS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts, Tourism and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: -I begin by thanking all those who have participated in this debate for their contributions. The honourable member for Wannon (Mr Hawker) began on behalf of the Opposition and I thank him and the Opposition for their indication of support for the Arts, Sport, Environment, Tourism and Territories Legislation Amendment Bill.

SPEECH.PARA: One of the characteristics of portfolio Bills is the fact that in many cases they provide for minor technical amendments, but honourable members appropriately take the opportunity to extend the debate across areas of interest and concern. To that extent, the final contribution, by the honourable member for Perth (Dr Charlesworth), is an indication of the way in which debates can be used. People would be aware of the honourable member's long association with and contribution to Australian sport. I listened with a great deal of interest to his contribution to the debate. He brought to this debate a great deal of knowledge in the area of Australian sport and I think the House appreciated his thoughts.

The contributions by the honourable member for Cook (Mr Dobie) and the honourable member for Macquarie (Mr Webster) touched on a number of issues relating to the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service. In particular, the honourable member for Macquarie made reference to his concerns about bushfires in the Blue Mountains of New South Wales. As a near neighbour of the honourable member for Macquarie, I can identify with those concerns, because the Blue Mountains area has been devastated on many occasions by bushfires. There was great concern during the course of the last summer-continuing into the early autumn-that once again that area could be ravaged by bushfires. It is one of those great natural disasters that is always on the minds of people who inhabit that part of New South Wales. The thoughts that were provided in the debate by both the honourable member for Cook and the honourable member for Macquarie have been noted.

The honourable member for Petrie (Mr Johns) in his contribution brought to the debate his special interest as chairman of the caucus committee on the arts, sport, the environment, tourism and territories. His interest covers the range of matters that are being dealt with in this Bill. I understand that a great deal of his contribution related to developments in far north Queensland in the Tully region, and in particular the Tully Millstream. That has been an area of interesting controversy as far as the proposals by the Queensland Government are concerned.

I have had an opportunity to visit that area in recent times, and I realise that it poses some interesting dilemmas in debates relating to environmental questions, particularly when we look at the obvious questions of potential energy resources that could be provided by projects like that. Yet, on the other hand, people would obviously feel concern when magnificent rivers face potential damage because of major developmental projects.

The proposal of the honourable member for Capricornia (Mr Wright) related to his interest in country Australia, particularly central Queensland. I know of his interest in the King O'Malley aspect of the commemorative project that is part of the portfolio responsibility. I know that most people would recognise the great contribution that that great character in Australian politics has made to the political life of this country. The honourable member for Capricornia has made very strong and persistent representations to my office in wanting to push the case for an appropriate commemoration of King O'Malley's presence in the Capricornia region of central Queensland.

As most people are aware, the amendments to the series of Acts that are covered by the Arts, Sport, Environment, Tourism and Territories Legislation Amendment Bill are largely of a technical nature but, as I indicated at the outset, they do allow members who are participants in this debate the opportunity to range fairly widely. I think in that sense portfolio Bills serve a useful function because they allow honourable members who contribute to these debates an opportunity to press those principal matters of concern to them. In particular, it gives honourable members who have a particular electorate in or professional relationship with some of the areas that are covered by the portfolio amendment Bills an opportunity to add that additional presence and contribution to the debates.

I conclude by thanking all honourable members for their very positive contribution to the Arts, Sport, Environment, Tourism and Territories Legislation Amendment Bill during the debate this afternoon and this evening.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ruddock Mr P.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Immigration (Education) Amendment Bill has been introduced to provide the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs power to broaden the categories of people who may avail themselves of English language and citizenship courses. The explanatory memorandum tells us that it also makes a number of minor technical amendments. That explanatory memorandum, which is the font of all wisdom in these matters, goes on to say:

SPEECH.PARA: The Bill provides that the Minister may arrange for English courses and citizenship courses to be provided to particular categories of persons . . .
and for the Minister to arrange:
for the courses to be provided to persons who hold a Temporary Entry Permit of a class specified by the Minister by notice in the Gazette.
On reading all of that, we are little further enlightened as to what we are in fact discussing.

The second reading speech of the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs (Mr Hand) was one page long. He told us, by way of a little further elucidation, that the Bill allows persons holding temporary entry permits of classes specified by him to have access to adult migrant English program courses and citizenship courses and goes on:

This will enable participation in such courses by asylum seekers and nationals of the People's Republic of China and their spouses in accordance with temporary residence arrangements and access to government services for these groups announced by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) in his speech to Parliament of 27 June 1990.

So we know now that the Immigration (Education) Amendment Bill is about the provision of extra benefits to People's Republic of China (PRC) nationals who happened to be in Australia at the time of the Tiananmen massacre. Specifically, it allows for those people with a four-year temporary entry permit and their spouses who have been enabled by this Government to join them here in Australia to have access to the adult migrant education courses and citizenship courses provided by the Government at the expense of the taxpayers of Australia. According to the Government's estimates, approximately 11,000 people may avail themselves of these courses.

To many, this Bill represents another flagstone in the bypass to permanent residency for a group of people who have not been required to satisfy normal migration criteria. This is reinforced by the explanatory memorandum which tells us that the very people about whom we are speaking are, `persons who have qualified for special provisional residence categories in Australia'. I do not know what was meant by the draftsman, but all honourable members will know that the explanatory memorandum is an aid to interpreting legislation and if people wanted to believe that temporary entry might lead them to permanency in Australia one could be forgiven for believing that that was a possibility when one sees that the Government uses the term that these are people who have qualified for special provisional residence categories in Australia.

The Bill allows for access to English language and citizenship courses. We in the Opposition are not opposing that grant of permission to participate in those courses. But we do have concerns as to the way in which the Government has proceeded with this matter, as we have had concerns about the way in which the Government has dealt with the question of Chinese students generally.

The first matter I seek to have clarified very clearly by the Government is that this Bill, which speaks of providing both English language and citizenship courses, is not providing citizenship courses discretely which are intended to aid people who are intending to be long term settlers in Australia. If they were discrete courses, I could see no reason to provide citizenship education to people for whom long term settlement in Australia is not intended. I have been assured that they cannot be separated. If that is the case, that ought to be made clear by the Government.

This Bill is the outcome of the inconsistent, ill-considered, ad hoc and, frankly, chaotic matter in which the issue of PRC nationals has been handled by this Government. The Opposition's position in regard to this matter has been consistent, considered and in keeping with the principles of existing criteria, long applied by Australia for migration selection and refugee determination. We have at all times said that there was no basis for the creation of a special category; that there was no basis for disadvantaging this group by not treating them with the respect accorded all other claimants for refugee status within Australia.

Let us look at the significant decisions made in relation to PRC nationals since the then Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs, now the Minister for Defence (Senator Robert Ray), announced on 6 June 1989 an extension of temporary entry permits for PRC nationals, legally or illegally in Australia as at 4 June, until the end of the following month. The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), belatedly realising the gross inadequacy of this provision, later announced on 16 June that the Government was further extending the visas for another 12 months until 31 July 1990. At the time of his announcement, Senator Robert Ray clearly enunciated the Government's intention to treat PRC nationals like any other applicant for refugee status. In the Senate Hansard of 6 June 1989 at page 3415, the then Minister said:
Applications will not be determined on the basis of a class of people, but on individual merits. They will be considered on the basis of individual claims.

It seems that the Prime Minister forgot this little dictum when he announced on the Jana Wendt program exactly one year later the creation of a special category for PRC nationals. In a move characteristic of the Prime Minister's disregard for the parliamentary process, with which we are all familiar, he failed to consult his own Cabinet on a decision which was to have a significant and lasting impact upon the entire immigration program of this country. The Prime Minister announced a special immigration category for 19,400 Chinese nationals in Australia before 20 June 1989. This provided them with permits for temporary residence until 30 June 1993. Applications for permanent residency from members of this group would not be considered if the political situation in China did not improve at the end of the four-year period, we were led to believe.

Those PRC nationals arriving after this arbitrary cut-off date nominated by the Prime Minister were entitled to apply only for refugee status under existing criteria. In this sense, they are exactly the same arrangements which apply to Sri Lankans, Lebanese, Iranians, Burmese and Fijians, to name a few of the claimants with whom we are all familiar. So we have two classes of people: some who have justifiable claims for protection and another group who may have no substantial claims for protection but are given by this Government automatic cover.

By relegating this latter group to a special category, the Prime Minister was still not capable of fair dealing. He denied that very group of people, whom he told us he was seeking to protect, the protection that some of them could have rightly anticipated under applications they had already lodged within our law. The Government provided that unless PRC nationals withdrew their claims for permanent residency under refugee or special humanitarian criteria, or on the basis of family sponsorship and employer nomination, they were not entitled to benefits provided under the terms of the four-year temporary entry permit. These included, as they were announced later-at very considerable cost, I might say, to the Australian taxpayer-special benefits, family allowance, family allowance supplement, Medicare, labour market programs, English language training, with which this Bill deals, and education. The denial of these benefits represented a blatant attempt to bludgeon PRC nationals into accepting this limited form of entry permit.

Further, the Government scheme also denied claims by highly qualified, eminently employable and outstanding students, many of them within our universities, to be able to obtain permanent residency on occupation grounds-the very basis upon which other people are entitled to apply. The result of that has led to a very significant brain drain to Canada, the United States and Singapore in particular.

However, in good faith, the Government has belatedly moved to remedy that shortcoming-a matter that I have drawn attention to previously. It was always understood that the temporary entry permits and the subsequent extensions were designed to deter PRC nationals from applying for permanent residency. The Prime Minister made it clear both in his statement and in newspaper reports as early as August 1989 that students were being refused application forms and the Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs was actively discouraging them from applying under this category.

Fair dealing in relation to these students has been absent while blackmail has been used to compel withdrawal of applications for permanent residency. The most outrageous case of which I am aware was that of a young lady whose husband, a highly distinguished academic, was to undertake collaborative work in the United States and needed a re-entry visa to be able to return to Australia. He was told, `Your re-entry visa to go to the University of California for that collaborative work will only be given to you if your wife withdraws the application for permanent residency'-which she had separately lodged and which she was entitled to pursue. That is just one of many such outrageous cases that this Government's scheme has brought to my attention.

I could go on, because there have been other developments since the announcement by Senator Robert Ray on 21 December 1989 of those who were here legally or illegally on 20 June 1989 and who believed that they qualified for refugee status and should apply before 30 July 1990- the date on which Senator Robert Ray led them to believe they were eligible to apply. That assurance that Senator Robert Ray gave was really the most unkindest cut of all.

Several days beforehand, having led them to believe that they were entitled to lodge applications up until 31 July, on 19 December 1989 the new regulations that the Government introduced ensured that PRC nationals were no longer able to lodge those applications on humanitarian grounds for permanent residency and that their applications after that date would have no legal standing at all. Honourable members will know that that was because the PRC did not qualify because a country for which applications for nationals in the special humanitarian criteria had been made could not be considered until it was gazetted, and no countries were gazetted. So the Minister's invitation of 21 December can be described clearly as a rather cruel hoax on those who were considering applying in that area.

When the Prime Minister declared on 16 June that the most immediate thing was to give these people the confidence they needed so that they would not be under any pressure whatsoever, it has to be remembered that the Government condemned these students to very considerable uncertainty and anxiety, and it has not relieved them of that burden until this day. Even now, to get applications processed by this Government, under the law students have had to apply to the courts of this land to compel the Department to proceed with that processing. It was part of the blackmail this Government perpetuated to ensure that they were denied that opportunity and forced into taking the four-year temporary entry arrangements.

There are other matters relating to those students who were in China. In October 1989 the Government caused further confusion by applying new rules to student visas. The recruitment of new students under ELICOS-English language intensive courses for overseas students-from the People's Republic of China was suspended until January 1990 to enable a backlog of 20,000 applications in Beijing to be cleared. When the applications were reopened in January it was with more stringent criteria.

This episode of mismanagement left many potential students unable to come to Australia and many penalised financially after paying up-front fees to Australian colleges. Australia had to endure the embarrassing spectacle of rioting students outside the consulate in Shanghai. Legislation in the form of the Overseas Students Charge Amendment Bill was required to right one of the consequences of this wrong. The cost to the Australian taxpayer of $50m, possibly, was thereby authorised to repay money to those students who were so wronged.

In a category called pipeline processing that the Government introduced to deal quickly with applications of the estimated 25,000 backlog in Beijing, the Government used criteria that were much less stringent than the global criteria introduced for all other students. That meant further discrimination, in that case in favour of those who were in China, but it also allowed many intending illegal entrants into Australia. We still do not know the extent to which those post-Tiananmen Square students have obeyed the conditions of their visas and returned to China. There is enormous potential for continued numbers of overstayers as a result of that pipeline processing.

At the time of the Prime Minister's extraordinary pronouncement of policy on the Jana Wendt show, the Opposition expressed grave concerns about the conduct of immigration policy and the Prime Minister's judgment on these matters. There was no sensible basis for rejecting case by case determination of PRC nationals, pre-or post-Tiananmen Square. The only fair and equitable option to pursue was the provision of proper resources for processing and an extension of time for processing under existing arrangements for determination of refugee criteria, or the other humanitarian arrangements that have since been put in place.

We must remember that at the same time as this new category was created for Chinese nationals, the Prime Minister, in an extraordinary display of arrogance, dismissed out of hand the right of Khmer boat people now in Australia and applying for refugee status to be considered on a case by case basis. He simply declared that they were not political refugees. He did reconsider that matter later, but it was evidence of his attitude on this matter and this issue.

The Determination of Refugee Status Committee was set up to do what the Prime Minister in his arrogance said would not be done, that is, determine what their status is and who is or is not a refugee. Properly, these people were entitled to be assessed in accordance with the definition of who is a refugee, which has been the subject of international agreement. A refugee is a person who is persecuted for reasons of race, religion, nationality, membership of a particular social group, or political opinion and who is outside the country of his or her nationality and is unable or, owing to such fear, unwilling to avail himself or herself of the protection of that country.

The Prime Minister, to his shame, pre-empted and diminished the integrity of the whole process by making his own judgment in advance of those determinations. The blanket approach adopted by the Prime Minister towards categories of people applying for protection in this country made a mockery of the entire refugee program and jettisoned long-standing and well accepted internationally recognised practice with regard to the treatment of refugees, and Australia's reputation was thereby damaged.

Some Chinese nationals, without doubt, were certain to be subjected to victimisation if they were to return to China. But it is far from clear that all students pre-June 1989 would have fallen into this category, particularly given the statistics of the make-up of this group of PRC nationals. In answering a question in the Senate in November 1989 the then Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs, Senator Robert Ray, Senator Bolkus informed us that of the 12,973 PRC students who were in Australia before 20 June 1989 only 12.7 per cent were enrolled in tertiary courses and the balance were in non-formal courses, the majority of which were English tuition. He said that it was estimated that 40 per cent of the Chinese ELICOS students overstayed their visas at that time with the implied intention of remaining in Australia illegally. So we knew that before this decision was announced.

Where does this leave us now? In the light of the Government's recent decision to lift the last economic and political sanctions imposed on China, the Government needs to make perfectly clear its position on the future status of Chinese students in this country. I am sure all honourable members are familiar with the statement by Senator Evans of 26 February on Australia's relations with China, in which he said:

The Government today decided to remove the remaining economic and political restrictions on Australia's relations with China of those applied in June 1989 following the tragic events in Beijing on 4-5 June 1989.
He went on in that statement to say in relation to the Government's view:
in other respects there have been discernible improvements in the human rights situation in China.

That was the stated, considered view of the Government. The Opposition has no hesitancy in saying that the proper approach to deal with PRC cases is to look at them individually. That is, each claim for protection ought to be determined on that basis. There is no doubt that the greater claim of those who were pre- Tiananmen Square could be tested in that process. Those with entitlements under existing non-discriminatory criteria for a grant of resident status should obviously have their claims also properly tested. Spouse and occupational grounds are obviously amongst those entitlements.

Now, I have to say that that would be the Opposition's approach at the end of 1993. The same criteria that we have long said should be applied should be applied at that point in time. If there is no need for protection in 1993, then obviously those who are here and cannot claim on any other basis should be returned to China. The Opposition has of course expressed some doubts about the human rights situation in China. This view is obviously not shared by the Government, however. Under our approach, the question of human rights violations would have had no bearing on our own immigration program. On 27 June 1990, the Prime Minister observed that:
. . . unless we were confident that the situation in the PRC was such that human rights were no longer generally at risk, permanent residence would be granted to those that apply.
That was the Government's stated position.

Citing the `discernible improvements in the human rights situation in China' as adequate cause for lifting sanctions, will the Government now advise the PRC nationals in Australia on 20 June 1989, and indeed all of us, that as of 30 June 1993 those without permanent residence granted under normal immigration criteria will be required to leave? Will the Government announce that now?

I have indicated that the Bill under discussion is not opposed by the Opposition. But that does not in any way derogate from the flawed decisions that the Government made which allowed PRC nationals to stay in this country. This Bill provides English language and citizenship courses under the adult migrant education program. But, according to the explanatory memorandum from which I quoted earlier, these places will be funded out of current appropriations.

In December 1990, the report of the working party on post-secondary education training `identified significant gaps in resourcing and deficiencies in outcomes in English language programs'. The report from the Government's advisers said that many migrants were forced to leave programs before they had reached professional goals; and that these gaps applied to programs funded and administered at all levels of government. The report estimates that about 360,000 overseas born Australians do not speak English well or at all and, of those, 170,000 are in the labour force now. The working party estimated that less than one-third of these have any form of access to language training. Already, according to this report, there is a backlog of between 50,000 and 60,000 long term residents of this country with language difficulty who are currently disadvantaged by under-resourced adult migrant education program funding. That is the Government's advice.

Given these alarming statistics of the total inadequacy of language training programs, how does the Government justify disadvantaging our long term settlers, the people whom we have invited here, by allowing access to a group of people who are not, or quite possibly will never be, permanent residents of this country? Again, to quote from the report:
An NESB-
that is, a non-English speaking background-
Australian resident without access to English language learning is seriously disadvantaged, possibly for life.

This Bill provides that 11,000 people who have only temporary entry will be permitted access to these courses and quite possibly in preference to long term Australian settlers and residents in need of English language tuition and for whom, it is said in economic terms, it is important that Australia provide that facility.

The Government's handling of this issue has exposed its social hypocrisy, political ineptitude and intellectual vapidity. This is a matter of very real concern. The Opposition will permit the passage of this legislation; it goes through without any opposition from us. But the need for this was borne out of the Government's decisions taken in relation to the PRC nationals. It is a cost which the Government said it would bear out of Budget. But the cost of the provision of adult migrant education programs is in fact being borne not by the Budget, but at the expense of other long term residents of this country, other people who have been invited to settle in this nation. That needs to be clearly understood.

I can assure you, Mr Deputy Speaker, that as I go around Australia speaking on these issues, I will ensure that every person who is denied a place in the adult migrant education programs will know that there were 11,000 places, quite possibly, removed by legislation passed tonight for which the Government was unwilling to find the funds to back up the decision that it took.

While I am dealing with the question of funding, there are considerable costs to the Australian taxpayer involved in the decision that this Government took in relation to the PRC nationals. As I said in my speech earlier, many of those people had no right, if they were properly assessed, to remain in Australia. They had already intended to stay here illegally, and we have permitted them to remain on without testing any claims for protection. I would not want to send anybody back who had valid claims. But it is clear that if we had had the willingness to submit people to proper scrutiny, to examine their entitlement, a number of people who were permitted to remain by the Prime Minister's announcement would not have stayed in this country; the cost to revenue would not have been as significant as it is; the prejudice to other long term settlers would not have occurred; and we would have had funds left over to assist the Treasurer (Mr Keating) in relation to his deficit.

This was a flawed decision taken by the Prime Minister largely, I think, because of his own ill-considered statements made in the environment of emotional pique at the time of the Tiananmen Square massacre, and we are still living with the consequences of his ill-considered promises at that time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crosio The Hon J.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —In speaking in support of the Immigration (Education) Amendment Bill, I would certainly commend the honourable member for Dundas (Mr Ruddock). It is through his remarks this evening that we in Government finally know the humane and caring attitude of the Opposition! It condemns the actions taken by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and this Government in assisting and helping those people who, through unfortunate circumstances-particularly the Peoples' Republic of China (PRC) nationals, to which the honourable member devoted most of his remarks-have been in this country afraid of something from which they would want to flee. There is nothing in this Bill appertaining to that particular subject.

SPEECH.PARA: What this Bill is about is the broadening of the availability of Australia's excellent English courses under our adult migrant education program (AMEP). The Bill itself will allow more people to be eligible to participate in the AMEP courses because they are designed to provide an opportunity for recently arrived migrants with language difficulties to participate in an appropriate sequence of learning arrangements; to acquire the confidence and language skills needed to function effectively in Australian society; and, particularly, to assist our new arrivals in attaining their goals.

After participating in these AMEP courses, migrants will hopefully be able then to access appropriate employment, gain entry into mainstream education and training programs, communicate effectively with local services and in social situations, and continue to learn English independently. The program itself was established in 1947-well before the Tiananmen Square massacre-and it has become the largest government-funded adult English language teaching program in the world, and is one of Australia's main settlement services.

Not long after the establishment of AMEP there were few language classes, living allowances or other educational supports provided to encourage migrants of a non-English speaking background to learn English. Today English language acquisition has never been more important, and the demand for places in English courses has never been higher-an impetus that the Australian Government strongly endorses. The Language of Australia, a discussion paper on Australian literacy and language policy for the 1990s, released in December last year and quoted by the previous speaker, the honourable member for Dundas, states:

The Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs estimates that there is a backlog of 50,000 to 60,000 people seeking placement in adult English as a Second Language programs. This backlog, combined with low proficiency outcomes for those people who exit the AMEP program early (due to strong demand from new arrivals), adds considerable pressure to general education and training systems.

In 1988-89 an estimated 35.4 per cent of all incoming adult migrants aged 16 years and over required English language teaching. Generally 94.1 per cent of refugee and special humanitarian migrants require language instruction, while 62.4 per cent of family migrants and 18.2 per cent of migrants recruited on the basis of skill also require English language proficiency.

English needs to be learnt early before inadequate communication strategies have been established and migrants have become habituated to employment in jobs below their actual skill levels. Through the AMEP, incoming migrants are better serviced through access to longer periods of English language support. The key features of the program not only include the teaching of English but also a comprehensive educational assessment, counselling, placement and referral service. It includes professional and curriculum support activities, underpinned by the national centre for English language teaching and research. It provides a national management information system and client support arrangements such as free child-care and income support to facilitate access to the AMEP courses by women and financially disadvantaged clients.

Under the AMEP national plan, by the end of 1992 it is anticipated that 85 per cent of all resources will be allocated to the following priority groups: people with occupational skills in demand, preparing to enter the work force; employed migrants, requiring further English support for full work force mobility; unemployed migrants, needing English to enhance their work chances; and people with further study needs, preparing to enrol in courses to improve their employment potential. The remaining 15 per cent of resources will be allocated to groups with equally important social and life skill needs, such as migrant women and elderly migrants.

The AMEP has grown rapidly since the Hawke Labor Government came to power in 1983. This has been due to an expansion of the immigration program, the heightened awareness of the long term importance of teaching migrants English, and the recruitment of increasing numbers of qualified migrants who require sophisticated English to use their skills. Operating on a budget of $83m for 1990-91, with 70,500 participants and 5,000 courses last year, AMEP has more than 40 major language teaching centres, covering every State, located in areas where migrants live. AMEP courses reach about 80 per cent of all incoming migrants and course options are designed for people in rural as well as urban centres. Classes are offered day and night-in class, at work or at home-and at individual learning centres.

Typical AMEP participants are newly arrived migrants of a prime work force age not yet employed and who have a minimal knowledge of English. In New South Wales alone the percentage of these new migrants wanting to participate in the AMEP courses is 45.9 per cent, with the demand for the courses by the migrants in Victoria being 31 per cent.

There are four adult migrant education services (AMES) centres which help the migrants living in my electorate of Prospect. These centres are in Fairfield, Cabramatta, Parramatta and Blacktown. The majority of students attending these centres are from Asia, with other key groups being from the Middle East and South and Central America. The main language groups of these students are Vietnamese, Arabic, Cantonese and Spanish. Khmer is also prominent, particularly in the centres of Fairfield and Cabramatta.

Most of these students are newly arrived in Australia, with less than three years of residence, are aged between 25 and 34 years, have about 10 to 14 years of education or less, have a very low level of English skills, are semi-or unskilled and have no formal qualifications, and are unemployed.

Three of the AMES centres were extended in 1990 to meet the increasing demand in Sydney's west. Approximately 11,000 students attended the four centres servicing my Prospect electorate and 429 courses were run at these centres in 1990. As well as general English classes a wide range of special programs were available, such as bilingual courses to assist learners with their initial English learning, study skill classes to assist students undertaking further studies in mainstream institutions, job seeking skills classes to assist students in seeking employment, pronunciation classes to help students learn the standard Australian pronunciation, language of childbirth classes to help women deal with the childbirth process in Australia, office skills courses to provide training in clerical skills, and crossover classes to provide skilled migrants with work experience and job seeking skills.

Because migrants are people at different life stages they face different settlement challenges. The majority will want to work and require support to become ready for the labour market. A growing proportion will be sophisticated self-directed learners. Others will be less confident, lacking experience in classroom situations. However, the importance of obtaining a firm grounding in reading and writing, as well as speaking and listening, can hardly be overstated. English language skills provide the foundation which will expand or severely limit migrants' potential for social interaction, employment and training throughout their Australian lives.

The AMEP can be seen as a shrewd economic investment in Australia's future. Even more powerfully than in the past, knowledge of English will regulate migrants' access to life choices. I quote a recent report, The Challenge of Diversity: Policy Options for a Multicultural Australia:

Successful settlement in a multicultural Australia means having the opportunity to participate in and contribute to Australian life on an equal basis with all other Australians. The single most important factor in accomplishing this . . . is English language proficiency.

It is rapidly becoming obvious in our society that those migrants with the best hope of continued employment will be skilled, literate in English and flexible-that is, they must be geared for a lifetime of retraining. Unskilled people with minimal English will be vulnerable to long term unemployment and economic marginalisation.

Research from a 1988 report by the Committee to Advise on Australia's Immigration Policies, called Immigration, A Commitment to Australia, demonstrates a clear nexus between poor English, low skills and long term unemployment. This Committee consisted of a demographer, an ex-ambassador to China, a Commonwealth Government representative and representatives from the Australian Council of Trade Unions, local government and the Ethnic Community Council as well as a town planner. These people consulted relevant groups in the community to investigate and report on Australian immigration policy. This report stated:

There will not be a future for unskilled people in a rapidly growing Australian work force. Industry protection in such industries as vehicles, clothing, textiles and footwear has contributed to the maintenance of the kinds of jobs which many unskilled and semi-skilled migrants have worked, instead of restructuring the economy towards high technology, skills and design intensive industries.

Yet another report entitled Immigrant Qualifications: Recognition and Relative Wage Options has found--(Quorum formed) Obviously, in calling this quorum during my speaking time, the Opposition could not acknowledge the fact that the honourable member for Dundas had no knowledge of the Bill before the House. He tried to bring up the story of the immigrants who had been caught in this country.

If the main purpose of this Bill is to expand the range of persons eligible for English tuition courses under the AMEP and to allow the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs (Mr Hand) to arrange for language training and related services to be provided to non-government organisations, I for one say `wonderful'. Many migrants, not only in my electorate but in all electorates, will also say `wonderful', because it is mainly through the training and support of the AMEP courses that migrants will get the chance to assimilate into the Australian way of life.

There are many reports that have been canvassed dealing with migrants and the range of skills available to migrants within Australia, but all reports have found that immigrants from non-English speaking backgrounds were perceived as identical, whether or not they had overseas acquired skills. It was also discovered that the Australian born and immigrants with some Australian qualifications were more acceptable to employers.

This is where the AMEP can help and has helped migrants so much. By accessing an English language program, migrants are better able to enter other more formal education and retraining to make them more attractive to employers. Many of the migrants who benefit from AMEP courses are professionals, business migrants, skilled trades people, factory shift workers, older teenagers, home-makers, elderly parents and adults preparing for further study.
According to The Language of Australia discussion paper:

Unemployment rates for recently arrived immigrants are about three times higher than for Australian born workers. Immigrants who do not speak English well or at all are particularly disadvantaged. Poor proficiency in English is also a major reason for under-employment of many migrants who may have gained high professional and technical qualifications in their country of origin.

This sentiment is reiterated in a report that I received only yesterday from the Bureau of Immigration Research entitled The Cost of Low Levels of English Proficiency Amongst Immigrants in the Workforce. That report states:

It is confirmed that there is a purely economic case for immigrants not proficient in English to undertake the necessary training. It is not just poor English which is a problem, but immigrants with reasonable knowledge of English also have much to gain from further improving their proficiency.

It is clearly important to develop and maintain the facilities for immigrants with little or no English to acquire a basic knowledge. But on economic grounds, the strong case for providing opportunities for those with a reasonable knowledge of English to improve it further is just as strong.

The AMEP courses cater to this advice. After completing initial courses in English, migrants are offered a range of specialist courses through the AMEP, again to help them get employment and become accustomed to Australian society. Advanced English courses within the AMEP are also offered by nine independent tertiary providers or language centres based in universities around Australia.

It is important that this Bill before the House be carried. It is important that we have opened up the availability of AMEP courses to more people. I support the action of the Minister in bringing this Bill forward in this way.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bradford Mr J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am sorry to say it, but I think the honourable member for Prospect (Mrs Crosio) has, in her spirited support of the adult migrant English program (AMEP) actually missed the point of the Immigration (Education) Amendment Bill that is being debated here tonight. This is a debate about a piece of legislation which actually adds fuel to a fire which was effectively started by this Government when it chose to give special treatment to a group of People's Republic of China (PRC) students who were here in Australia at the time of the Tiananmen Square massacre.
—Kicking the old Asian can again. You've tried that before.

—I do not need any help from the honourable member opposite. This is not a debate about the effectiveness or otherwise of the AMEP. In fact, this Bill amends the Immigration (Education) Act 1971 and provides power for the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs to broaden categories of persons who may avail themselves of English language and citizenship courses under the AMEP. I agree with everything that the honourable member for Prospect said, but she really missed the point of what we are talking about here.

SPEECH.PARA: There is no doubt that literacy is a problem among immigrants in Australia. A report released by the Bureau of Immigration Research last month estimates that problems in English language proficiency in the work force cost Australia $763m a year. That study found that Australia's aggregate output would increase by that $763m if most immigrants became as fluent in English as those who speak it as their mother tongue.

The report actually compared the earnings of a person with poor English and one fluent in English and found that the person who had poor English actually earned about 6 per cent less in dollar terms. Using the 1986 census data on average annual incomes, this means that those who did not speak fluent English were actually being paid up to $2,389 a year less than those who could speak fluent English.

It is then quite clearly in the interests of both Australia and the individuals concerned for migrants to undertake proficiency training in the English language. English is quite evidently the first language of Australia and I believe that, ultimately, those people who wish to live here and become Australian citizens, with only limited exceptions, should be literate in English-notwithstanding that those intending to migrate to Australia are expected to be literate in some way. That recognises that the points system takes into account the applicant's English skills, but nevertheless there are still a large number of immigrants who do not have those skills. Many of these people come here as part of the family reunion scheme or as the spouses of people who have successfully migrated here. That is not to say that many of these people are not literate in their own language; clearly many of them are. But there can be no doubt that English is needed in order for them to optimise their earning ability in the Australian work force.

However, many people arriving here do not participate in the AMEP because they may not be aware of the importance of English for successful settlement or, for many of them, because the financial realities are such that it is most important to find a job immediately, and in some respects that may preclude them from attending an AMEP. Despite these difficulties and the enormity of the task before us, as the honourable member for Prospect correctly pointed out, the AMEP has been very successful. Approximately 70,500 people participated in the program during 1989-90; 78 per cent of these people had been in Australia for less than five years and approximately 25 per cent of them were currently employed-that is in 1989-while 55 per cent were unemployed and the remainder were not in the work force.

The AMEP national plan for 1990 through 1992 took into account various aspects of the program and included the expansion of child-care facilities, a strategy to promote the AMEP to eligible clients within Australia and before arrival and to inform the general public of the program. A survey of AMEP clients was conducted in order to assess the efficiency, effectiveness and appropriateness of AMEP services.

It appears that the program is much more than just a matter of teaching English to a few new arrivals in unused classrooms at night, which is the common public perception of it. Clearly, its purpose is to provide the best possible vocational opportunities to immigrants and to help them integrate into the Australian lifestyle. It sets the foundation for long term residents who may choose to become Australian citizens. In fact, the citizenship component forms an important part of the program.

In effect, this Bill seeks to grant access to the AMEP to those PRC nationals who were granted a temporary entry permit by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) in June last year. That is really what this debate is all about. I remind the Parliament that the Opposition spokesman, the honourable member for Dundas (Mr Ruddock), who spoke earlier, was critical of the Prime Minister's decision to grant en masse four-year temporary permits to all PRC nationals in Australia at the time of the Tiananmen Square massacre. Consequently, these people were granted access to various Commonwealth-funded services and were allowed to apply for grants of permanent residency under the employer nomination category and to bring to Australia spouses and dependent children.

Having made that decision-I emphasise once again that the Opposition did not support it in the way it was put into effect-it would in our view nevertheless be quite unfair not to let these people work to support themselves and not to allow them access to adult migrant English language and associated courses. To this effect, as was clearly spelt out by my colleague earlier, we support the Bill before the House.

However, a number of important concerns about the Bill need to be emphasised further. Firstly, we need to recognise that although the Government claims that there are no additional costs involved as additional eligibility will be met within existing appropriations, the conclusion must be that for every PRC national or spouse or families who participate in AMEP there will be one less space for those people who have migrated to Australia and who have received permanent entry status.

It is true that a great many Chinese nationals will not require the AMEP as they have already studied English language intensive courses for overseas students. After all, that is what they were; they were here as students. However, it is estimated that, notwithstanding those who do not need AMEP, there will be around 3,000 people who will be eligible. We have to add to those a significant number-around 5,000-of adult dependants who will also require the AMEP. This must surely be a point of concern, especially when one considers the figures I quoted earlier about the cost to the nation of having new Australians with poor English capabilities in the work force.

While many of the original PRC nationals may have applied for permanent residency, the fact remains-and I am not sure that the Government has made it entirely clear, and if it has not it ought to-that the majority of these people will have to return to China in about three years. I believe that the Government has brought about a huge problem for itself in creating this special status for PRC nationals, notwithstanding the human rights issues involved, and the honourable member for Dundas made very clear our sympathy in respect of that issue. No-one is advocating-certainly not the Opposition-that they should have been sent back to China immediately.

There is no doubt in the minds of Opposition members that the Government should have taken a much more thoroughly considered decision than it did. The coalition argued at the time that a case by case consideration was the only proper way to establish adequately who had valid claims to remain in Australia under existing non-discriminatory criteria. It appears that in applying for permanent residency these people will now finally be considered in this fashion. That is the correct way to go, but they are entitled to stay here until 1994, even if their applications for residency are rejected.

I remind the Parliament of the cost of this to the community. As I think the honourable member for Dundas pointed out, there are significant costs not only in the English training programs-we have already recognised that the Government has not allocated any more money, so there will not be any more effective or recognisable costs in that-but also in jobs that may otherwise have gone to Australian citizens and permanent residents and in the access the students and their dependants have now been given to the social welfare system, and so on. Those things may well add up to a significant cost to the Australian people.

I think it needs to be made perfectly clear-and I know the Opposition spokesman has made it perfectly clear to these people-that those people whose applications for permanent residency have been rejected will have to leave Australia in 1994. We should not equivocate on this because there is a suggestion in all of this that somehow we are seeing the thin edge of the wedge in terms of these people. There is a distinct possibility that they may be being misled and, come 1994, they will see themselves as having some special claim to stay here.

I believe it needs to be made abundantly clear to them that if they do not qualify for permanent residence they will be leaving-and that might mean many thousands of them. I suppose it will be a problem for the coalition, being in government in 1994, to send them back. But we will face up to that responsibility and we will go through the correct processes when the time comes.

This Bill, which gives access to one more government-funded program, should not be seen as the thin edge of the wedge. There is no implication, in our view, that these people will be allowed to stay on after their four years are up. As I said, when in government the coalition will take appropriate action depending on and taking account of, I hasten to add-knowing that the honourable member for Reid (Mr Ferguson) is following me in this debate and knowing of his compassion- the circumstances that exist in China at that time.

I believe it would be preferable for those who will be returning to China not to participate in the citizenship component of the program. As I said earlier, there is a citizenship component and, in a sense, when we looked at the legislation we thought it might be desirable if these people were excluded from that component of the program. Obviously, for practical reasons that was not possible. In our view the fact that they are exposed to that aspect of the program may imply to them in some way that they are being prepared for citizenship, for which of course they may never qualify.

In short, the AMEP is not geared towards people who are only in Australia temporarily. The honourable member for Prospect spoke about the fact that the AMEP had been in place for all those years. But it was not geared for temporary residents; it was never intended for them. It is designed, in effect, to ensure the future security of new Australians, and to provide a service that will benefit not only the nation, but of course the individuals themselves.

Even with this in mind, the coalition is of the opinion that those PRC nationals who will be here for four years cannot be denied the right to learn English and secure employment. We take the view that the Prime Minister's decision in the first instance to grant temporary resident status to all PRC nationals, and his subsequent announcement in June of last year to enable spouses to join those in Australia and granting access to government services for this group, was fundamentally the wrong decision. It was not thought through clearly. As my colleague pointed out, there was a conflict at the time between what Senator Robert Ray was saying and what the Prime Minister subsequently announced on television to Jana Wendt, apparently without consultation with any of his colleagues, and certainly with no reference to Parliament.

We take the position that that was fundamentally the wrong way to go about doing things. It was not thought through clearly. Whilst we were all moved-I am sure each of us was moved by the scenes we saw occurring in China at that time-the decision that the Prime Minister took was not a rational decision. It was not a decision that measured both the interests, ultimately, of those Chinese nationals and the interests of the Australian people at large.

Having made the decision that it did, the Government now has a responsibility for those people. The bottom line, the real point of this legislation, of course is indicative of the Government realising the extent of that responsibility. My advice-gratuitous though it might be, and coming from a fairly new backbencher-to the Prime Minister is that in the future he might consider more carefully any selective decisions he makes on human rights issues and immigration regulations. I could perhaps advise him to be less emotional and more objective in these matters, and remind him further that his first responsibility is to Australian citizens, to those who are permanent residents pending citizenship, and to those who are seeking to migrate here who have done the right thing by joining the appropriate queue. There are plenty of people waiting in line who would certainly question the way in which this matter has been handled.

Mr Deputy Speaker, I believe that the vast majority of Australians-particularly ethnic Australians-are very unhappy with the way that the Government has handled this matter. Having said that, as I indicated earlier, the Opposition supports this legislation for the reason that we really now see it as being the correct thing to do for these people and for others who may well find themselves in the same situation. It would be rather churlish of us now to oppose this legislation on the grounds that it was compounding a wrong.

As I said earlier, this legislation in a sense really adds fuel to a fire that the Government lit for itself. It is now in a position of having all these people here and recognising that it has a responsibility to them. It is for those reasons the Opposition now sees-and it is certainly a pragmatic point of view-that it is a piece of legislation that should be supported.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ferguson Mr L.D.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, in speaking on this Immigration (Education) Amendment Bill, I would note its particular relevance to the electorate that I represent. Of the 158 electorates in Australia, my electorate has the thirteenth highest number of overseas born, or the children of overseas born. It is seventeenth when considering those people who were both born overseas and who have resided here for less than five years. There is the reality of a number of migrant hostels from the early postwar years in Merrylands and Birrong, for instance, which saw eastern European migration, both from the Baltic States and the Ukraine. Of course, in more recent times there is the Villawood Hostel. So the electorate of Reid is at the coalface of these programs. Equally, the children of these residents are in schools such as Old Guildford, which has special English programs because of the high number of overseas born students. It is crucial that the adult migrant education program (AMEP) be effective.

SPEECH.PARA: In looking at the issue at hand, I indicate my appreciation of the efforts made. The honourable member for Dundas (Mr Ruddock) has cited figures in regard to a failure of delivery to a significant number of Australian migrants. I have not read the particular report. He did not cite the pages, but I hope later on he elaborates on the characteristics of those people to whom services were not delivered. As was noted earlier by other speakers, this service was not created yesterday morning; it has existed since the late 1940s, and it has to be seen in the context of a fairly massive increase in funding, nearly doubling in the period since 1984. So if there have been some failures in that system, perhaps they did not happen since the election of the Hawke Government; perhaps they were partially the responsibility of previous governments. I think we should bear that in mind.

I know of the paper the honourable member for Dundas referred to, but not having read it I do not know whether it included a survey of the reasons for a particular non-delivery to any group of individuals. I do not know whether assessments were made of their particular interests in taking those courses, et cetera.

As I said, I want to put on the record, in the context of some criticisms, my appreciation of the service. With the current Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs (Mr Hand)-and also on an individual basis-I had the opportunity to go to the Westbridge Hostel to see the teachers there in operation. It is somewhat dubious to criticise the system in the context of what I saw. I have rarely seen any work group in Australia have such a feeling of value in what they are doing. They have a sense of working to a goal to which they have a very deep personal commitment. I have witnessed that at that Westbridge Hostel.

If there are failures, I can say it is certainly not for lack of effort. The degree to which people go outside their normal working hours, the degree to which they have developed resource papers off their own bat, the degree of in-service that occurs both locally and on a professionally centralised basis is fairly impressive to me. As I said earlier, there is a high degree of motivation amongst the employees there. There is a great degree of participation by them on a local scale in the programs and, as I said, in amending booklets to meet particular needs.

It is not just a matter of equipping people to go and work in a particular job; teaching is obviously a very broad task which involves dealing with varying levels of education and indeed covers a wide variety of language abilities. Significant numbers of these migrant people are illiterate in their own tongue. Many of them are traumatised by the very violent political situations that they have come from. I have had that personal experience at the Westbridge hostel. This is the kind of reality that teaching staff face. As I said, when we consider the age disparities, the range of English abilities, the slow and advanced learners, the illiteracies and diverse previous education levels of migrants, we see that the teachers face a massive task.

When we talk about AMEP, perhaps it is worth remembering that a large part of the problem that has arisen with the Chinese students does stem from one of the less well thought out penchants for privatisation of education in this country in the English language intensive courses for overseas students (ELICOS) system. That system was utilised to try to destroy the migration rules of this country. In that context there must be some concern at the push for privatisation of AMEP in 1989-90.

Turning to the specifics of the issue at hand, I personally have a lot of sympathy for the Opposition's position of demanding that there should have been individual assessment of the Chinese students at the initial stage. Quite clearly, if we are to have some integrity in the system, if refugee status is to mean something, if standards of endangerment to people are to be considered, then it is very difficult to put all that in the same circle as a wholesale allowance of a particular group.

As has been noted by previous speakers, the honourable member for McPherson (Mr Bradford), the decision to privatise the ELICOS program has been made and we are faced with a very large number of people in Australia seeking employment, et cetera, and operating within our society and not lacking English because of this privatisation effort in regard to ELICOS. As I said, ELICOS was widely used as a subterfuge to avoid our migration policy and was contrived by significant numbers of private school owners whose interest was more financially than scholastically motivated. We have to be realistic with regard to that process in time. We are talking about a fairly extraordinary situation and a fairly unusual proportion of people in that category. That category did consist of a significant number of migrant people who were perhaps more articulate than other groups temporarily resident in this country. It was a group that, it would be fairly logical to say, might be more politically motivated, more involved in issues and therefore perhaps more inclined to be persecuted subsequently.

While we say that it is wrong to give special rights to this group, some circumstances were abnormal. We have to be realistic about the politics of the situation. There are already significant complaints from the Opposition about the staffing failures in the Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs and the waiting times. What really would have been the reality if we went down and assessed each individual? As we well know with migration, there would have been constant attempts to undermine the system, distort it, fabricate situations and invent levels of political activity and possible harassment. That would not have been a process that would have been quickly overcome; it would have dragged on for some time and diverted resources from departmental requirements. Those departmental requirements often involve looking at overcoming other attempts to distort and cheat the system and to jump in front of other people who are doing the right thing by adhering to our processes by filling forms out overseas. There might be concerns that some people should not have been allowed into Australia because they did not have genuine political activity and did not face harassment. In fact, it is said that a significant number of them, because they had the money required to do these ELICOS courses, actually come from the elite of the Chinese communist party system.

As I say, at the same time the resources required and the major backlog we already have with regard to processing a variety of other refugee status people from the Middle East, Sri Lanka and a number of other countries would have meant a significant waiting time for those who do the right thing which should not have been tolerated.

The original position of the Opposition was that it was all very sad because these refugees were queue jumping and given special provisions. As I said, I can see the logic of that position and I have some sympathy with it, but at the same time what we are also getting is the politically self-interested emphasis on the unspecified number of individuals who are deprived of rights under this situation. I am talking about those people who were so greatly threatened, who could have migrated here under our current rules but were not given an opportunity, who were bludgeoned into not applying for other forms of residence, were relegated into a sub-category, blackmailed and not given a fair deal. This emphasis on those individuals is an attempt to cultivate some support in those areas for political self-interest. Whilst there might have been a fairly insignificant number of those people, that is more than balanced by the other side of the coin in this decision.

Quite frankly, one point that I, if not the Government, would like to emphasise is the need for people to actually apply overseas to migrate so that we reduce, as the current Minister has attempted to, the number of people who seek to change status while in this country for reasons such as a sudden illness in the family, contrived marriages, et cetera. If those people have genuine fundamental rights to be part of our migration program, then perhaps we can see about that in 1993. Perhaps they can go back and apply from China just as people are lining up in Ankara to travel to Damascus and a number of other countries around the world to seek to become part of our programs. I do not think that there is really that much great hardship for the small unspecified minority who have been mentioned. We also have this new-found concern with the brain drain of these overseas students who, as the Opposition has correctly described previously, are in Australia predominantly under subterfuge to migrate anyway.

It is a bit hypocritical for the Opposition to talk about the Government's decision to reinstitute relations with China. There were not too many doubters in the Opposition when some of its members decided that they had better rush over to China and establish trade contacts, have deputations there and try to move things along a bit quicker than the Government was doing. To come now and say that they have a lingering interest in the rights of those people in China is perhaps questionable.

I would again like to stress the efforts of the service. As indicated by previous speakers, despite some denigration, we are talking about a fairly major service unparalleled in the world in its size and endeavour. We are talking about a service that aided 70,500 people last year, a group that is predominantly lacking the language, is predominantly unskilled, and predominantly very lowly educated.

There must be some concern that all of this might be destroyed by people with an ideological bent who are not willing to analyse the reality of the situation-that is, the reality of moving towards privatisation of the scheme, a privatisation that would not guarantee local availability and that would not specify the access that currently exists in regard to child-care. The honourable member for Dundas has talked about people who are denied equity of access. Certainly, it will be a lot worse if there is any attempt to bring another scheme following the ELICOS pattern into this sector as well.

We have a situation where any change or attempt to further turn this area over to the private sector-an attempt so failed through ELICOS-would involve a diminution of the network of information that currently exists; of the networking between various sites; and of the high standards of teacher accreditation, which no-one opposite could dispute; and would not cater for the particularities of this group and the different levels of requirements.

In conclusion, I would like to reiterate some doubts about the original decision. We have to attempt to have some integrity in the system. Every person who is allowed into Australia causes some general public concern about the system. It creates the groundwork for community opposition and hostility to migration in general. It is unfair to those people who have legitimate claims to humanitarian access to this country. For those reasons there must be some doubts about the original decision.

In 1991, the facts are that these people will be here for four years; that they do need access to the system; and that they are part of the Australian community whether it be for four years or longer. To deny them this access and right to better their circumstances obviously undermines general society. I support the Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Charles Mr R.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are debating the Immigration (Education) Amendment Bill in the House tonight because once again amending legislation is required to fix an Act that was changed by the Government by announcement in the press-that is, the Immigration (Education) Act. It has done it again. The Government is good at that sort of thing-government by press release. I congratulate the Minister for Science and Technology (Mr Crean), who is at the table. I appreciate that he was not involved in this particular debacle. Nevertheless, over and over again the Government legislates by press release.

SPEECH.PARA: The thrust of the Bill that we are debating tonight, excluding a number of minor technical amendments, basically gives right of access to English language courses and citizenship courses to the Chinese nationals who were unable or unwilling to return home after the Tiananmen Square massacre. The open door policy enunciated by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) shortly after Tiananmen Square has given rise to the short-circuiting of usual migration procedures-some would claim it is queue jumping-by the large number of people who originally came to this country to further their education. Now we are being asked to facilitate that group's learning of the English language at public expense. This is most definitely a backdoor, underhanded way of fast tracking migration for a particular group of people.

Surely it would have been more appropriate to investigate and assess each individual case on its merits. After all, that is the way that every other migrant or would be migrant is assessed. I know that for those who come to my electorate office and who are one point short it is no go; they are not permitted to enter Australia. They are not migrants to our country.

One complaint that I have with this particular piece of legislation is the continual reference in the document itself to the word `persons'. We are in the process of so dehumanising and depersonalising the English language that perhaps we should not be teaching English at all. I maintain that English is a rich and vibrant language. It is, as a result of its richness, its comprehension and its ability to convey complex ideas in addition to straightforward statements, coming into more or less universal use.

TALK.START.PARA: —Even with an accent.
