—Even with an accent. `Persons'-my goodness, what on earth are we all about? This Bill is about access to English language courses. I hope that these courses are a little more specific as to include gender. `Person' is such a non-specific term and word that it conjures up pictures of almost inhuman androids or the like who have no real relevance to the subject, which is in fact people. The men and women who came to this country as students on temporary short term visas and who, through the tears of the Prime Minister, have now been allowed to stay for up to four years and perhaps even permanently are individuals. They are people, not persons.

SPEECH.PARA: This Bill is basically a Government housekeeping Bill. It is a Bill that is necessary, I contend, because the Government needs to get its house in order to deal with some 20,000 Chinese nationals who came here to visit for several months and ended up unexpectedly staying several years, perhaps even permanently. The way in which this matter of extended visas and permanent residency has been handled was a mess from start to finish. It would appear that no checking was done as to the validity of claims for student status in order to qualify for the four-year temporary resident permit. Yet here is a government opening the way for temporary residents not only to jump the migration queue but also to shove aside those who did it the right way in order to fasttrack into English language and citizenship courses at the public expense.
While on the subject of citizenship courses, I wish to raise the topic of citizenship. The definition given in the Bill is:
. . . a course of instruction designed to impart an understanding of ways of life in Australia and of the rights and duties of an Australian citizen.

It is a requirement that all migrants pass this course prior to being granted citizenship. That is my understanding. Is that so, Mr Deputy Speaker? Is it a requirement? If not, why is it not? Is it because we are so desperate that we accept all comers without first determining whether they have a real understanding of what it is to be an Australian citizen?

Actually, the definition of citizenship course is most inaccurate. It is not about citizenship duties or prerequisites to become an Australian citizen. Rather, the citizenship course, as provided by the Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs, appears to be an information service on how to make use of government services such as registering for unemployment, Medicare, sickness benefits, the first home owners scheme and other social security benefits.

Migrating to this country is one issue. Learning to speak our language is another. But citizenship is really something quite different, separate and very special, and it is certainly not a step to be undertaken lightly. I am pleased to see that this legislation is opening up English language courses for newcomers to our country, but it should not be at the expense of migrants who have been here for some time and who have been working so hard that they have not had the time to do the courses or perhaps even have not had the knowledge that such courses exist or are available at no cost.

Some 20 per cent of those participating in the adult migration education program have been in Australia more than five years. It is indeed commendable that the Government is expanding the range of people who wing down a report into literacy. I would foreshadow that that report will deal with courses on English as a second language. Everyone in this place should look forward with great expectation to receiving that report.

Recent reports from the Bureau of Immigration Research suggest that problems in English language proficiency among migrants in the work force are costing Australia $763m a year. A study which was released in Canberra on 4 February this year said that about $134m was estimated to be lost in output and occupational health and safety costs because of people who spoke what is termed `poor' English. The report concluded that an overall improvement in English proficiency had the capacity to yield an estimated earnings increase of 6.5 per cent. It would appear that there is a very good case, purely on economic grounds, for migrants to undertake English classes to improve their language capability and consequently their incomes through increased productivity.

The honourable member for Reid (Mr Ferguson) emphasised in his delivery the value of English as a second language and the value of those courses for migrants. He talked to us about his appreciation of the courses and their value to our new citizens and to our country. I have no disagreement with the honourable member for Reid. It is clear that those people who come to this country without English as a first language have great need of English courses and literacy courses in order to be able effectively to participate in our society, to understand our literature, to have access to the legal profession, to have access to government programs and services and to understand our sometimes incomprehensible documentation and our incomprehensible forms, including taxation, social security, Austudy, et cetera.

The honourable member for Reid and I are one in agreeing on this issue. But there are only so many bickies in the barrel. There are only so many dollars and there are only so many people we can afford to train, or else some other program somewhere must suffer. We now have potentially between 20,000 and 40,000 extra people shoved into the system, so somebody suffers. It is either our Chinese students who suffer or it is new migrants from Vietnam, Taiwan, Indonesia-perhaps Jakarta-Germany, Austria or any country where English is not the first language. They are the ones who will suffer.

The honourable member for Reid went on to say it was hypocritical of the Opposition to talk about our interest in human rights in China regarding the refugees. I say to the honourable member for Reid that that is a lot of rot. My goodness, talk about hypocritical! Simply because the Opposition had the audacity to say that the Prime Minister went running off with the tear jerker again, he comes into this place and makes these statements. He has absolutely no idea what he is talking about; it is just something else to carry on with because he did not have enough time to fill up the speech. He did not make it as it was.

It is clear that the Opposition is not hypocritical at all. The Opposition has been clear and straightforward. It has told the Chinese students exactly where it stands with respect to this issue. So that is a lot of nonsense. This Bill is all about giving English language courses and citizenship courses to those Chinese-some 20,000 of them-that the Government said should stay here, or could stay here, because of the Tiananmen Square incident. That is terrific.

On humanitarian grounds and on all humanitarian concerns I support the retention in Australia of those Chinese students who were under threat. But this legislation changes the eligibility for those courses. The financial impact statement in the explanatory memorandum says:

There will be no increase in Commonwealth appropriations as a result of the amendments made to the Act by this Bill. The cost of extending eligibility for the Adult Migrant Education Program to some classes of temporary entry permit holders will be met within the current appropriation.

I question the validity of that statement. Surely it cannot be accurate. It is my understanding this week that English as a second language courses are not only fully subscribed but that migrants under the business migration scheme are really taking up their entitlements to these courses to the maximum.

I would not deny any migrant the right to learn English in our country, but I must admit that I have to question why our business migrants, who have to come up-front with half a million dollars before they are accepted, and who, according to the press this week in Queensland, are dumped on the Gold Coast without any possibility of starting up a business without any assistance from the Department, have come without, it seems from the information that I have, any English as well. We have these great business migrants coming into Australia and we are going to teach them English-maybe-and boy are they taking up that entitlement. But when the hell are they going to start a business? I do not know; perhaps someone here does.

Those in the business migration scheme need in excess of half a million dollars in assets and they have to set up a business within strict guidelines. One would expect that surely they had English before they came here. Is that wrong? I hear a lot of conversation on the other side of the House. Is it wrong to expect that they should have had English before they came here? Evidently not. I believe that their participation in the program is extremely high. The places are full of many migrants who need the program-they really need English as a second language-and are unable now to have access. Perhaps it should be a requirement for citizenship that applicants have a competent standard of English, that they undertake courses and that they are able to pass a test on Australian history, political institutions and the Constitution. I know that such a suggestion will be controversial, but Australian citizenship is highly valued by those swearing allegiance to the Queen. Our nation would be better served by citizens with good English language skills and an understanding of our history and political institutions. That is worth a thought.

This Labor Government has demonstrated an absolute lack of principle in dealing with the students that we are discussing tonight. Back in June of 1989 we all saw our Prime Minister in tears over the dreadful massacre in Tiananmen Square. Then he announced that all Chinese students currently in Australia-about 20,000-would not be forced to return home against their will. Those who arrived after 20 June 1989-about another 20,000-were encouraged to apply to stay here on humanitarian grounds.

What about the thousands of people around the world who were having their applications processed for migration as at June 1989? Were they also offered an extended visitors visa to come and live here for four years-`See if you like it; go home if you do not'? Where is the justice? Following hot on the heels of that fiasco, we had the announcement in July 1990 that these same special visa temporary residents would have access to almost the complete range of taxpayer funded Federal Government services. The Bill that we are debating tonight is being introduced to open up the adult migration education program to the queue jumpers while they are still visitors. To add insult to injury, in the same week that we are debating this amending legislation, the Government has decided to lift all remaining economic and political sanctions on China.

TALK.START.PARA: —You wanted it done earlier.

—We also would have treated the students differently. Being from Victoria, one would have to ask: is this so that Premier Kirner can finally sell off the bankrupt Victorian State Government's share in the Portland smelter to pay for the redundancy packages for the current State Labor members of parliament. It is a reasonable question, is it not? Many of them will be redundant, will they not?
—Too many of them; you could not pay them off.

—They are good at these redundancy packages, are they not? The honourable member for Reid knows all about that. We know that there have been discussions regarding such a sale under the previous guidelines of limited contract. Whilst supporting this legislation, we decry the actions of the Government as being totally inconsistent and not beneficial to anyone with respect to this whole issue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hand The Hon G.L.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

TALKER.NAME: Mr HAND
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-First, I want to thank those honourable members who took part in the debate, although a number of speakers paid little heed to the substance of the Immigration (Education) Amendment Bill and expressed a wide range of views, which I would be happy to debate at a more appropriate time. However, I will address some of the more outrageous comments made by honourable members. Even though this is a small Bill, with precise sets of words in it, one would have thought that honourable members opposite would have been able to grapple with it, but it seems that not many of them have read it. They have attributed to this Bill a whole range of issues which I can assure them are not reflected in the legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: The point to remember is that people who will now become eligible must hold a temporary entry permit of a class specified by the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs by notice published in the Commonwealth of Australia Gazette. That is the key phrase. The shadow Minister for immigration and ethnic affairs, the honourable member for Dundas (Mr Ruddock), has returned to the chamber and that is good to see. I listened to his earlier comments, and I will refer to some of them in a moment.

The previous speaker, the honourable member for La Trobe (Mr Charles), and a number of others, spoke about the financial impact and, of course, in the explanatory notes it talks about the current appropriation. It does not say, for argument's sake, that in the future funds will never be made available to pick up the increased demand which may flow out of the eligibility being provided for these people. There may be a range of people eligible for this, some of whom could be groups that the Joint Standing Committee on Migration Regulations-of which the shadow Minister is a member-made recommendations to me about concerning arrangements for married folk, de factos, et cetera. Spouses could become eligible for something like this. People who are granted refugee status under the new arrangements will now become eligible because of this particular Bill. The Bill was a fulfilment of the promise made by me by way of an announcement in the press last year. I draw the attention of honourable members to the following paragraph on the second page:
Access to the adult migrant education program would be given to all except those who had studied under English Language Intensive Courses for Overseas Students (ELICOS) programs.
One assumes that they have gained English through that course. That was announced last year.

The honourable member does not read his correspondence; that is the trouble. He comes in here and mouths off and, of course, he is not fully across the topic. A few cheap shots and away he goes, sending out the speech to the electorate. Some people in his electorate will be very interested to read his comments, I am sure, and we will probably all hear from them. A number of things were said about the People's Republic of China (PRC) students who were here on 20 June and those who came afterwards. Clearly, they are two quite distinct groups. That decision was made, contrary to the views expressed by the shadow Minister, after a lot of thought, weighing up a range of issues at the time which we are still prepared to stand by.

I mentioned the fact that there are two groups, the first being those who were here prior to the cut-off date of 20 June. Clearly, one would have to say that most people in Australia at the time of Tiananmen Square and around that time-and I have said this before-really had to fight to get on a platform at any of the meetings held in the capital cities. It is a bit of a cheap shot to have a bit of a ping at the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) when one could have gone to any number of meetings around Australia where people displayed their emotions in a range of ways.

It would also be fair to say that the community generally, and I include the media, would have left these people in no doubt as to what protection we were going to provide. At the meeting that I spoke at in the Melbourne Town Hall, all political parties were there, business leaders were there and trade union leaders were there, and all called for the protection of these people. It is all very well, as I said, to come in here and make these claims, but I put it to the honourable member that this was a decision based clearly on the needs of these people, then and still now. We do not back away from that decision at all.

I am sure that they will be interested to know that the shadow Minister talked about uncertainty. My God, when they read his speech they will become very uncertain as to their future-and no doubt they will read his speech. I think he has contributed most unfairly to this debate by making that threat about what will happen to them in the event of a change of government and his becoming a Minister, which is not likely to happen, thank God-and the Chinese people would be most grateful for that.

TALK.START.PARA: —What was the Government proposing, Minister?

—We have given certain undertakings to the pre-20 June people which the shadow Minister is well aware of and has commented on. The post-20 June group is quite different. They came here after the incident in the Square and everybody knows that they left China with the permission of the Chinese Government at a time which was very tense for China. That is a quite different situation. There is quite clearly a difference in the situations of the two groups. That, I am sure, is known to both this side of the House and the Opposition side.
—It was clear from my address.
—It was not clear from the address at all.
—You said it was.

—I do not think it was clear. I am making the point as I think some people would be confused. There is a thing called a radio, and there is a thing called a television. Unfortunately, I was at a meeting but I did come out to hear the shadow Minister because I always like to listen to him-he knows that. I never miss him and I caught every word.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member also talked about a range of other things. It is extraordinary that he said that he would go around Australia telling people that funding shortages or the lack of a service being provided in their region was caused by these PRC people. That is a very unfair thing to be saying to people. I hope that he does not say it, and I really do not think he will because I know him better, but he did say it here. I think it is most regrettable that he would use people in that way. We go again to the current appropriation.

TALK.START.PARA: —That's right.

—That is right, but the honourable member has implied that for time immemorial any shortfall in the system will be the fault of these people, and that is what he will tell people. That is singling out a group of people who are unable to defend themselves, and the honourable member will exploit them amongst other people in the community. I say shame on him for that.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member also referred to the working party on post-secondary English language training. It is clear that he has not read the report. That working party served a valuable purpose by examining the situation and producing a report that has been widely circulated in the community and on which the community has been invited to comment. The report gives the users of the program a unique opportunity to comment to the two Ministers involved, namely, the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Dawkins) and me, and I think that is a very solid approach. But the honourable member has in some way denigrated the report when, on any view of it, it could be claimed that it is not a bad report.

TALK.START.PARA: —I used it as a source; I didn't denigrate it.
—We are criticised on the one hand for producing the report and circulating it amongst the community, and then he says, `I used the report as a source'.
— It is a great document.

—It is a good document, and it is good to see that the honourable member is using sections of it. So do not worry about this language training program. The Government recognised that the program needed examination; that has been done. It will have to be discussed by the Government in the not too distant future, and it will be. The Government is also giving the users of the program access to that process, which is something the Opposition did not do much of when it was in power. On that point, it is interesting to note that in the 1983 Budget $36m was allocated; last year $92m was allocated. This is the Government that the Opposition claims is not really interested in the program.
—How much is inflation?
—The problem with the honourable member for La Trobe is that he talks too much. If he tones it down he might learn a bit tonight and be able to go back to his electorate.
—This is the pot calling the kettle black.

—The last thing I need is the old timer, the honourable member for Cook coming in here and lecturing me. He should just be quiet and settle down. The honourable member may get too excited, and I get worried about him when he gets excited. So be quiet. This program services a large number of people in a large number of institutions around Australia. The Government recognises that more money is always needed for programs. I would very much like to be able to meet every demand that comes forward. The matter is being taken very seriously by the Government, and the report that has been prepared is an example of how serious the Government is about this matter.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member for Dundas referred to the Cambodian situation and implied that these people somehow were being disadvantaged. There is no group of people claiming to be refugees anywhere in the world who have been given more access to the processes than have the people who arrived on our shores. The first boatload of people are now housed in Sydney-26 people, 17 cases. This group made application and their assessments had been completed. However, the people who were advising them sought an undertaking from the Government that these submissions could be re-examined by the Legal Aid Commission of New South Wales. Rather than face the prospect of there being any hint that people who had come here seeking refugee status were being denied their rights, I readily agreed to that-quite properly, I think. I was approached by representatives of the churches and other organisations with a request that the Legal Aid Commission review the applications just to ensure that all steps had been taken. That is now occurring.

It takes an extraordinary amount of time to do the work involved in these cases, as the shadow Minister and others know. The interpreting problems, et cetera, that emerge will take time. These cases will be presented by 5 April this year. At this point none of the cases have been lodged.

In the case of boat two, 123 people are in this group. There are 86 cases. Again, the work on applications is being done with a lot of community involvement. Again, the Government made sure that every single opportunity was given to these people to present their cases in the most detailed way. We are really talking about life. That has to be understood. That is why we have taken every precaution to ensure that people get proper access. This work has been done by the Refugee Advice Casework Service in Melbourne. To date, there are submissions covering 14 cases. As I said, there are 123 people and 86 cases. There will be five cases per week coming in between February and June.

The third group comprises 79 people, who are in Darwin, and 55 cases. Honourable members will recall that we had these people housed in tents. I was seeking accommodation for them in other parts of the country. I met with an almighty coalition of forces in Darwin-the Catholic church, the Anglican church, the trade union movement, the business sector and the Northern Territory Government-who said that they should be allowed to remain in the Northern Territory. Again, we complied with that community wish. I think that some 25 lawyers in the Northern Territory came forward offering to carry out the work, which is-I repeat-very extensive in terms of people presenting their applications. I am advised by the lawyers that all applications from this group will be completed by 31 March.

In the last couple of days two other boats have arrived here, their occupants seeking refugee status. There were 33 people on board the first boat. They are currently in Darwin, as is the second group of 35. It is premature for me to inform the House as to where these people come from. At this point they are claiming certain things. That is currently being investigated by the departmental officers dealing through interpreters. I raise that because it was implied that the Government was not approaching in a proper way the Cambodians and other people who have recently arrived. The world is changing quite dramatically in terms of the people arriving on our shores and in other countries. We here have certain obligations under international law to ensure that people get full access to our law and to what is able to happen under our law. That is why we are taking all this care to ensure that people are given access to their entitlements in relation to these applications.

I conclude by saying that the Bill, whilst minor, generated a fairly wide debate. I have taken on board the comments made by honourable members on both sides of the House. I recognise that there is an increasing demand for the programs. Honourable members, when they go back to their electorates, can assure their constituents that I will be striving to take up the challenge to increase the services provided. I commend the interest shown by honourable members on both sides in what is a really worthwhile program for people to have access to. As a previous speaker said, this is important for people; in a country such as this their whole life can be affected by whether or not they have access to English. I could not agree more. We are striving to do that.

The Immigration (Education) Amendment Bill does provide access for people, but, I repeat, people who will be given access by gazettal, by their entitlement being gazetted. Some of the wider comments that have been made, such as those referring to the court case et cetera, I cannot address, but I would like to and will in the future.
Debate interrupted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ruddock Mr P.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I intend to make certain brief comments, if I may, because I am conscious that I am eating into the time of my colleagues and believe that that time should be devoted to the adjournment. I thank the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs (Mr Hand) for outlining the situation in relation to the Khmer Rouge. But let me make it very clear: at no stage did I imply that they were today being treated in an improper way.
—I was the Minister, and I am telling you they have never been badly treated under me. I resent the accusation.

—At no time did I imply that they were being treated in an improper way, nor did I make any allegations about the way in which the Minister has handled this matter. But I do not resile from the comments that I made about what the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) said on the Jana Wendt program, A Current Affair, where, very clearly, he rejudged the issue. They were comments that he later had to retract. That is all I adverted to.

SPEECH.PARA: I thank the Minister for his comments tonight because they were important in clarifying the situation. But I do want to make this further point: the time that it is taking to make decisions in relation to the Khmer is, in my view, sending a wrong impression about the prospects of resettlement in Australia to those people overseas who may be contemplating making a very dangerous journey by sea. It is not a matter upon which there ought to be delay, and that is a point I have made elsewhere and will continue to make.

TALK.START.PARA: —You obviously didn't understand the processes.

—I understand the processes and I understand that we do not yet have fully in place the committees to enable proper determinations to be made. But that again is a matter that is in the Minister's hands because it goes to the resources that are available for that process.

SPEECH.PARA: The second point that the Minister did not deal with, which I simply want to point out very clearly, is the long term situation in relation to People's Republic of China (PRC) nationals pre-Tiananmen Square. I understand the distinctions very clearly in relation to the PRC students and PRC nationals in this country. The situation is that they have temporary residency only. If the Government intends permanency, it is a decision it could make today. If the Minister intends permanency, he could make that decision now. I do not believe that he wants to. Having regard to Senator Evans's comments about the situation in China, that is a matter that for those people needs to be clarified.

The Minister can leave those people in limbo and make comments about what I have said. I do not resile from what I have said one iota. What I have said all along is that a case-by-case determination is the proper route to take. Those people who were here who may have had greater claims because they were pre-Tiananmen Square would have had that considered by those who considered each individual case-and that was the proper way to go. Again, we would not send anybody back who had a proper continuing claim for protection. But those who have no claim, in our view, have no entitlement, unless they meet the same criteria for permanency as any other applicant is able to satisfy.

The only other matter that I want to deal with briefly-it is the only other point of contention-relates to appropriations. I know that governments like to keep appropriations and budgets in their own hands. But the fact is that as much as the Minister may seek to provide additional funds, in a Budget context next year fewer funds could be provided. That is what could happen. Simply to say that there may be the possibility in a new Budget context that there will be more funds ignores the obverse, which is equally clear, that there could be fewer funds. That happens in a Budget. The Minister knows more about the workings of finance than I do. The point is that the explanatory memorandum states:
There will be no increase in Commonwealth appropriations-
plural-
as a result of the amendments made to the Act by this Bill.

The financial impact statement made by the Minister in the explanatory memorandum tells us that there will be no increase in Commonwealth appropriations as a result of amendments made to the Act by this Bill. If the Minister is suggesting that there will be additional appropriations in some forthcoming Budget--

TALK.START.PARA: —I never said that.

—If that is what the Minister is suggesting, he should make that clear. Otherwise, the situation is as I have put it: for every place that is found for somebody who is here temporarily, somebody in a program which at the moment, by the Minister's own evidence, is short funded finds a place at the expense of a long term settler. That is the case. Unless additional resources are found, what I have said is true, and demonstrably true.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hand The Hon G.L.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

TALKER.NAME: Mr HAND
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I shall address only the question of the Cambodians because I know that people want to speak in the adjournment debate. Let us be perfectly clear about the process here. These people have come. In some instances their applications have been done twice. Why have they been done twice? Because their advisers were not confident that they were done properly the first time. That is why they are taking so long. I would have thought that the honourable member for Dundas (Mr Ruddock) would understand--
—I understand that.

—Fourteen have just been lodged-none in some instances and, in the other case, I read them out. I will do it again for the honourable member so that he can grasp what I am saying. He is trying to portray that this is our fault. It is our fault all right in terms of giving people every access to their rights. I do not run away from that. As I said, none of the Sydney group is in yet because they are all with the Legal Aid Commission in New South Wales, an organisation probably controlled by people who are closer to the honourable member politically than to me.
—Not at all. It is a jointly funded operation.

—But still, it is the New South Wales Legal Aid Commission. I would have thought it is a pretty reputable group and it is taking its time and doing the job properly, with our best wishes. I do not want somebody claiming that Australia did not do the right thing by people and give them the opportunities. That is the point.

SPEECH.PARA: There are 14 cases before us in the second group. There is none from Darwin. We have had 25-odd lawyers in Darwin working on these cases in a voluntary capacity. They insisted on doing the work. They were supported by a community organisation up there which just about covered the whole of Darwin society. We have let them do that work. But they have found that it is a very long process.

TALK.START.PARA: —So what I said was true; there were 14 cases which are capable of being determined.
—There are 14 cases which are with us and others that are coming in at the rate of five a week.
—That is all I said.

—No, the honourable member did not. He has inferred over and over again, in the way that he always does, that there is something wrong with the process. There is nothing wrong with a process which seeks to be fair to people. That is what we have striven to do. I just say that I thought the honourable member's original comments were wrong in the inferences that he made. For the record, I doubt that any other process for assessing refugees anywhere in the world is as fair as what is being applied here.

SPEECH.PARA: It is not my fault, brother, that we have taken up the honourable member's time. He raised the matter; I did not. So I will talk. Above all, he should understand. For the record, I appreciate his comment about us taking a long time. Let us understand why it is taking a long time. The worst thing that could have happened would have been to force things on people; to rush them through a process. The honourable member for Dundas knows and I know that some people from the legal profession went public and said that if that were done they would take us to court.

I was going to make sure that every opportunity was given to people, which I think was the correct way to proceed. That is the point I am making. There is a right way and a wrong way and this Cambodian group, and the other group that arrived yesterday, will be given the same sort of access to the process. I am happy to talk to the honourable member for Dundas and the Opposition at any time about any way they may suggest could assist in the process. I would welcome their ideas; that is what this place is supposed to be all about. I have made that offer before. If they have any suggestion as to how we can protect the rights of people to the fullest and speed the process of getting that information together, getting it lodged, so that there is no interference with their rights, I would welcome that input. I say that to both sides of the chamber.

It is taking a long time but there are very genuine reasons for it. There are people watching our process, as the honourable member correctly said. But we are governed by certain laws here and certain rights that people have-access to the law, et cetera-which makes me want to leave no stone unturned in terms of seeing that people have access to the fullest opportunity to present their cases. That is what I will continue to do.
Bill agreed to.
Bill reported without amendment; report adopted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Burr Mr M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday in Question Time the Treasurer (Mr Keating) misrepresented me in statements that he made, inferring that I had made disparaging remarks about the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson). Some five hours after the Treasurer had misrepresented me I was permitted in this House to make a personal explanation. In making that personal explanation I was severely limited in what I could say in my defence. Tonight I want to elaborate further on that personal explanation.

SPEECH.PARA: The Treasurer sought to draw conclusions from an interview that I had made on Australian Broadcasting Corporation radio with ABC interviewer Judy Tierney. That interview was conducted on 26 February 1991 in Hobart. For the information of the House, I wish to quote at greater length from that interview. I quote directly from the transcript that has been provided to me by the Parliamentary Library in Hobart:
JUDY TIERNEY How do you think the Federal Libs are going at the moment Max?

MAX BURR Well the Liberal Party is performing very well, particularly under Dr Hewson. I think Dr Hewson, he is engendering a confidence, a hope that perhaps he might be able to lead the country into a better state of economic resurgence than what it is at the moment. I think that the present Labor Government has simply run out of steam, it has run out of ideas and clearly it's become lethargic as a government, so that the country is looking for a change in government, now Dr Hewson himself I think is at this stage stimulating a confidence in a hope for the future, but it hasn't been there for some considerable time . . .

If the Treasurer had had the honesty to read in full the comments that I made in the radio interview he would have given a totally different impression to this House than he tried to give. What amazes me is why the Treasurer of this country would seek to draw on a rather obscure interview by a humble backbencher to justify his claims here that there are some divisions among members on this side of the House.

TALK.START.PARA: —He is desperate.

—I think it indicates the stage of desperation that the Treasurer has reached in his political career. I put it to the House that it is not I who ought to defend my position but the Treasurer who ought to defend himself because he has reached the stage of arrogance and egotism at which he is not prepared to admit that he has run out of ideas. He is prepared to hold onto his position for the sake of his own ego and to the detriment of this country and every person living in it. The Opposition has continually called for the resignation or the sacking of the Treasurer but, because he will not resign, because the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) will not sack him, he comes into this House and tries to use every obscure reason to create divisions in the Opposition.

SPEECH.PARA: The problem is not with me and it is not in my support of the Leader of the Opposition. It is with the Treasurer and his incapacity to fulfil his portfolio role. I put it to the House that the Treasurer ought to come in here and give the House a full explanation of his handling of the Treasury portfolio. He ought to produce a blueprint that he believes should be followed by this country for its economic resurgence rather than try to stimulate some divisions on the Opposition side.

I remind the House that it is not the Opposition that is the Government of this country; it is those honourable members on the Treasury bench. They will not stimulate confidence in this country by trying to gain cheap political points. What we want and what the country wants is a blueprint for the economic recovery of this country. I believe very firmly that it is only Dr Hewson and the Liberal Party that will give the lead that this country desperately needs.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hulls Mr R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The recent floods in the Gulf region of my electorate have created untold stress and hardship for my constituents.
—Mr Deputy Speaker, I raise a serious point of order in that we do not have a Minister in the chamber.
—There is no point of order.
—Mr Deputy Speaker, we have a Parliamentary Secretary. Under what authority does a Parliamentary Secretary assume the position of a Minister?
—I ask the honourable member to resume his seat. It is a spurious point of order.
—No it is not, Mr Deputy Speaker. I require an answer. Under what authority does a Parliamentary Secretary have charge of the adjournment?
—The matter before the House can proceed under the current arrangements.
—Under what power?
—I have given my answer. The honourable member asked for an answer. I call the honourable member for Kennedy.
—Order! The honourable member for Gippsland.
—Thank you, Mr Deputy Speaker.
—Are you still here? We had condolences for you.
—I warn the honourable member for Gippsland.
—What about--
—I warn the honourable member for Gippsland.

—Mr Deputy Speaker, as I said, the recent floods in the Gulf region of my electorate have created for my constituents untold stress and hardship which have been exacerbated for some by the disgraceful actions of a certain insurance company. This company has given new meaning to the term, `Kick them while they are down'.

SPEECH.PARA: The rain began in the Gulf of Carpentaria in early January and it is only in the past week or so that it has begun to ease. The communities of Normanton, Karumba, Burketown, Doomadgee and Mornington Island have been isolated for almost two months. As a result, the normal supply routes to these communities have been cut leaving the residents largely reliant on emergency supplies flown in by the State Emergency Service. The SES is to be commended on the service it has provided to these communities, but its job has been made more difficult by the lack of all-weather airstrips in the region. For example, the Mornington Island airstrip has been closed 14 times in the last two months.

By mid-January there was a serious shortage of food and supplies available. I visited Normanton and Mornington Island about this time and the shelves in the supermarket were devoid of any fresh produce and milk, and supplies of other basic items such as sugar, flour and toilet paper were extremely low. In an attempt to relieve the situation the Mornington Island Shire Council, in conjunction with the local SES coordinator, organised for a sea barge to carry emergency supplies from Cairns to Karumba.

The 30-metre flat bottomed barge, The Tasma, left Cairns on 22 January on the long voyage around Cape York and down to Karumba. However, the weather gods were determined to continue wreaking havoc. The barge overturned in heavy seas off Weipa. Thankfully, the four crew on board were rescued, but the entire cargo was lost. This was certainly a serious blow to the Gulf residents because their supplies and their morale were now at a critically low level.

However, worse was to come for some local traders who had many thousands of dollars worth of goods now at the bottom of the ocean. They found, to their horror, that their insurance companies were unlikely to accept liability for the losses, because the goods were not insured for marine transport. While one can say that these traders should have checked with their insurance companies first, it needs to be remembered that this was all arranged under emergency conditions and that transit by sea was the only option available.

There were some who did check their insurance policy and were relieved to note that the class of risk listed was `marine cargo'. I have a copy of one such policy in front of me. However, with certain insurance companies, nothing is as it seems and in this case `marine' has no nautical meaning at all.

On behalf of one of my constituents, I have been dealing with one of the insurance companies in question, namely Lumley General Insurance Ltd of 199 Charlotte Street, Brisbane. As the facts will show, `charlatan' would be a more appropriate address in the circumstances. I have been shocked and dismayed at the attitude this company has taken. It has shown a complete lack of desire to assist its client in any way in this emergency situation.

I have in front of me a copy of a letter in which Lumley General Insurance has formally denied liability for the loss. It states that my constituent's policy only covered goods transported by road. But as I said earlier, all roads were under water. Unbelievably, however, Lumley's has had the temerity to deny liability without a formal claim even being submitted. It has even refused to issue my constituent with a claim form. I have been told in no uncertain terms by Lumley General Insurance that, `This is the end of the story'. However, I disagree and I am determined to ensure that this in fact is just the beginning of the story.

A number of other insurance companies that have clients in similar situations have issued claim forms and are investigating the same. While the final outcome of these claims is unknown, it has been indicated that the insurance companies do recognise that their clients were operating under emergency circumstances and that the claims should be assessed accordingly.

I do hope that these companies recognise their moral obligation and that they accept liability. I refer here specifically to Mercantile Mutual Insurance (Australia) Ltd and the AMP Society. I call on them not to take the same approach as Lumley General Insurance. I ask the House: what is the use of an insurance company that makes general propositions to clients and then relies on cute legalisms in an attempt to avoid its moral obligations?

Basically, Lumley General Insurance is saying that `If you want to test our ruling, then you spend more of your hard earned money and take us to court'. These types of insurance company should be closely examined by the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs (Senator Tate) as to their fitness to be involved in the insurance industry. If this is the approach Lumley Insurance takes--

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cowan Mr D.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I generally try to refrain from raising in the House parochial matters concerning my electorate, but I am deeply distressed by the matter which I would like to raise tonight. It concerns the town of Bulahdelah situated on the Pacific Highway within my electorate. In the town there is a volunteer bush fire brigade and a volunteer rescue association.

SPEECH.PARA: Recently these organisations acquired telefinder pagers from Telecom Australia so that they could contact each other in cases of emergency. They now find that the pagers fail to operate simply because there is need for a telefinder repeater in the area of the township. The township has a population in excess of 1,000 people. It is a large farming area with a timber industry, dairy industry and grazing industry.

In making a decision to reject this town's request for a repeater station, Telecom Australia has neglected to recognise the fact that this town is situated on a busy highway. Practically all the calls that these voluntary organisations receive are reports of accidents on the highway, involving people who do not even reside in the district. They certainly receive a couple of such calls every week. The situation is always urgent. The organisations are notified by the police to attend the accident immediately. They save people's lives. I know a few people who have been saved because of the work of these organisations. But now they find that their pagers cannot operate properly.
I have made representations on behalf of these organisations. Telecom Australia admits that they should not have been sold the pagers and it has offered to refund their money.

This is not the point. Whilst I recognise that Telecom Australia is a corporate body, surely to goodness it can bend a little to supply telephone repeaters to two voluntary organisations, each with 14 or 15 people active in them. The organisations were talking to me only the other day, and I totally agree with the complaint they have that they are entitled to this equipment. They are doing a virtually national job upon a busy highway-the Pacific Highway-which is inadequate to meet the great demands of the traffic in that area. It is mountainous land and there is often an accident there. Undoubtedly, something has to be done to assist them.

I am wondering whether the Minister, who was in the House last night at this time, may be prepared to lean a little upon Telecom Australia and to point out to it how necessary it is that these voluntary workers, saving the lives of many people year in year out, should receive their telephone repeater, which can be easily located within the area to give the service. They have also pointed out to me that, when the people who have pagers are travelling through areas such as Newcastle and the Taree-Forster area nearby, they are unable to use them because of the poor reception. I raise the matter here because I am very concerned about it. I have a sympathy for the people concerned and for the work they have done, as I said earlier, from a voluntary point of view. I ask the Minister to try to assist the people concerned.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Taylor Mr W.L.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 14 November 1990:

QUESTION.PARA: Did the Government, in the ALP policy launch on 8 March 1990, commit a sum of $15 million to marriage counselling and the provision of counselling services in remote areas; if so, (a) what action is the Government taking in response to the recommendation of the Australian Institute of Family Studies to coordinate policy across accredited agencies for the delivery of marriage counselling services, (b) what are the guidelines for accredited agencies to apply for funding from the sum committed by the Government, particularly for services in remote areas, (c) how is the sum to be allocated, (d) what is the Government's formula for funding accredited agencies, and (e) will there be any discrepancy in funding between agencies which provide identical services; if so, (i) will discrepancies exist between Church and non-church agencies and (ii) what will be their justification?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Duffy The Hon M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) No. In the ALP policy launch on 8 March 1990 the Prime Minister, Mr Bob Hawke, committed the Government to an extension of marriage counselling and related services. The sum of $15m was not mentioned. However, the Prime Minister did commit a total of $128m over three years to a range of proposals to deal with crises in people's lives which included the marriage counselling funds.

(2) (a) The Report of the Australian Institute of Family Studies was launched in June 1990 and its recommendations have not yet been fully considered. However the Government has set in train a number of initiatives in this context:

(i) a number of meetings have been held between peak bodies representing Marriage Counselling organisations and officers from the Attorney-General's Department to establish the needs of clients and the best way in which organisations, with the assistance of the Government, can address those needs. These discussions have included the question of the most cost effective ways of addressing the needs of rural and remote Australia;

(ii) a mapping exercise is underway to determine those areas most in need of counselling services. When this has been determined, the Government will be able to expand services more equitably than has been the case in the past and more effectively use the limited funds available;

(iii) mindful of the limits on the available funds, the Government is also taking steps to place an emphasis on the quality of the services provided and to put in place financial controls to ensure that funds are expended in such a way that the maximum benefits are achieved;

(2) (b) Guidelines for organisations seeking approval to conduct programs of Marriage Counselling, Family Mediation, Marriage Education, Adolescent Mediation and Family Therapy are available for organisations seeking funding. Copies of these Guidelines are available from my Department.
(2) (c) The sum is to be allocated as follows:

A further $0.760m was set aside for administration, with $0.440m remaining unallocated. The additional funding in 1990/91 has been used to augment existing services. A decision on the allocation of the additional funding available in 1991/92 and 1992/93 has not yet been made.

(2) (d) At the present time funding of the services provided by organisations is on a cost reimbursement basis of up to 75% of the amount expended. As part of the review of the manner in which the Program funds services, the funding formula is to be assessed for effectiveness and may be amended.

(2) (e) As agencies are funded on a cost reimbursement basis, it is feasible that agencies providing identical services but incurring different levels of costs may receive different levels of funding.

(3) (i) Some church organisations have lower costs because of their greater use of volunteer labour and access to church owned facilities. Since funding is on a cost reimbursement basis, funding levels will reflect such lower costs.
(ii) Not applicable-church affiliation is not a criterion in relation to funding.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Langmore Mr J.V.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 13 February 1991:

QUESTION.PARA: To which countries did Australia export weapons and military equipment in 1989/90 and what was the value of those exports to each country.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bilney The Hon G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: Values for each export destination are shown in the following table. The statistics embrace all defence related goods as covered by Schedule 13 of the Customs (Prohibited Exports) Regulations and therefore also include such items as cryptographic goods for financial institutions and non-military lethal goods such as sporting rifles and related ammunition.
DEFENCE EXPORT APPLICATIONS APPROVED BY FINANCIAL YEAR AND COUNTRY WITH EQUIPMENT VALUES
(1) Actual exports differ from statistics on applications resulting in a permit because sales do not always proceed after approvals have been granted or some deliveries are yet to be made.

(2) These statistics do not include applications relating to temporary ``exports'' such as returns sent to Australia for repair, goods returned for warranty reasons or goods exported for demonstration reasons. Such applications will add another $81m to the 1989-90 total for approved applications.
(3) Approvals resulting in exports are those for which documentary proof of export has been received.
